<Author>canehdiangrl
<Content>married at the majestic Stayed from Sept. 9-16 at the Majestic, then travelled to Excellence Punta Cana.Beach: Soft white sand, gorgeous clear blue water, very warm with gentle waves for swimming and some okay snorkelling. No difficulty finding a beach chair. No towel games. The beach waiter came around every hour or so, and drinks took about 10-15 minutes to get from the beach waiter (in contrast, it would take you about 5 minutes to walk up to the beach bar, get a drink, and make it back to your seat, as the bar is not directly on the beach). Hint: The punta cana area sits on the eastern coast of the D.R., with the Atlantic Ocean in the northern part, and the carribean sea in the southern part. If you want a nice beach, pick a resort along Bavaro Beach, which is the Carribean Sea. Our resort further north of the airport was closer to the Atlantic Ocean, which meant the beach was way too dangerous to swim in due to big waves (I'm a strong swimmer and I wouldn't have gone in). Room: As part of the wedding package, we were upgraded to a 1-bedroom suite, which was on the 4th floor. The elevators were sometimes working, and sometimes not, but we are able-bodied and it helped us get some exercise. The room was pretty clean, except for the giant hairball left by someone else on the top ledge in the shower that stayed there for the whole week - we named it cousin it. It became a bit of a joke just to see if or when it would disappear. The bed was an average hotel bed - hard with the occasional spring sticking out a little bit. Air conditioning worked well, no musty smell. Our power didn't go off, but it did for everyone else we were travelling with. Some occasional very small ants around the bathroom sinks, but we have had the same at all of the 5-star hotels we have stayed at in Mexico - I think they just go with the humid climate. We also had a Gecko in our room, but I figured he was eating the bugs, so didn't worry about it. Food: If you've been to a 4 or 5 star resort in Mexico, then to compare the food, think similar, but down a notch. When you drive to the resort, you'll see that they are poor and have nothing, so it's amazing that they can provide what they do at these resorts. And what they can get is a little bit limited, so it makes for them putting together some interesting combinations. The food at the buffet sits under lights, but don't be fooled, they weren't exactly warming lights, because the food was usually lukewarm at best. So we stuck to salads, breads, cold foods, or the made-to-order stations, and had better luck. Everyone in our group had at least 1 day where they were a little under the weather, so bring some basic over the counter medications and you should be able to cope. Drinks: Bring insulated travel mugs. They don't have many brands of higher-end name brand liquor, but they have some, and you must ask. It's true that their frozen drinks are watery, and you have to ask to make sure they add liquor - often, they will ask you, with rum? The lobby bars and martini bars make the drinks in the traditional blender-style, and they are better, but these bars are way too far from the beach and the pool to use as your drink source throughout the day. Bugs: Our ankles were eaten by sand-fleas or no-seeums on the beach (not sure what they were). It didn't affect our days on the beach, but at night, our ankles were itchy. Bring bug spray - we had spray with 35% DEET. The mosquitos are small, fast, and do come out at dusk. Many people walking around with numerous bites. I kept After-Bite with me at all times. Climate: Thunderstorms at night, very hot and sunny in the day. The beach has a nice breeze - there was no breeze by the pool.Pool: Big, no problem finding shade or sun. No towel games. Quiet parts and noisier parts. Entertainment: Too wiped out from the sun to stay up late for the 10pm shows, but did see a little bit, and it was the traditional resort-style entertainment, with laughs produced from hotel guests doing silly things, or shows that gave you something to watch, but didn't really entertain. Service: Polite, but not always friendly. Staff didn't really try to speak English, but the front desk people were better. Overall: It was a nice vacation, but we came here for the wedding service they provide (which was perfect), and we like to try different resorts, so I know we won't stay here again.

<Author>bowlmeova
<Content>A best buy in the Caribbean!!! My review will be rather lengthy and completely candid. I hopethat in reading it, anyone contemplating the Majestic Colonialwill feel fully informed about this wonderful resort. I will coverall bases starting with the planning of the trip to the departurefrom the airport.Planning: Check a lot of websites about any vacation destinationyou may consider. For this trip, the best deal price wise camefrom [---]. It's the first time I've usedthis source but it won't be the last.Assuming you have selected Punta Cana as your destination,include a private transfer from the airport to the resort of yourchoice. In doing so, your stay at the airport after luggageretrieval will be minutes. Those who elect to save a little moneyby not using a private livery can be at the airport up to an hourwaiting for a van to fill up. Then it is a 30-40 minute ride to theresorts area of Punta Cana.The Majestic Colonial: It is in a word SUPERB!! When enteringthe lobby you will get the feeling you made a good resort selection. The registration is quick and friendly. During thisprocess someone will give you a complimentary fruity drink called a majestic. A nice touch.Room selection: Our trip was mid-September, the low seasonin the Dominican so there should be some flexibility should aparticular room be not to your liking. All rooms have four digits.The first indicates the building. Bldgs. 2 and 3 are preferredas they face the pool. Bldg 1 faces an older and not so nicelooking resort while bldg 4 faces new construction of a resort.The second digit is the floor . There are 4 and I would avoid thefirst floor for one reason. Anyone will have access to your roomif you forget to lock the sliding door to the patio. The last 2 digits are the room # itself. Plenty of elevators to the upper levels.There are different room sizes and prices. We selected aJr. suite ( smallest and lowest price ) For 2 people a jr. isexcellent. This small room has over 500 sq. ft. of space!!Marble flooring throughout and a king size bed ( in our roomanyway ) The room has a jetted tub but it is out in an open area.It was of no concern to my wife and I. You may read in other reviews that the shower / toilet area offered no privacy. Not soin my case as both the shower and toilet areas had 6 footopaque glass doors that cannot be seen through. The shower is huge and again all marble. There is a decent amount ofstorage space for your clothes, a safe for valuables, and a mini-bar ( more on that later )The grounds: A really stunning place and one of the cleanestI have seen anywhere. The groundskeepers are working almostaround the clock to keep the Maj. Col. super tidy.The staffers: Everyone is very friendly and ready to be of assistance. Learn a few basic Spanish words and phrasesand it will make things a lot easier in communicating.You can get a paperback book from Amazon.com for $2.00that has commonly used phrases. Most of the staffers speakpassable to good English.The restaurants: This is the one area where I have somenegative issues, but to a relatively minor degree. The Maj.Col. has 7 restaurants, 2 of which require reservations fordinner ( Le Gourmet and Matsuri--Matsuri only for the teppenyakiwhich is like a Benihana ) One of the issues is that in lowseason, not all restaurants are open every day. This is notmentioned in the resort webpage ( it should be.....full disclosureMaj. Col. ) As a result we only dined at Le Gourmet once( the steaks there are very good ) and Matsuri was not openon any day we were there. On Thursday evenings the resorthas a beach party so all but one restaurant is closed for dinner.This is not a good policy for the resort to implement. There is aCaribbean food place ( Taino ) decent food, nothing memorableserved buffet style, I liked the goat meat.There is an open air restaurant near the beach serving buffetlunches and sit down dinners ( beef , chops and seafood beingthe specialties ) The chateaubriand is fine except they substitutethe mashed potatoes with french fries so it isn't really achateaubriand. There are some flies in this restaurant, but it is open air so this is not a major downer for me. In the sit downareas, the resort does not change its menus either.The biggest mistake the Maj. Col. makes in the buffets is thatthe food in trays is generally cold. The reason is their  heatlamps are the size of a night light!!! I don't know anyone wholikes cold scrambled eggs or sausage. On the plus side, the buffets have chefs who will prepare hot meals at any time of theday that are very tasty. So just be wary of the buffet trays beforeyou load up a plate. The buffet salads are good and the desserts are ok. This is not haute cuisine, which I'd neverexpect at an All inclusive. If I want the very best in dining, I wouldtravel to Paris or to Italy.Beverages: The room has a minibar stocked with soft drinks,bottled water and Presidente beer. There is a limit of 2 beersper day in the minibar but the suds drinkers can have all theywant at the resort bars. Leave a $2.00 tip for the minibarstockman and you'll get exactly what you want. Leave a note withthe tip indicating your preferences.As to mixed drinks, they are fruity and not very alcoholic. I don't have a problem with this. The resort doesn't want its guestsgetting hammered!! Jimmy at the lobby bar makes a terrificlemon frozen daquiri. For you boozers, premium stock isavailable at an extra fee.The POOL: The best I have seen anywhere in all my travels.It is 1200 feet long, in a snaky shape. There are sections wideenough for swimmers to do laps. There are areas with jacuzzijets as well. The pool is extremely clean. The water depth isa uniform 3 ft. 9 inches ( that's 1.15 meters for you metric unitfolks ) There are also a couple of kiddie pools for the toddlers.As an aside, this resort does not cater to children so unlessyour kids will be happy at the pool and the beach with nothingelse to entertain them, perhaps you should consider anothervenue. Hey!! this ain't Disney!! Mucho beach chairs and palapasto go around. The quieter part of the pool is closest to the lobbywith the fun and games closer to the beach.The beach: Again lots of chairs and palapas. A very cleanbeach with soft sand that doesn't get hot even at high noon,and no rocks or shells in the water. The beach is Atlantic Oceanwater but surprisingly not too wavy. All in all, one of the finerbeaches I have seen.WARNING: for the prudes and those bringing the kiddies.Women can go topless. Didn't bother me save for the fatbroads who should just know better about undressing inpublic.Tipping: LIke some other reviewers, I recommend bringing100 dollar bills for tips. Use them to inspire better than theexcellent service you're going to get anyway. Tip the chambermaid daily ( 2 or 3 bucks will do ) Do the same for the serversin the restaurants, including the folks who just clean your table of empty plates at the buffets. $1.00 per drink at thebars will get you better drinks in time. These guys rememberthe guests who remember them. Before you leave for home,give $5.00 to the nice kid at the beach towel hut. He speaksno English and has the most boring job at the resort, yet he hasa ready smile for everyone despite the tedium of his work.The bugs: Some reviewers have complained mightily aboutinsects. They just weren't an issue for my wife and I. Goprepared though. Bring a repellant ( 30 % DEET ). Themosquitos are tiny, the size of gnats. They can be bothersomeat dawn and at dusk but they go away during the day.There are sand fleas at the beach and their bites will itch so pack some type of itch relief. They are not a major problem though. Show me a beach without sandfleas!! Be sure tokeep the sliding door to your balcony closed to keep themosquitos out of your room.Wrapup time: It's possible that some travelers had a badexperience at the Maj. Col., hence some negative reviews.We all know some folks just like to [---] no matter what.I cannot fathom the bad reviews. The Majestic lives up to its name and it has to be among the best bargains anywhere inthe Caribbean. If you're traveling on a tight budget this resortcannot be beat. I may never go back to the Dom. Rep. as thereare too many places in the world I haven't seen. However, ifI do make a return visit it will assuredly be at the magnificentMajestic Colonial.Departure: Get to the airport at least 2 hours prior to flight time.Americans need not pay the $10.00 exit tax.One last thing, if you do have issues with this or any other resorttalk to someone in charge as I did with 2 restaurant managers. They want tourists to recommend their venues and as the oldsaying goes  the squeaky wheel gets the grease

<Author>domincanadecorazon
<Content>Magic at the Majestic! I had the pleasure of staying at the Majestic Colonial for one week with two of my girlfriends. We had a fabulous time at this resort... the weather was amazing (but prepare to sweat 24/7!) and the accommodations were roomy and comfortable. Since we chose to go in the off-season, the resort seemed quite empty at times, but I personally loved this aspect because we received extra attention from the staff (many of whom knew us on a first-name basis), and it also made the ambience more relaxing. I would like to direct attention to a very special group of people who work at this resort, because they are the ones who made our trip unforgettable... The Animation Team, as they are collectively called, are a group of young men and women who run the entertainment at the resort. They direct all kinds of activities during the day, ranging from dance lessons to step aerobics to silly games you can choose to participate in, and a nightly 'show' that often involves audience participation. They are all very excitable and so much fun to be around, and they always aim to please, so lose your inhibitions and learn to dance the Taki Taki and the merengue. As some of the only single girls in a resort full of couples and families, we definitely got more attention from the guys than we otherwise would have, but this was a great way to learn the merengue and more about the Dominican culture. The more Spanish you know, the better, so make the effort to use what you know... but your English will be easily understood as well. Some people whom you should seek out during your stay include:Martirez and Elsa... If you are a gym-goer and want to stay fit during your stay, head to the small but homey gym on the premises. There you will meet Martirez and Elsa, two wonderful people who will be your personal trainers. Martirez looks like he belongs on the cover of Men's Fitness magazine. He is very patient, knowledgeable, and curious about you, and he loves to talk baseball since he used to play minor league ball and actually grew up with some of the best MLB players out there today. And, of course, he's an amazing dancer :-). Elsa is a super-fit and super-friendly aerobics instructor who will always greet you with a radiant smile... but don't be mistaken, she becomes a drill sergeant in the gym!!! Talk with her about her family, especially her daughters, and you will learn about love.Pablo, Leo, Jesus, Jan, and Melvin are some of the most visible members of the team, often found near the center of the pool or on the beach. They are FANTASTIC dancers and want to teach you all about Taki Taki and merengue. These guys are fun and want you to have fun, so make the effort to get to know them! And don't forget to greet Eddie, the sports bar DJ, who will keep the beat pumping with the hottest hits during your trip! Walter El Mosquito is in a class by himself... when you see him you will understand his nickname... he marches to the beat of his own drum, and if you are lucky enough to catch a glimpse of him, you will split your side laughing while watching him in action. Besides Elsa, we unfortunately didn't get to know the girls as well as the guys, but Lina, Coni, Pamela, and Espaghetti deserve a special shout-out. They are all beautiful and tons of fun as well, and we encourage any male travelers to seek them out and dance with them. Get to know the Dominican people during your stay. Whether it be the man cleaning the pool or handing out the towels (Francicos), or serving you at the restaurant (look for Henry at the beach palapa), they are at your service, and by making the effort to talk with them, you will discover the friendly and loving nature that embodies the Dominican culture and spirit.Many thanks to all of these people who made our week in Punta Cana truly unforgettable.... we will miss you all very much and hope to return sometime soon.

<Author>Patusia
<Content>Beautiful hotel, fantastic holiday We stayed at Majestic for our 2-week holiday, 5-19 June. It鈥檚 a beautiful hotel and we had a great time. Check-in Check in was quick and easy without any problems.Grounds 5/5Amazing! The layout of the buildings with a fantastic swimming pool that runs through the hotel grounds is beautiful. The design of the grounds is superb, everything is well kept and wherever you are at the hotel the surroundings are beautiful. We loved that there were so many palms, plants, gardens with ponds and fountains. All of this truly makes the hotel majestic both day and night. There is no surprise that with such amazing grounds the hotel is busy with weddings. And neighbouring Majestic Elegance construction didn鈥檛 bother us at all. Weather During our 2-week stay the weather was very good overall. We had one day of rain from 11am till early morning next day. Apart from that it was sunny and hot all the time.   Beach 5/5Breathtaking, amazing and so long! We were very happy that there was no towel game and we didn鈥檛 need to get up at early hours to get a palapa. The beach in front of Majestic is wide and there are lots of spots to choose from. Ocean looks beautiful from the beach. Water was warm and calm during our stay. There are some stones on the left side, but the right side is just sand. We did some snorkelling, saw some nice fish but I would recommend going for a trip to some of the great snorkelling spots in the area. We walked along the beach a few times and Majestic beach seemed much nicer and less crowded than Bahia, Riu and Iberostar鈥檚 beach. Pool 5/5We only spent a few hours of our entire stay at the pool. We preferred to stay on the beach with white sand and comfortable breeze. But still the pool at Majestic is the best pool I have ever seen. Room 5/5We stayed in room 3241 鈥?building 3, second floor, garden view and partial ocean view. The room was specious and always cleaned well. The bed was very comfortable and Jacuzzi worked well. The bathroom/toilet layout didn鈥檛 bother us at all. The balcony is huge and we enjoyed having coffee there and looking at beautiful views. If you like spending a bit of time on the balcony then I recommend asking for a room in building 2 or 3. If not, then it doesn鈥檛 matter where you are at Majestic. The fridge is stocked up daily with water, beer and soft drinks. And also we had face towels in the room- 2 changed daily. Service 5/5 All staff was very friendly, helpful and although they work hard and long hours they all keep smiling. Nothing is a problem for them and they do their best to make your holiday special. And yes, some staff do not speak English but we were in the country where Spanish is an official language so it was up to us to learn a few words and phrases. Please remember that the staff do not get the education we are used to at home, but they could teach European hotels鈥?staff a lot about service and smile! Food 3/5Unfortunately, here we had a few problems. Yes, the choice is very wide and even very picky eaters will find something they like. There is no problem with that. We both got sick. Hubby got sick on 4th day (before any trip), I got sick in the second week. We were very careful with water, using only purified water for brushing teeth, we didn鈥檛 drink any dairy cocktails, avoiding lettuce, creamy cakes etc. We do believe that we got sick at the hotel. (At our 1st trip which was only half day we didn鈥檛 eat anything and at our 2nd trip we both were already ill.)It didn鈥檛 spoil our holiday, we still were able to enjoy the hotel and relax. Entertainment 4/5The animation staff work hard to entertain everybody around the hotel. There are activities at most times. We saw a few shows 鈥搒ome very good, other so so. The Michael Jackson show was the best. We visited the casino at the hotel a few times 鈥?it鈥檚 small but pleasant. I was lucky to win on the machine all the money my husband lost on the roulette! TripsWe did Caribbean Festival that was fun and staff made sure that everyone was having good time. Bavaro Runners was very informative and included horse riding, Dominican school and home visit, cigars 鈥渇actory鈥?and Macao beach. It was very well organised. Overall we had a great time. And we will definitely be back one day!Big thank you to Richard  AnnMarie for your help and hospitality. And thank you everyone on TA Forum for your advice and helping us choosing Majestic.

We were supposed to arrive on 8/20 but due to a sick family member (not going with us) we were delayed 2 days. This was the first time I bought trip insurance (only $17 pp) and I鈥檓 glad I did as it should pay for the 2 days of the hotel not used.At PC airport, be prepared to pay $10 per person for a tourist card which you hand back 5 seconds later. The bathroom situation which I鈥檝e read about is a minor inconvenience. One wrote if with kids, get a bathroom with a door, however all rooms have this situation. When you enter the room, the bathroom is on the right, without a door. There is a big double sink, a toilet behind a frosted 戮 length door, a huge marble shower behind another frosted 戮 length door, and a Jacuzzi bathtub. The bathtub is not enclosed. We got changed either in the huge shower or in the entranceway. Some people wrote about lack of washcloths, to us it is no big deal. However, you can just call housekeeping and they will bring you some. You鈥檒l probably need more pillows also, as they are flat.The room has a hairdryer, iron, free safe, bathrobes (nice touch!) and tiny tubes (1-2 usages each) of shower gel, shampoo, and conditioner. In the entranceway are closets and the minibar stocked with water, soda, and 2 beers. We also got champagne and chocolate bars. There is a nice size patio with 2 chairs and a table. Building # 2 鈥?most desirable because ALL rooms face the pool and you are closest to the buffet. There are 4 floors (elevators), and on the 1st floor you reach the pool via 4 bridges. The first floor rooms all have access to the pool via the patio and they have 2 comfy lounge chairs. These rooms have king size beds and I was told 鈥渘ot for families鈥?although I did see some families with younger kids in them.Building # 1 鈥?adjacent to building # 2 and actually the beginning and ending rooms of each of these building are steps across from each other. In the middle of the buildings is a fountain. Rooms in this building face the Grand Paradise hotel next door.Building # 3 faces the spa and pool.Building # 4 faces the construction side of the new Majestic Elegance hotel.Loss of PowerThis did happen on several days, each outage only lasting 5-10 minutes.Pool1200鈥?feet long, running alongside the entire length of building # 2. Plenty of lounges available with shade. (at other hotels, you have to wake up at the crack of dawn to 鈥渞eserve鈥?chairs 鈥?not the case here) It is huge, even at full occupancy you had plenty of room in the pool to yourself. <Author>Lorrayne G
<Content>Majestic is the right name for this hotel! Yesterday, my family and I (including two daughters aged 14 and 6) reluctantly returned to England after two amazing weeks at the Majestic Colonial hotel (August 19th-September 2nd). I am a frequent business traveller (2-3 times per month) and therefore am more than used to travelling around the world and staying in hotels - so I have high standards, but I am also very reasonable and realistic in my expectations of hotel standards and customer service. In addition, I have regularly visited the Caribbean islands of Barbados, Jamaica, Antigua, Cuba and the Dominican Republic with my family for my annual vacation. Dominican Republic has been our island of choice for the past 3 years in a row for value for money, lovely hotels, lovely people and convenience (direct flights from UK). In 2006 we stayed at the Ocean Blue in Punta Cana (loved it), in 2007 the Iberostar Hacienda Dominicus in Bayahibe (liked it but not as much as the Ocean Blue, the pool was a big disappointment - quite shabby), and in 2008 the look of the amazing pool at the Majestic Colonial meant that rather than return to the Ocean Blue, which had been the original plan, we would try the Majestic. We were not disappointed!!Check InUpon check in, we were greeted with the Majestic Cocktails and Majestic Cookies and given our wrist bands. I noticed throughout the stay that the wristbands for adults were different colours - ours were cream, others were red and others silver. I found out later after asking a friendly waiter that this was so the staff know where we are from - Cream = British, Silver = American/Canadian, Red = Spanish. Which would explain why we were often greeted in English rather than Spanish by staff, when others were greeted in Spanish. We were immediately taken by a bell boy to our two rooms - 1403 and 1404.RoomsWe had two standard suites with two double beds in each. I was initially a little disappointed because I had hoped that my room would have a King size bed. The hotel was fully booked but offered to change the rooms in two days so that we could have a king size bed when quite a few people were scheduled to leave. In the meantime, a maid arrived immediately to push the two beds together and remake the beds so that the sheets and matresses held them together - voila - one 9ft bed!!!! We liked the 9ft bed so much we didn't bother changing after the two days!! The bedroom was very well furnished with lots of added touches to make the stay comfortable including two white towel robes and slippers, iron and ironing board, free to use electronic safe, free minibar which was stocked up daily with a bottle of house champagne (not actually champagne, but French, sparkling and quite drinkable!), two Presidente beers, Pepsi, 7UP and the local version of Orange Fanta, Red Rock Naranja, plus of course bottled water. It's not mineral water, but purified local water called Alaska - which is to be expected. There was a coffee machine, colour TV with the usual US channels - CNN, ABC, Starz (great for films), BBC America for us Brits and also German, Spanish and Italian stations. The bathroom was great - a big jacuzzi and fantastic walk in shower which could easily fit more than one person and double sink. The bathroom is part of the room with the jacuzzi bath forming the division between the bed and the bathroom and the toilet is separate but has an opaque glass door which does not meet the floor or ceiling - so if you are sharing with someone who you would really rather couldn't see or hear you on the toilet - then this might cause a challenge!! The room also offered room service, but as we were in a standard room, there was a cost to receive room service. Other higher rated rooms included free room service. PoolOh my God.... the pool at this hotel is the best ever!! I just can't find fault with it at all. It is huge - and is split into two areas - a quieter area for people who don't want to be involved in the games and activities, and then the part where the activities take place. A very small kids pool is also in the 'busy' section along with a swim up bar. The pool is not deep - only about 110cm deep, so my 6 year old daughter could stand up easily in any part of the pool without worry. The number of sun beds and shady parasols were also just right. As a result, I didn't see any of the mad scramble to put down beach towels at 6am to secure a good spot that often happens at other hotels,. Everywhere was good! The quiet pool also has a jacuzzi area which is just by the bar (not swim up). The bar by the jacuzzi closed just a few days into our holiday, I guess because the hotel got quieter as we were coming close to September and the end of the school holiday season. So as a result, we had waitress service by the pool instead, even better. By the end of my stay, the waitress didn't even need to ask what I wanted, at regular intervals, our drinks would just appear!!! She was amazing..... I just wish I could remember her name! The pool was very clean compared to other pools, I saw no debris at all - no leaves, no dead insects etc the entire time I was there. Majestic Kids ClubA big hello to Angelica, Massiel and Pablo - our friends at the Kids Club. They are a credit to this hotel - especially Angelica, if I could take her home to be my daughter's Nanny I absolutely would! My 6 year old daughter absolutely loved her! This is the first hotel I have stayed at where Georgia begged to go to kids club every day. The facilities at the Kids Club are good - a small pool with two big slides, a manmade beach with sunloungers, widescreen TVs, pushbikes etc etc. The Kids Club had some renovation going on as Majestic is building a sister hotel, the Majestic Elegance, right next door which directly impacted the Kids Club, but apart from it being not as pretty to look at as it normally would be, it was business as usual!!RestaurantsThere are 7 restaurants at this hotel - two of them require reservations, the rest are walk ins. Buffet Restaurants Portofino  SupremeThis is classed as two restaurants - but the reality is it is one huge buffet with two seating areas. We ate breakfast here every day. The buffet is indoors and airconditioned - which is a bonus as I have stayed in many Caribbean resorts where the buffets are in areas with no windows or doors. This means that you can eat in comfort without being too hot and also that there are less 'wildlife' with you - no birds flying around your head, and hardly any insects etc. The buffet had everything - omelettes, eggs and pancakes cooked fresh to order, fresh bread, ham and cheese, fresh fruit, donuts, cakes, muffins, waffles, Bacon, Sausage and other local foods. Fresh fruit smoothies were made to order and champagne was available for those wanting champagne and orange juice. The coffee was regularly kept topped up by waiting staff, with fruit and herbal teas and hot chocolate also readily available. I often read on Trip Advisor about people getting stomach upsets. I did too - but quickly realised that it wasn't down to poor food preparation but more likely my inability to process the combinations of food that I was eating - especially eggs. As soon as I stopped eating little bits of everything from the buffet, and also stopped eating the omelettes (tough as they were yummy!) my stomach settled back down. When I looked at the combinations of food others around me were eating I did wonder if other people's stomach complaints were also 'self inflicted' without realising!Restaurante Taino - Mexican.This was my least favourite restaurant. The food was OK but wasn't as good as the Mexican at the Iberostar had been the year before. But we ran into an old friend, one of our waiters remembered us from the Iberostar where he had also worked when we had been there in 2007 - very small world, and how lovely that he remembered us and went out of his way to smile and say Hello!Restaurante Matsuri - Tepinyaki/ChineseThe tepinyaki part of this restaurant requires reservations and is in demand as it can only sit 12 on each of the two tables - but the wait is worth it, the food is great and the atmosphere is so much fun! We went 3 times, each time was better than the time before. The food was great and the 'performance' from the chefs were amazing. It's also a great way to meet and chat with fellow holiday makers, as it is virtually impossible to not talk to your neighbours unless you don't speak their language! My 6 year old daughter actually wanted to eat the shrimp (prawns) and realised that she really liked them - I could never get her to eat it before! The Matsuri also has a sit down chinese section which does not require a reservation.Restautante Le Gourmet - FrenchThis restaurant does not allow children under 12 years old and also requires a reservation, so my husband and I went there for just one night. The food is very good and the wine list is wonderful with a sommelier there to help with recommending and tasting a wine if you need help. The wine here is chosen from a wine list and is not included in the All Inclusive fee. So we chose a lovely Louis Latour Chablis for USD37 which was added to our checkout bill. Restaurant Steak House 'Rodeo Grill'  Seafood Restautant 'Tres Carabelas' The Beach Buffet Restaurant changes at night into two restaurants - the steak house and the seafood restaurant. As it's also the beach restaurant, this is the only restaurant that is 'outside' and therefore not airconditioned. We didn't try the seafood as my husband and kids are not fish eaters. The steak restaurant was good - I had a lovely sirloin steak twice and the chicken once. My chicken was very overcooked, but I know that my children's chicken was very nicely cooked each time they ordered it - so I guess I was unlucky.Garden Coffee BarIf you just want a simple breakfast, rather than go to the buffet - self service coffee, orange juice and croissants are available opposite the buffet by the pool. In the evening, the garden coffee bar turns into a bar and a band plays with dancing. Onsite Doctor/PharmacyThis was the first year that we didn't need treatment for ear infections - so I can't comment on the quality of the 24 hour onsite doctor (hurrah) but there is an onsite pharmacy where my husband was able to purchase painkillers for a headache. ShoppingThere are a number of shops at the hotel. The checkin reception area held the cigar shop and the Caribbean jewellers, Harrisons. Outside there was a number of additional shops - a Mini market selling postcards, sweets and crisps (very expensive - USD13 for a packet of sweets and a big bag of crisps), plus toiletries and suncream, rum, Majestic branded tshirts etc. Other shops sold clothing including bags and tshirts branded Gucci, RalphLauren, Lacoste, Chanel etc (although they clearly were not), costume jewellery, local paintings etc. PhotographersTropical Photographers are the onsite photographers and have photographers roaming the grounds permanently offering to take pictures. Sometimes with animals from the local zoo - monkey, iguana, smake, parrots etc. They can also be booked for private photo sessions. The photographers are very good and after a little bit of negotiation over the price when you go to collect the pictures, not hugely expensive. The standard price per printed photo is USD12, USD10 or USD8 each depending on the size of picture. But if you buy a few - you can always negotiate - we did and were very happy with the final price. One word of caution - they do not accept credit cards, so be prepared to pay in USD or visit the ATM in reception to withdrawn Dominican Pesos to pay.GymI used the gym twice and felt very virtuous when I first arrived, but then the pull of the buffet and the bar became too strong!!! The gym had all the usual equipment and has someone around to help with how to use the machinery if you need assistance. SPAI didn't use the spa, but it looked beautiful and very well equipped using Mary Cohr products. When we were there the SPA was offering 15% of treatments. Animation/EntertainmentFor some reason, I always end up falling asleep at some ridiculously early hour when I go on holiday - I think I get too relaxed. As a result, I only saw one show - which was entertaining - if you are thinking 'Broadway Musical' you will be disappointed, but if you think 'local amateur dramatics - lots of enthusiasm but not always matched by talent' you will enjoy it for nothing else than laughing at them. My daughters actually saw more than we did as they were desperate to see the magic show but my husband and I were too tired - so they went without us. It was so nice to know that they could go and be fine, no worries about safety. The shows all started at 10pm which is a bit late in my opinion - 9pm would have been better as I might have gone to more and also the children wouldn't find it too late to watch too.WeddingsThere are two places where couples can get married - the 'Tronera Bodas' which is a small outside pavilion for weddings and also a small onsite chapel which also takes Catholic Mass on Saturday evenings at 1830.Well, what more can I say. This place is great - simple as that. They are building the new Elegance right next door and therefore some people will have views of the building site (luckily we didn't, we overlooked the hotel on the other side of the Colonial) - the Elegance sounds like it is going to be even better than the Colonial with extra touches of luxury being added. However, the Colonial delivered everything we needed and more. The staff do speak English, some better than others - but they do want you to speak to them in at least a little bit of Spanish - which is fair enough in my opinion! You don't need much to get by....1) Ola - Hello2) Adios - Goodbye3) Por Favor - Please4) Gracias - Thank You5) c贸mo est谩 - How are you?6) Muy Bien - Very well7) Excellente - Excellent8) Con - With9) Sin - Without10) Cerveza - BeerThat's it - ten words that pretty much got us everything we wanted, together with a big smile and a response that was usually in English from the staff but you could see they really appreciated us at least trying, and laughed when they tried to get us to say more in Spanish and our faces went blank!!Do I have any recommendations for future visitors - yes, make sure you have enough USDollars - especially if travelling from Europe. If you want to purchase anything in the shops - photos, more suncream, postcards etc, the shops will want you to pay in USD notes and will be very reluctant to take your credit card for the transaction especially if it's not for lots of $$$$. The photographers won't take credit cards at all, plus you will need USD30 cash each to enter and leave the country. On one occasion when I needed to get more money from the ATM it had run out of cash and as it was a Saturday, it would not be restocked until Monday. Reception did try to help but the best suggestion they came up with was to ring another hotel and make arrangements for us to go to the hotel and visit their onsite bank, which we decided wasn't necessary and we simply waited until the ATM was restocked - luckily our purchase wasn't urgent.Will I go back to the Majestic - absolutely!!!! The staff at this hotel work very hard and I know for a fact that management watches them closely - on a couple of occasions, I saw them being lined up and given their orders and even reprimands, the staff certainly looked like they had to work hard - everything was very efficient and quick for a Caribbean resort...... The hotel deserves it's 5 star hotel rating and it deserves a 5 star Trip Advisor rating too!!!!Enjoy!

<Content>Still Beautiful This was my second visit to the Majestic. My first was two years ago. This resort is absolutely gorgeous and it might very well be one of the prettiest resorts on the entire island. The food is OK, but not great. Breakfast was by far my favorite meal. My husband is an extremely picky eater and he always found something to eat. As far as the food is concerned, I've always wondered why they don't have a restaurant that is dedicated to just serving Dominican food. The Taino restaurant for some odd reason had a Dominican buffet, but serves mexican food off of the menu. The Mexican food is not very good. In my opinion, they should stick to good old fashioned Dominican cooking at the Taino restaurant b/c I'm sure that many people would love to experience a typical dominican meal.There were a couple of things that I found had changed from my last visit. During my first visit, the frozen drinks were actually frozen. This time around the drinks were watery as they came out of the machines and the bartenders added crushed ice. Not a big deal for me, but if you a big fan of frozen drinks, you will be disappointed. Also, the power went out at least once every day, once again, this wasn't a big deal for me but I do remember that during my first trip the we never lost power (maybe it has something to do with the resort being at full capacity). If all you care about is relaxing and enjoying the beautiful surroundings, then this is the resort for you.

<Content>nice holiday! My daughter (7) and I just got back from the Majestic and we had a wonderful time!- I had read some reviews of the hotel that were so bad that I was a little scared to go and thought that I may have made a mistake booking there- fortunately we experienced none of the problems others had - such as food poisoning, giant cockroaches, etc.  We went mainly to swim in the beautiful ocean and pool- both were amazing! The beach was gorgeous and the surf was not too rough for my daughter to swim in and the sand is soft and perfect for building castles and digging. I also loved that the pool is 4ft deep throughout and is so long and winding -there were always areas for kids to jump and swim around without bothering anyone- there is also a section for volleyball and a swim up bar....  In my opinion the pool really was the best part of the hotel - it is warm - which I don't mind - and it was also kept so clean.  We were given rafts our first day from departing guests and I would highly recommend bringing your own rafts, sand toys - plastic pails and shovels - the gift shop is unbelievably expensive - a little set of beach toys (like the kind at a dollar store) was $25 US - there wasn't a price tag on it but that is what the woman at the counter told me .. (sunscreen was also $20 - which we did have to buy....so bring plenty of that too)  The rooms were clean and ours was always well stocked with towels and the fridge was restocked every morning. Mosquitoes there are smaller , faster , smarter - bring spray! It doesn't seem to last long - The hotel will spray your room at night - if you need fumigation call the front desk . I had our room sprayed once- It worked but smells awful afterward and you can't exactly air it out or the mossies will come back.... -We tried a few of the restaurants and had nice meals and very attentive service- The grilled snapper was delicious and so was the chattaubriand (sp?) at the steakhouse....The breakfast buffet was perfect for my daughter - pancakes, bacon , fresh fruit, - plenty of variety and they replenished the buffet frequently-We tried the teppanyaki (sp?) restaurant - we had to make a reservation for this and had one time to choose from for the entire week we were there- it was OK - we are from Toronto and so have some favourite Japanese restaurants here.... I wouldn't have bothered to make a week in advance reservation for this restaurant again- the other restaurants are better - especially the outdoor restaurants by the beach. After visiting there I would recommend:-definitely bring mosquito repellent, sunscreen, raft and beach toys if you have kids- flashlight - the beach is really dark at night - also there were power outages almost every day - at night it can be scary for kids when the lights go out as the room gets pitch dark instantly - the outages didn't last long when we were there - ***pillows- this may sound silly but - I have to say the pillows at the Majestic were the absolute worst pillows I have ever slept on- if you want to get a good night sleep bring a pillow -Have a great time!!!

<Author>churrosCanada
<Content>Paradise from a realistic perspective! We just got back from the Majestic colonial after a one week stay I am writing this review because I feel that many previous posts are unrealistic and dramatic! People have booked and researched thier vacations and are departing questioning whether they have made a huge mistake and contemplating whether to cancel or switch to alternative accomodations as a result of some of the outrageous claims being posted!I am not saying that the Majestic is perfect and without room for improvement - but what resort in the caribbean (DR for that matter) is? We are very scrutinizing and picky (I am a self-proclaimed stickler) and proud of it and i am telling you that the Majestic is above average! The food selection /availability and freshness is good by caribbean standards. Breakfast in the main buffet is wonderful. The selection of freshly baked goods (where else do you have a chef baking croissants in front of you and making churros and donuts on a daily basis?) Where else will you get a chef making crepes? omelettes? eggs to your liking? champagne and orange juice? personal smoothies? and this is just breakfast! The Dominican coffee is wonderful - drink as much of it as you can because you will miss it when you're gone! Even more memorable are the cappuccinos (many people don't realize that you can order them in all the restaurants including the buffet!) Enjoy them because they are delicious! The a la carte restaurants are also decent - some better than others (but that is anywhere you go) Lets face it -there are many resorts that don't allow you unlimited a la cartes, nor do they allow you to just walk in and be seated at your convenience, like the Majestic. I have travelled all over the caribbean and despise being told I am only allowed a certain number of a la cartes and have to prereserve at times that aren't necessarily conducive to me. At the Majestic - whenever YOU are ready for dinner you show up painlessly at a restaurant and have your meal. That is what a stress free vacation should be about! The lobster at the Seafood restaurant is wonderful (which is why we enjoyed it a few times)! The Chateubriand at the Steakhouse is also quite good (we also enjoyed that a few times)! The Mexican is below average as is the Chinese! The best places for dinner are the Buffet (Large selection), the Steakhouse and the Seafood Restaurant .Another wonderful feature of the resort is that you do not have to wake up at the crack of dawn to race to claim sun loungers and palapas - there are many and you will find one if you show up at after breakfast.The service is average - you will find happy people and not so happy people doing their jobs. We didn't find that the staff worked better/worse dependant upon tipping. Tip those people who you hit it off with because they made your experience a little more special! The animation team is average - based on previous travels I really didn't feel that they made the vacation more memorable. They really need to revamp this team because a few seem to be working hard while others seem to be there for the wrong reasons (dead weight that anchor the whole group). The resort also needs to strengthen their kids club - while they have the facilities in place they do not have a strong animation team reaching out to the kids. On 3 evenings there was nobody working at the kids disco and the kids were sadly dissappointed. Upon probing we just got excuses and passing of the buck from the animation team.The general cleanliness of the resort is above average - although I will say that they need to strengthen their maintenace department - as there are many things in need of repair that seem to be let go. Sadly, if this continues this resort will look old really fast ( it is only 3 years old but looks older due to lack of upkeep).To be realistic, the Majestic is above average from DR standards - as I have stayed elsewhere twice in the DR I can confidently say that. Yet, you see that it has so much potential and caters to a clientele that does expect a lot - well travelled, educated and experienced - so one would like to see the Majestic reach its full potential. With stronger management and more attention to service this resort can/will meet its full potential. It is truly a diamond that needs to be polished so that one can truly appreciate its lustre.Do not hesitate to go to the Majestic - every person I met there had a positve, relaxing experience (many felt that it had exceeded their expectations). Go with an open mind and you will surely have a wonderful and relaxing vacation!

<Author>MAZ-JMZ
<Content>P-E-R-F-E-C-T Vacation First of all, my Husband and I are in our early 60s and this was our first trip to Punta Cana, as well as our first time at an all-inclusive resort. We booked our trip (8/13 鈥?8/20) through Liberty Travel (Kimberly Scharf) in St. James, NY. We had direct non-stop flights on American Airlines from JFK.ARRIVAL: We arrived at the Majestic at approximately 4:00PM and were personally greeted with an icy cold Majestic and welcomed by Annemarie (who is a very sweet and lovely young lady) at the check-in counter. She made sure we made our dinner reservations at LeGourmet (French) and Matsuri (Teppanyaki) before she personally escorted us to our room (#2127) 鈥?(which was one of the four room choices we had originally requested). Upon entering our room, we found a Welcome Platter and a Bottle of Champagne on the table to welcome us. That personal touch made us feel special right from the start.ROOM: We were in a Majestic Junior Suite (which is a Ground Floor Swim-Out Suite) in Building #2 along the Swimming Pool, directly across the Pool from the Spa. Our room was in the middle of the resort (between the Lobby and the Beach) where it is quieter. This room category is Adults Only. Our room had a slightly musty odor (which is common in the Caribbean), but Lysol Spray took care of that in a very short time. The room was large and very clean. The air conditioning was very comfortable and the ceiling fan circulated the cool air throughout the room. We took the advice from prior TA Reports and brought two of our own flat rubber stoppers (for the jacuzzis) and an automatic night light (which we placed in the outlet by the sink). We also brought RAID Flying Insect Spray with us to spray our room each day for any mosquitoes that may have gotten into the room, but we never had a problem.ROOM SERVICE: They have a very limited menu, but on several occasions we found the Club Sandwiches for lunch while relaxing on our private terrace to be very good, along with a bottle of Presidente from our mini-bar, which was fully stocked daily.TAP WATER: Do NOT drink or use tap water to brush your teeth or to rinse your mouth or toothbrush. We used only Bottled Water and had NO problems. Be sure to keep your mouth closed and be careful not to swallow any water while showering.SUNSCREEN: We brought SPF-60, 45, 30 and 15 along with us. We both started with SPF-60 on the first day and got very little color. My husband (who is obviously smarter than me) continued to use SPF-60 throughout our entire stay and came home with a nice golden tan. I, on the other hand, thought I knew better, and decided to step down to SPF-45 on the second day and ended up burning rather badly on my chest and arms 鈥?sun blisters and all. Only you know how badly you will burn in a very strong sun 鈥?BE VERY CAREFUL.BEACH  OCEAN: The beach is absolutely gorgeous with soft white powdery sand. There were always plenty of palapas and lounges on the beach to relax in the shade. The ocean was always calm and crystal clear during our entire stay. The water temperature was very warm (at least 85 degrees).SWIMMING POOL: There were also plenty of palapas and lounges in the various areas around the Pool. The Pool was always very clean and warm (sometimes actually too warm and more like a bath). Be sure to bring your own Pool Float(s) with you to float around on as the resort does NOT provide them.BARSWET BAR (Swim-Up Bar): This bar is located near the Beach end of the Swimming Pool. They serve drinks on the Pool side (as a Swim-Up Bar) as well as on the Land side where they have several tables  chairs. Be sure to say 鈥淗OLA鈥?to Maximo at the Wet Bar (on the Swim-Up side). He is the one who is always smiling and saying 鈥淵EAH BABY鈥? Everyone seems to love him and when you meet him, you will definitely know why.BEACH BAR: This bar is located in the center of La Hispaniola which is located in the Palapa Hut on the Beach.LOBBY BAR: This bar is located in the lower Lobby and is a gathering place from 5:00PM 鈥?1:00AM. Whether it be a cocktail before dinner or a night cap after dinner, be sure to say 鈥淗OLA鈥?to Pedro and Alejandro, who are both a lot of fun and make great Dirty Monkeys and Mojitos.PIANO BAR: This bar is located in the upper Lobby. They have live piano music in the evening. Be sure to say 鈥淗OLA鈥?to Roberto. He is also a great guy.PLAZA BAR: This bar is located outside in front of the Buffet Supreme. They have live music in the evening with plenty of tables to sit at while relaxing with your favorite beverage.CASINO: The casino is small, but not too small to have a little fun in after dinner. There are 3 or 4 tables and about 20 鈥?25 slot machines ($.01 - $.05 - $.25). The casino also has a small bar to the left as you enter.RESTAURANTSBUFFET SUPREME: This restaurant is located adjacent to the lower Lobby. The only meal we ate at the Buffet was a huge breakfast each morning, which is my Husband鈥檚 favorite meal and which we both enjoyed very much. They had several different food stations: Omelettes 鈥?Fried Eggs 鈥?Waffles 鈥?Crepes 鈥?Pancakes 鈥?French Toast 鈥?Mimosas 鈥?Fresh Fruit  Fruit Smoothies 鈥?Mini-Pastries. They also had a buffet table with bacon (the best I ever had), ham, sausage, etc. You will find practically anything you could possibly want at this buffet. The Chocolate Croissants are to die for.LA HISPANIOLA: This restaurant is located in the Palapa Hut on the Beach. It serves a continental breakfast in the late morning and lunch and afternoon snacks during the day. (In the evening, this restaurant becomes the Steak/Seafood Restaurant, which is separated by the Beach Bar, for dinner.) We ate lunch here a few times and found the Pasta Station to be the best choice. They had several different kinds of freshly cooked Pasta (cooked in front of you) along with 3 different Sauces (Tomato Sauce 鈥?Meat Sauce 鈥?Alfredo Sauce). I tried all 3 Sauces and they were all very good. My husband also had a Panini Sandwich one day for lunch and he liked it very much.LE GOURMET (French): This restaurant is located in the lower Lobby and is Adults Only. The food and service were both excellent. Entr茅e choices: Filet of Beef 鈥?Grouper 鈥?Red Snapper 鈥?Chicken. We both had the Filet of Beef which was very tender and very good. The only thing we did not care for was the spice used in the gravy served on top of the filet. It was a rather strong-tasting spice that was unfamiliar to us.MATSURI (Teppanyaki): This restaurant is located in the lower Lobby and has two separate rooms (each room seats 12 people) around a Teppanyaki grill. Entr茅e choices: Filet Mignon 鈥?Chicken 鈥?Salmon 鈥?Shrimp. Each person is allowed to choose 2 out of 4 choices. Since there were 2 of us, we ordered all 4 choices to share between us and each of us got to taste a little of everything. Our entr茅e was served with Fried Rice. Everything was superb and we also enjoyed the Teppanyaki Chef鈥檚 unique presentation.TRES CARABELAS (Seafood): This restaurant is located in the Palapa Hut on the Beach. A few small tables overlook the pool. Entr茅e choices: Grilled Lobster 鈥?Grouper 鈥?Red Snapper 鈥?Garlic Shrimp. We ate dinner here 3 times. We had Grilled Lobster 2 or 3 times and each time it was cooked to perfection 鈥?moist, tender and very tasty. My husband also had the Garlic Shrimp and he enjoyed that very much as well.RODEO STEAK HOUSE (Steak): This restaurant is also located in the Palapa Hut on the Beach. It is separated from Tres Carabelas (Seafood) by the Beach Bar. Entr茅e choices: Chateaubriand 鈥?Sirloin 鈥?Churrasco 鈥?Pork Chops 鈥?Brochette. We ate dinner here 2 times and each time we enjoyed the Chateaubriand with Bearnaise Sauce served on the side. Both times the Filet was very tender and juicy and cooked exactly the way we ordered it 鈥?MEDIUM RARE.LA BODEGUITA DEL MAJESTIC: This is a late-night Snack Bar and is open from 11:00PM 鈥?6:00AM. It is located on Caribbean Street near the Casino and Sports Bar. My husband had the Deep Fried Hot Wings and Nachos with Cheese several times and he enjoyed them both.CONCLUSION: We both had a wonderful and memorable vacation in Punta Cana and look forward to returning to the Majestic in the very near future. We found the resort to be very clean and beautiful, our accommodations to be very comfortable, the dining choices to be numerous and the food quality to be far more than acceptable (based on US (Northeast) standards). The Dominican people are extremely hard-working. Most of them work 16-hour days and as many as 12 consecutive days (or even more) before getting 2 or 3 days off. Some of them actually live at the resort and away from their families because it is too long a distance for them to commute on a daily basis. We found the Dominican people to be some of the friendliest and nicest class of people we have ever had the privilege or pleasure of meeting while on vacation. Instead of feeling like strangers in a foreign country (which is what we really were) 鈥?we always felt welcome and like we belonged because of the way the Dominican people reached out to us and welcomed us into their Country. Even though we did not speak their native (Spanish) language fluently 鈥?I am sure they knew that we were at least trying to communicate with them in their native language. I would highly recommend this resort to friends and family everywhere.Liked: EverythingDisliked: Nothing

I would even go as far as saying the largest standard rooms I have yet to see. I think they are all jr suites.The are very well kept and quite nice. As for the privacy issue, only if you have older children and are planning on taking bubble baths do I see an issue because the tub is not closed off, otherwise the open concept suits me fine ( I have a 4  2 year old) with me so I had no problems. The shower is large  towels were always readily available. No, the bed is not heavenly but I have slept on worse in carribean resorts. Do not think you will get the beds they have at the Bellagio in Vegas at an all inclusive in Dominican, I mean come on! 3- The beach and pool are the few things everybody agrees on and that is because they are GORGEOUS!!! I can't say more than seeing is believing.3- Here is the big one... FOOD. Admitedly not the best. Very comparable to other all inclusive resorts. I would like to know what people expect at a dominican resort? Do you expect to have Wolfgang Puck pop up and cook for you? I think not. When you have travelled, you know what to expect in an all inclusive. Want fine dining? pay for it  go to another island...try Aruba, Bahamas, Antigua.. but I garantee you the price won't be the same! You are in the dominican people accept it for what it is  you won't be dissapointed. Have I had better? YES, have I had worse? YES! 4- Service is extremely friendly. The language barriers though can get on your nerves. They (most of the employees) do not understand a word of english. That's what they should focus on, teaching their staff to speak basic english. Management needs to understand how important this is!! Had alot of difficulty communicating our needs, big downer. I must say though, that we are tippers, so I can't say for sure that this is why they were so nice to us cause I saw many people not tipping and they were just as nice. I'm sure it played a bit of a role in their attitude towards us but heck, my two kids are a handful  I gladly tip anyone that has to deal with them at mealtimes!5- Animation is probably as good as anywhere else I've been that does this sort of thing. They work hard and in this heat god bless the whole team for having that type of stamina! Listen is this what we consider a 5 star hotel? Probably not. I would definetly give this hotel a 4 star review because on the whole it is a very nice place to go relax and enjoy a week of sun. I would not return only because I never go to the same place twice (besides Vegas  Atlantis in Bahamas, who blames me right?) I saw alot of couples and I do believe that it could be quite romantic, assuming you don't bring your screaming kids with you like we did! Overall I was simply impressed and would definetly recommend this place. Don't listen to the naysayers, it is a good hotel at a good value. Even a really picky person cannot argue with that....I know cause I am a really picky person. Hope this helps you decide.

<Author>cherylhans
<Content>Beautiful resort This was our 2nd time to Punta Cana, and our 1st stay at the Majestic. It was tough not to compare to our previous resort stay at the Grand Palladium Bavaro four years ago! The first thing we noticed was the tremendous amount of construction going on as we entered the hotel grounds. We were a bit disappointed at the landscaping, as this could not compare to the beautiful grounds of the Grand Palladium. Keep in mind, the construction. Once we entered the lobby, check in was quick, easy, and we were greeted with a Majestic non-alcoholic drink, which is just want we needed after our long trip. While we were not escorted to our room as our other travel companions had been, getting around and finding our room was quite easy. Compared to the Grand Palladium, the Majestic is on much smaller grounds, although still quite large. We had two adjoining rooms with 7 in our party. The rooms were quite amazing! Every room is a suite, and they are top notch. I have read a lot of reviews about the bathrooms being open. While this is true for the tub and sink area, the toilet and shower stalls have coated-glass doors, and there is privacy. Each room has a balcony with table and chairs, and we had a beautiful view of the pool area and an ocean view (rooms 3332 and 3333). We did have a problem the first two days with the room sensor system. This system indicates when you are in or out of your room, and it also shuts off the fan and air conditioning system while you are out. The problem with ours was that it constantly thought we were out and kept shutting off. After contacting the front desk several times and finally getting the manager of the hotel and the manager of maintenance, they were able to override the system, and the problem was fixed. We were told that this is a known problem with a few rooms in the hotel... so just beware. We also had several power outages nightly, which the staff blamed on financial issues in the country, whatever that means.As for the food, I think it was pretty average. We had some really good meals, and we had some really average meals. I do think they could have catered more towards little children (we traveled with a 6 year old). The food at the Grand Palladium was excellent, and although the food at Majestic was good too, I think GP was just a bit better. We ate at the Hibachi, which was probably one of the best meals, although our chef was new and didn't give us quite the show we expected. The steak house restuarant was quite good, although there was nothing on the menu for children. We asked for a hot dog, which we know they serve at lunch, but we were told they could not provide us with one, so our son had a roll for dinner, which was the case most evenings in every restaurant, even the buffet. We finally wised up by the middle of the week and took about 3 hot dogs at lunch and wrapped them up for dinner, so at least our son had something to eat. We were disappointed that the sports bar, which served hamburgers, nachos, buffalo wings, etc. was only opened at 11:00 pm, at which time our 6 yo was already sleeping. I guess again, in comparison to the Grand Palladium, they had a 24-hour sports bar that had everything from hot dogs, hamburgers, pizza, popcorn, nachos, ice cream, etc. I guess I was expecting the same 24 hour service. Other than that, none of us went home starving or losing any weight!The drinks were plentiful. Each day we tried to find a new special of the day drink. The Majestics with rum were great... as were the dirty bananas, banama mamas, and the blue lagoons. We found that the best drinks were in the hotel lobby (nice and frozen). The pool and beach were excellent. I must say that even though the hotel was booked, you would never know by looking at the pool/beach. We never had a problem finding a chair, or group of chairs (14 of us all together), and we did not hit the pool/beach until at least 11:00 am. There were plenty of activities at both each day, and we all took advantage of everything we could, even the 6 yo. They do have a Kids Club, but the activities there were not too appealing to him, as there were more fun things to do at the beach or pool. Shopping - if you want to take a nice long walk to burn off some of those extra drink and food calories, you can walk to the beach market, which is approximately 2-1/2 miles down the beach (facing the ocean, turn right and start walking). Just remember, it is about 2-1/2 miles back, although we did see a water taxi...but we did not use this, so I cannot comment. Every Thursday vendors come to the shopping area at the hotel. It is your typical jewelry and art work with lots and lots of haggling. One rule of thumb... they always at least double their asking price... so make sure you start out really low, and if you get it for at least half of what they asked in the beginning, you'll be okay. You can also barter in the hotel shops (which I didn't realize until this trip). Excursions - we took the safari outback excursion, which was pretty good. It is an all day trip where you will be driving most of the time (manual jeeps). They take you to a cigar factory where you can purchase cigars, rum, vanilla, cocoa, etc. We went to a family home where they share with you some homemade hot cocoa and island fruits with a chance to buy coffee, cocoa, vanilla, etc. We then went to lunch on a horse ranch, which was pretty good, and then we went horseback riding on the mountain. After that, we traveled to the other side of the island to the ocean with some beautiful scenery. The trip was $90 per person US, and it was well worth it... but it is an exhausting day. Overall, our trip to the Majestic was an enjoyable one. The staff was top notch, and we knew a lot of their names before we left. I would definitely visit this resort again, but next time I would be more prepared as far as the food was concerned for my children. I cannot say which hotel I liked more, the Grand Palladium or Majestic, as they each had their own qualities that I really really liked. The Majestic had much nicer rooms and was easier to get around. The Palladium had much better food with a much larger variety of restuarants. I guess it is in the preference of the visitor which is more important. Like I said, we did not go hungry, no one got sick, and we all had an amazing time!

<Author>Steelpoint
<Content>A good time was had by all.. This was our first trip to the Dominican Republic. We stayed at the Majestic Colonial from 8/16 through 8/22. My wife and I were traveling with four kids ages 15-21. We stayed in a beach front room and the kids stayed in a garden room in the same building. The resort is situated perpendicular to the beach, so with a beach front room you are a couple of hundred yards from the main building and the restaurants and activities there, which was not a problem for us because a walk after dinner was welcomed by all. The reverse of this is that if you are going for the beach and are in a lower numbered room closer to the main building, the walk to and from your room to the beach could be an inconvenience. The rooms are well maintained and well designed, constructed off all stone and woods with a very open layout. Every room has a jacuzzi tub. The shower is large enough for two with room to spare. The water pressure is somewhat low, but that is not unusual for island resorts. The in room refrigerator was restocked with soda, water, and beer every day. Every room has a safe, hair dryer, and iron. We did not have a problem with cleaning service. We did not have a problem with insects that I have read on some other reviews. Remember that this is a tropical island and a moth, ant, or spider can be expected. Is your house that tight that you have never seen an insect inside? The grounds are very well kept with constant gardening being done by the grounds crew. The food was average to good. The breakfast at the main building is much better than the breakfast at the beach. There is a larger selection and the food seemed fresher. The same can be said about lunch. The beach food is a little greasier and there is less of a selection. It also gets a little more crowded at the beach lunch than the main building restaurant so there can be wait times at the grill or stations. We found the quality of the dinners in the ala carte restaurants to be good. For dinner the steak house on the beach, Rodeo Grill, had a good atmosphere and the food was good. I found the Chateaubriand cooked perfectly and very tender. My kids had the sirloin which was also tender. The French restaurant, Le Gourmet, was also good. The guacamole martini appetizer was very good, as was the pumpkin coconut soup. Lobster Bisque was fair, although my 18 year old son had three of them! I tried the beef tenderloin which I thought was very good. My wife had the chicken and risotto which was also good. I thought the meat in general was good. When I asked I was told that all the beef was local. I found the Dominican restaurant, Taino, to be the best and most flavorful of the hotels restaurants. The Dominican Soup was very good. The Paella was also a hit. We did not get into the Japanese restaurant so I can't say anything about that except reserve early! The bars in the main building are the best for relaxing and meeting people. The service here was also better than at the other bars on the property. In general we found the service to be somewhat indifferent, although there were some who went out of their way to help. A knowledge of some Spanish was helpful in this regard as it made communicating our requests easier. If you are going to drink, you must try the Mamauana!The Animation Team will get you involved if you are caught napping at the beach or pool. They are friendly and fun. There was never a problem finding a place to sit in the sun or shade. There was plenty of room and the towel game was kept to a minimum. The beach is beautiful and kept very clean by hotel staff. There is a barrier reef a couple of hundred yards off shore that keeps the water at shore calm so swimming and snorkeling off shore is easy. If you are going to swim outside of the buoy line you have to be aware of boat traffic and hopefully they are aware of you. The snorkeling off shore right in front of the resort is poor, mostly dead coral and some common fish. If you head to the right down the beach a few hundred yards there is a reef right off shore within the buoy lines of the RIU(?) that is pretty good and safe as far as the boats go. We also did parasailing down at this part of the beach which was cheaper, $70 for 2 people vs. $85 at our resort. We all had a good time with this. The only organized tour we did was the Zipline Adventure, which I booked from home online. The ride to the interior was a fun 45 minutes that gave us a chance to see the towns and country side, which was the same route as the Island Safari as we saw their buses on the roads to and from the Zipline. The staff at the Zipline was very professional and the equipment very safe. I would recommend this trip to the adventurer in everyone.The Dominican Republic is a Spanish speaking country so a knowledge of some Spanish is very helpful. We had four kids with us who were fresh out of school with years of Spanish behind them. Communicating with the local people in their language seemed to get us a little more respect and attention on and off the resort. A Four Star resort on an island is not the same as a four star resort in your homeland. Your vacation will be as good as you make it. Roll with the minor problems, speak to the local people, learn the local customs, enjoy the beach and sun and you will have a good time.

<Author>momof3maryland
<Content>Fabulous! Perfect family vacation! Honestly, we never had a better vacation, regretting only that we didn't find the Majestic until now! Some of the negative reviews posted right before we left for Punta Cana almost made me switch hotels, and all I can say is we were all delighted with our stay at the Majestic! So glad we didn't change our reservations!This was our second trip to the D.R., but our first stay at the Majestic. We will DEFINITELY vacation here again. The Majestic is absolutely gorgeous, and the physical layout of the resort makes it so easy to enjoy all of it. We are a family of 5, children aged 20, 15, and 10, and EVERY ONE of us loved the Majestic. We are beach lovers, and this beach is gorgeous, there was always a nice breeze, the water was clear and refreshing, and there was plenty of shade. We didn't expect to join in any activities, but we did and loved it! Beach volleyball with Walter (loco mosquito boy!), and John, and beach aerobics with John were our favorite activities. All the animacion team work very hard to make sure that the guests have fun, and we especially appreciated the efforts of John and Walter! We usually don't participate in group activities, as we enjoy swimming and reading on the beach, but we started with the kids being encouraged on Sunday, August 17, by another member of the animacion team to play Bocce (didn't get his name, also a funny, hard-working, friendly guy) and they were reluctant and shy at first, but the animacion gentleman pulled them in to play, and they ended up having a blast! From there, we were happy to participate in beach volleyball, coconut throwing contest, aerobics, stretching, and it was fun to watch the volleyball when we were too hot to play, and especially when Walter (loco mosquito boy!) was keeping score, which he and Jon both did in French, Spanish and English!! We are from the US and enjoyed the games along with people from all over the world. Our 10-year old son joined in the Kids Club soccer game on the beach, and ended up making friends who he enjoyed playing with the rest of our stay. The staff in the main buffet and the beach buffet were generally very attentive and most of the staff spoke English, Spanish, and we heard a good bit of French spoken by the staff, too. Very friendly, pleasant staff all around.Since our 10-year old son is a picky eater and not very patient waiting for food at a restaurant, we ate all meals at the buffet, and we always found food to please everyone. The crepes (especially those made by the magician chef early in the week) were delicious at breakfast, there was always fresh fruit and pastries galore. At dinner, there was always something to be found that was delicious and filling, especially the fish and chicken, vegetables and fruit.One day there was paella on the beach for lunch....lobster, shrimp, all cooked in front of us, with the animacion team encouraging everyone to come join in for the stirring! THe paella itself was delicious!We had excellent service every day on the beach by Denny, the beach concierge. We always had cold water, cervezas and Majestic drinks to savor!We didn't expect to go to any of the shows, but the way this place is laid out, the theater is right off the path from the buffet/lobby bar area to the rooms, so we did wander over to the Michael Jackson show, which John and the other animacion team members encouraged us to watch, talking it up on the beach in the afternoon. Well, we had fun watching it, the cast all worked hard and it was hot to be working so hard. If there were only big fans in the theatre like there are at the airport, we would have stayed longer at the show.The circus show featured some very talented acrobats and stunts, and was also entertaining, but again, we were too hot to stay for all of it.The rooms were gorgeous, the layout was fine. The shower is large enough to change in if you want privacy. We are a modest family, and felt fine in these rooms. The power did go out sometimes, but only very briefly and the air conditioner was easy enough to reset the few times we needed to.The balcony was great....there is enough of an overhang that we were able to sit out there on Friday when Tropical Storm Fay was hitting the island, reading, while it was windy and rainy. The layout again is worth mentioning, as you can walk to the buffet and lobby area without getting wet and staying in the shade, as the walkways are covered.We saw many families with strollers, older people with walkers, and it seems that everything was easily accessible for all.We booked this vacation with Bookit.com and the agent onsite was Turinter who also ran the shuttle from the airport. Everything was perfectly handled.We left several dollars for the maids everyday, and also left $ in the fridge or handed it directly to the minibar guy everyday. We tipped at each meal and we tipped everyone who served us. All of these people work very hard. We were glad to have had a lot of $1 bills with us for tipping.TIPS: Buy some cheap washcloths at the Dollar Store, colored ones if possible, and drape one over each faucet to remind you not to use the water for toothbrushing. Use the bottled water for that.We also bought cheap inflatable rafts with us, and our own snorkels. Bring plenty of sunscreen! WE didn't have any problem with bugs or mosquitos, but had supplies with us if we needed them. Bring a towel from home, colorful, to help you identify your chairs on the beach. Bring large ziploc bags for the wet bathing suits you'll have to pack up when you leave.This truly was a wonderful vacation. We usually spend a week at the Jersey shore, which we love, in August, but I have to say this may replace that from here on. To be able to be on the beach all day until after 7pm without being too cold, without greenhead flies, to be able to swim without being cold, to have a breeze that is gentle and cooling, yet not cold, and to have fun watching or playing games on the beach, and exercise on the beach everyday, was HEAVENLY!Top it off with being able to walk up to the buffet on the beach for lunch, and bar service on the beach! Can't ask for anything more!We were also happy to be able to attend Mass at the Chapel onsite on Saturday evening, even though it was in Spanish! Thanks.
