<Author>drpdd
<Content>Lower your expectations if you want to enjoy this resort This is a very difficult review for me to write - my aim here is solely to help those thinking about staying at this resort, in specific, or in Punta Cana, in general, make an informed decision and, hopefully, have a more pleasant experience. (my apologies in advance for any grammar/typos)Summary: If you are absolutely set on visiting Punta Cana, the Majestic Colonial is not a bad place to say as long as you lower your expectations - Specifically, you will not be dissapointed if you expect a 2-star start hotel. You will be fairly dissapointed if you expect a 3-star resort. And, you will be extremely dissapointed if you're expecting a stay in a 4-star or better resort.Lastly, I DO NOT RECOMMEND you book your stay through an agency unless you receive a significantly lower price than what you would receive through the resort directly. More on this below.I assure you, this is a review from a real person with extensive travel experience. Feel free to contact me by email if you have any questions or are looking for additional helpful tips.The specifics: I stayed at the Majestic Colonial with my wife and 8 yr old daughter from December 13th through December 24th, 2007.We chose this resort based on reviews we read here. Initially, my wife was concerned about some of the mixed reviews we read about the resort. We chose to dismiss some of the negative reviews since no resort can please everyone and since we had stayed at other all-inclusives in the past and felt our expectations were more realistic. Punta Cana: Before you consider this resort town as your destination, I strongly recommend you do some research (you can get a free and extremely helpful tourist guide to Punta Cana by sending a request to cpt@codetel.net.do). Punta Cana is a somewhat remote resort community - it is located in a very rural area that's 3 hours away from the capital city of Santo Domingo and 1 hour away from the closest thing to resemble a rural city. The color of the water there is magnificent, the sand is among the nicest you'll find in the carribean. The superlatives stop here - it's that simple. Overall, my impression of this community is that is it still trying to define itself and still learning how to present a professional experience for the seasoned tourist. Though everyone is eager to help and tries to be friendly, it is difficult to find the knowledgeable and experienced help that you'd expect to find in a supposedly major tourist destination. We consistenly heard from guests at various resorts that the overall service level and food quality at Puerto Plata, Dominica Republic is vastly superior, although the beaches are not as nice. Similarly, having stayed at the Riviera Maya and and Cabo San Lucas ourselves, we found the overall service levels to be much superior. (I am openly very biased in favor of the Mayan Riviera - there's simply considerably more to do there, the resorts are MUCH better, service levels are superior, and the beach and water there are heavenly as well.Our view of the Punta Cana resorts was confirmed by several fellow tourists who we met while at various excursions. Most had stayed at the other upscale resorts in the area (iberostar, bahia prinicipe, riu, etc.) To a tee, they all confirmed that their stay was not up to par. Furthermore, we had several locals (taxi drivers, exursion coordinator who told us the Majestic was the best or second best resort in the area. I would come back to Punta Cana again, but I would probably wait at least 3 years to give the area a chance to grow and find itself. Making our reservation: We booked our stay through Cheapcarribean.com. In the past, we always booked directly through the resort/airline/car rantal company etc. We went through cheapcarribean because the resort was sold out of units and cheapcarribean had apparently blocked some rooms . In hindsight, this was a mistake. Cheapcarribean, as do most agencies, have very strict cancellation fees. At most, you can expect to get a credit, not a refund, toward future travel thru that agency. Compare that to booking directly with a hotel where usually you do not get charged if you cancel up to 24 hours in advance. In this case, we were very dissapointed with the resort after our first few days of stay. Had we booked directly through the hotel, we would've simply found another hotel without any financial obligation. Because we had already paid the full fee to cheapcarribean, we did not have that luxury. Getting to the resort: The Punta Cana airport was quaint in a nice way - it is a small airport and it was built to exude carribean style with tatch roofs and open ceilings. At the airport, you will be mobbed by workers who want to help you with your luggage. I recommend you get one of them to help for a few $. The airport is small, but, it is not necessarily well marked. We had purchased transfers directly thru cheapcarribean, but did not have a clear idea where to catch the shuttle.  The resort: With the reviews we read, and having stayed at other all inclusives (the Riu Palace Cabo San Lucas and Cancun, the Iberostar Maya and Barcelo Maya both in the Mayan Riviera Mexico) we expected and paid for ($580/night on average) a four star or better resort. We also expected a mega-resort comparable to those found in the 4-star category in the Mayan Riviera. To say the least, we were disappointed based on this expectation. (initially, we thought our stay may be better at one of the many adjacent truly mega-resorts - but, as we found out later, this was supposedly one of the top resorts in the area.When staying abroad, I tend to be fairly forgiving in many areas. I know the employees generally work very hard to please everyone. I know the cooks generally try to make the cleanest best food they can. I know management generally try to motivate their people as best as possible. When it comes to the safety of my family, I am not as forgiving. This resort had several areas that were of extreme concern to me:Safety: none of the roomc had peep holes or safety chains. Throughout our stay, we would hear someone knocking at our door and we were not able to safely make sure it was ok to open the door. The hotel saw it fit to have maintenance and maid service people knock on our door as late as 10:30pm. One night, we even had someone knock at our door around 3am in the morning. we did not open the door then obviously. I was appalled by the hotel's lack of courtesy to afford these standard and inexpensive safety features to their guests.Sanitation: Again, this is resort serving thousands of guests and you cannot expect hospital grade sanitation. However, I found general sanitation here unacceptable. Flies and bugs crawling on open food bars - especially the buffet/retaurant facility close to the ocean. Salads and cold foods served without ice or refrigiration (there would be ice around the food when it was first served. But the ice would not be replenished after it melts. not did the equipment supply any refrigiration) Before I would touch any uncooked items (fruits, salads, etc) I would bring my hand close to the food to check for temperature and, without exception, everything was always room temperature. Needless to say, I stopped consuming all salad bar, butter, milk etc period. Even with that, I constantly experienced mild pain in my stomach. (again, I had never had any symptoms throughout travel in Mexico and the Carribean) Water: you cannot drink water from the tap here -nor use it to brush your teeth. You'll have to use bottled water for that. (yes, Mexico has a similar problem, but four star resorts there filter their water for you.)Privacy: Ok, get this, all doors to public restrooms are always kept open. To the life of me, I just didn't get this. I closed the doors behind me several times when using the men's room, and someone would re-open the door. I know this cannot be a cultural thing.... (my wife and I theorized this must have to do with ventilation/HVAC - but were not sure). Though men/women could maintain a decent amount of privacy in most public restrooms, there were some were that was impossible. The urinal would be facing an open door ---- I am sorry, but I found this simply unacceptable.When we arrived, we were greeted with a gentleman who offered cold towel service and another waitress offering the Majestic special non-alcoholic cocktail. The lobby was beautifully appointed and was up to par with our expectations. We took the gestures to be a good omen for a pleasant stay. Boy, were were we wrong. The resort was build about two years ago. To best summarize the situation there, I believe the resort was built with very poor finish quality (open tiles, no mouldings on many doors, gaps in ceilings) the fit an finish in many areas is simply unacceptable for a 3 or 4 star resort. To compound things, it appears the resort may be operating on a shoe-string budget. Many of the repairs, if any, are done poorly. There is a general lack of PROFESSIONAL maintenane (you'll see a lot of people doing bits and pieces here and there - but they do not appear to be highly qualified) As a result, the resort facilities look considerable older than its age.Some find this resort to be huge. In my experience, I would call this a fairly small mega resort. It is considerably smaller than other all-inclusives in the area (the Gran Bahia Principe, Riu, and Iberostar next door are considerably bigger). There is also an overall lack of generosity at this resort. It is difficult to not sound like a spoiled american tourist here for I truly believe we are blessed to even have this opportunity to vacation) I just found it hard to fathom some of the offerings here. For example, the rooms do not have a pen and paper available. When we contacted guest services to request them, they said they do not offer such amenities to guests. None of the telephones in your room are marked - your only option is to press 0 for an operator. In all other resorts we stayed, we received a bottle of champagne and a basket full of fruits or crakers or something, here, we did not receive such a basket. In other resorts, you get 3 - 4 choices of hard liquor in your room, in addition to beer and soft drinks - here you get 2 bottles of beer per day and three bottles of carbonated drinks. Each day, you receive 4 bottles of water to your room (we tipped our waterperson everyday and received 8). One day, we did not receive any water. When we called to request water, we were told we get one bottle per person - that's three 16 oz bottles for three people to drink all day and rinse garggle etc... I had to call a supervisor at Guest Service and angrily point out that they could spare an extra 75cents of water for a guest staying for eleven days in suite at $580 per day. She promptly called someone to get four bottles instead of three :) sweetness. And they tell you you're supposed to drink 64oz of water per person per day to stay health. Their book library (books you can borrow while staying at the resort) consisted of about 30 English books. There were two ping pong tables in the entire resort. One was so delapidated, it reminded me of the makeshift table that was set up on LOST. There was one giant chess area and the pieces were broken and fractured. Guests have a choice of two games boards (Risk and chess). The workout facility was filthy and the floors were made of concrete with no padding or areas to stretch. The spa space was somewhat of a joke and only allowed you to use the space if you booked treatment. yet, many guests sneeked through the back swimming pool so they can enjoy the steam room and jacuzzi. The pools were long. But I found them so narrow and too close to the buildings - they had the feel of your local neighborhood apartment complex swimming pool. There is only one place where you can get towels and you have to look for it - in a resort this size, adding an extra location is an inexpensive option. Lastly, there is really not much to do around the resort (I know this sounds insane to some people) But I was bored a considerable amount of the time and likely found many others who were experiencing similar bouts of boredom.) I've never had that problem in the other resorts we stayed. Again, having stayed at similar resorts in the mayan riviera, you get considerably more for your resort $.  Guests currently stay in one of four buildings - with construction for an adjacent resort going on extended hours (yes 10pm) just yards from Bldg 4, we recommend you not stay in that building unless you enjoy looking at concrete blocks, watching construction, or need the sound and pounding of construction equipment to relax. Bldg 1, on the other hand, is a few yards away from another resort, and should you stay there, you'll have the view of another brighly colored building with many balconies staring right at you (there are not trees to block the view) If you don't like either option, plan on having a talk with the front desk staff (we were told they respond better if you fake being extremely angry) since there's a 50% or better chance you'll end up in one of those buildings. With the problems we encoutered at the hotel, I spent considerable time at the front desk and can assure you the front desk personnel spend a considerable amount of time moving people from Bldg 4 to Bldg 1 to - sorry that's all we have available. We lucked out ( if you want to call it that), in that out first room was in Bldg 3 facing the pool with a partial view of the oceanThe room: with three of us (my wife, daughter and yours truly) we ddecided to splurge on a colonial suite. Initially, we were given a room on Bldg 4, but requested we move to a different bldg and were given another room in Bldg 3. The suite was spacious - two separate rooms with entry, living room, small dining area a sseparate bedroom, jacuzzi, and bathroom with two sinks and one toilet (two would have been nice for a suite). We were pleased with the view of the pool and the partial view of the carribean. We soon found out the hotel had booked extra very pesty guests in our room - apparently the ceiling tiles were not placed correctly and that allowed flies and mosquitos to make an unhindered trip from the very hot ceiling to our room. we informed housekeeping and the maid promptly sprayed some very noxious cock-roach spray in our room - we informed here that we had flying insects and that spray would not work. Language barrier aside, I think she did her best to get us out of the room and into the pool while the insect spray went away. We also found out the shower drain was completely plugged and water would spill out onto the bathroom floor. In order to not re-live the nightmare that we encountered, suffice it to say, it took the hotel three days to fix the drain and on the fourth day a very very angry man concerned about the dozens of mosquito bites on his daughter and wife's legs, not to mention his own, to demand a different room or they would be finding new accommodations elsewhere. We finally moved to another room in Bldg 2. Up to that point, we were literally counting the days when this vacation would end. Things started improving a bit after our move. The new room had small ants everywhere - even our clothes, but we only had 1-2 occasional mosquitos to contend with and the bed did not serve as a biting bug motel like the other room. Also, by then we had ratcheted our expectations way down.Maid service: the maids in our rooms were consistently good and did a decent job in keeping the rooms clean as long as you allowed to come to your room before 12pm. After that, they may or may not come back. THERE IS NO TURN DOWN SERVICE at this resort. So make sure you have enough towels if you plan on taking two showers a day. Each day, we left a $3 tip along with a cosmetic item (my wife got 11 items from the $1 store to leave)I am not sure if this made a difference, but I felt our maids deserved it.Food; As much as I'd hate to revisit this subject, I guess I have to. This is hands down among the worst all inclusive food we've had. This is good if one of your goals in this vacation is to loose weight. I certainly did and so did many guests I talked to. As I mentioned previously, I refused to touch any salads, cakes, cheeses, cold cuts or any other item that required cool temperatures for the appalling lack of refrigiration and ice. The hot foods were without exception cooked almost beyond the point of recognition - I had a tough time finding a single item that would have any crunch to it - broccolio, caulifower, beans, rice, potatos, tomatos, cabbage - you name it, they were all cooked to the point where teeth were no longer needed. Soups were no different - each night you would have a selection of 1/2 dozen of soups that were all cream of something. Meats were inconsistent - some cuts were soft while others were girzzly and very tough. The food invariably was cooked with very little salt (and I watch my salt intake) and no consideration to herbs or spices what-so-ever. Here again, I want to mention the lack of generosity of this resort - limited vegetable selection, limited seafood (shrimp only offered in a paella - no asparagus, no scallops, no salmon, no clams, muscles- You get the same ho-hum offerings day after day - steamed potatos, boiled potatos, steamed then boild potatos...) For breakfast, my wife an I kept joking about how many different ways the cooks found to cook eggs - there were never less than 10- dishes made with eggs - omelett with cheese, omelett with ham, eggs over and easy, boiled eggs, plain omelett, scrambled eeggs, plain egg quishe, etc. The problem was there was very little else that was offered. For fruits, they constantly served, watermelon, cantelop, oranges and pineapple. NOTHING ELSE. Oh, we did find out for breakfast, you can have papaya or mango - but you have to request it directly from the cook there and you have to do it before 8:30 am because apparently both papayas are gone by then. Accordingly, I survived on rice and beans for three meals a day. Food lifesavers: The main buffet offers two pasta cooked to order stations and a lot of people took advantage of it to get out of eating the other food - there, the selection is very limited too - choice of the same 3 red sauces, 2 white sauces, 3 pastas, onions, green peppers, red pepper, canned (not fresh) mushrooms, and olives. I also heard the pizza there was good - my wife enjoyed a few cheese laden slices and I tried one - I found it acceptable.Breakfast: You can have a cook to order omelett with your choice of ham, cheese and onions - that's it folks. Also, they offer a milk-shake bar and I recommend the Zapote (local fruit) shake.Specialty restaurants: The Gourmet french restaurant is good for one dinner - we liked the steak they prepare there.  Beyond that, the food in the specialty restaurants is sub-par. We read the Japanese Teppenyaki restaurant is good and promptly made a reservation. For those of you familiar with such restaurants, you sit in a communal table and watch a chef expertly prepare food in front on you while doing various death defying tricks. We've been to many such restaurants and find the chefs are usually very funny and they've had years to practice and refine their craft. Our experience here was no less than comical. Our chef Francis must have literally read about Teppenyaki two hours before preparing our meals. His entire show consisted of playing catch with a supposedly raw, but obviously boiled, egg with two of the nine guests that were at the table. Next door, we heard sounds and applause from guests who were supposedly appreciative of their chef - but in our room, absolutely nothing. The silence was deafening. After a while, Francis broke down and confessed I don't know..... he said. He stopped short of cyring - but then at least we knew what to expect. By the way, here, the resort's lack of generosity again reared its head. Instead of lobster, scallops, prawns, steak etc that we had come to expect in other such restaurants - our choices were steak, chicken and shrimp with vegetables. That's it. The food tasted average - seasoning limited to salt and hoisin sauce. Here again, I was surprized to see the food sit there unrefrigirated for the rest of the night - our reservation was at 6:30 pm but I felt really sorry for the people who would come in at 9:30pm.What's even more comical is that every guest we talked to who at at the Japanese restaurant had Francis. I am now convinced that Francis is the only teppanyaki chef there and the noises we heard next room were a recording (I guess I've been watching LOST too much)Our theory on why food is so bad: We were later told (this is true) that all leftover food from the resorts had to be shipped and fed to actual prison inmates in the Dominican Republic. Service: at the main dining rooms, service is extremely inconsistent. Please, know that any tips you leave on the table must be shared by all service employees alike. This may in part explain the lack of consistent service for what incentive is there for one person to work hard while others don't. (If you do receive exceptional service and you wish to acknowledge that person with a tip, you must give it to them in their hand. Then, it is ok for them to keep it.) Here, expect that you may get water and possibly be asked if you would like to drinks something. No more. (your dishes may pile up on your table and they may not clear them until you leave). If you get better service than that, you would not get dissapointed. Another extremely dissapointing aspect of food service is the hours of operations. The main buffet breakfast in open from 7:30 - 10am. With the excpetion of the continental breakfast that offered by the beach, more on that below, nothing is served again until 12:30 pm. Keeping in mind, there is nothing to do at the resort after 6:00pm except for eating at the restaurants, a show that begins at 10 pm and goes till about 11:30pm and a smoke-filled disco that warms up about 11pm, your choices are to go to bed early so you can wake up for breakfast, or attend the show and take your chance at missing breakfast in which case you'd have to wait till 12:30pm to have a decent bite to eat. I am sure this resort will find the benefit of moving their breakfast hours to say 8am - 11am in the next couple of years. Room Service: You could order room service any time - Here's the actual menu: cheese, fruit, croissant, and jam $17 US Dollars plus 18% tax and $5 deliverySame as above but comes with eggs - $22Hamburger: $12Cheeseburger $14Steak: $22choice of 3 deserts: $8 eachAgain all items carry 18% tax and $5 deliveryContinental breakfast: Supposedly offered at the seaside facility from 10:30am to 11:30am for those who miss the buffet breakfast. The selection is pitiful: omeletts cooked to order with cheese and onions (if the grill is working or if the cook doen't run out of cheese and onions -usually within the first 30 minutes), stale bread rolls, unrefrigirated processed ham, and 2-3 fruits. If you look closely, you'll find tiny ants crawling all over the food and service utensils - occasionally you'll find someone who actually try to wave at the flies that come to have breakfast here. Sadly enough, this is the only place where you can get decent table service. Shows: A few of the shows are pretty good - after a few days, we found them to be somewhat loud and repetitive - so we avoided going there altogether. Plus, attending the shows, meant we would nothing to eat until 12:30pm and if you had dinner at 6:30pm, that was too long of a wait. One aspect of the theatre that I felt was wierd was how the seating was split up.Basically, the area facing the stage had no seating whatsoever going all the say back to the end of the theatre. So, there was this huge (abot 60 feet wide) open area in the middle of the theatre. Guests could sit to the left or the right of the theatre and only had one way to come in. This is difficult to explain but if you go there, you'll see exactly what I mean. I fail to find a reason for that for there were no performances in the middle of aisles. Exursions: This was the highlight of our stay there. Getting out of the resort made the stay more tolerable. My #1 recommendation if you wish to see the area is to hire a cab for 1 day($150) request an English speaking driver - the one we had is Franklin. The hotel will find a reputable and safe driver for you and you'll have a chance to customize your sightseeing. The nearest town is Higue (about 1 hour away) and there you'll find a cathedral that will blow your mind (it is of similar scale and magnificence to the grand cathedrals of Europe). We also recommend a trip to La Romana where there are numerous tourist things to do, including Altos de Chavon (where they filmed Jurassic Park, Rambo, Anacondas, and other movies) If you like to see the life of luxury, ask your driver to take you to Casa de Campos where you'll see the homes of Sammy Sosa, Steven Segal, Eddie Murphy, Steven Segal among other stars. If you're looking for authentic life, the city of La Romana is wonderful. You ccan also stop by a sugar plantation, a rum factory. Another option is to go on an exursion (wrip-off artists - I mean representatives are awaiting for you in the lobby of the hotel. You'll pay about twice the price and you're likely to see a watered down version of what is advertised (a visit to a rum factory means you'll stop by a rum store to purchase rum - a visit to a school means you'll drive by a school, a visit to a sugar plantation means you'll be taken to another store that sells goods for five times what you pay elsewhere and the drivers openly get a cut of the action. - Here but it is still an option.I heard some wonderful things about the capital Santo Domingo, but we did not have a chance to go there.Pharmacy: Make sure you bring insect repellant and some anti-itch cream with you. You will be bit whether you stay at the beach during the evening hours, you get our room in Bldg 3, or if you go out for an exursion. After I asked four different people at the resort about where to get anti itch cream for us and recieved 4 different answers - I learned there is a small pharmacy on premises next to the medical center. I was surprised to see the person there spoke excellent English but dismayed she wanted to charge $20 US dollars for a 1 oz tube of anti-itch cream (compare to about $5 in the US and $1.50 outside of the resort) and anther $20 US dollars for a small bottle of insect repellant. At first I thought she was asking for $20 Dominican dollars and then I thought she was haggling. She made it quite clear the price was $20 US and that prices were set. I later learned she charged $1.50 to other guests for 4 bandaids.

<Author>GailNewburgh
<Content>Bring towels! I have travelled to many, many all inclusives through the years, first staying at Club Meds, later on at much fancier resorts. What I missed at many of the more posh places was a lively activities team. It was ok if you wanted to sit on the beach or at the pool all day but I like to play games, do water aerobics and meet other people. The best thing about the Majestic Resort was their animation team. They kept you hopping with fun events, dance lessons, water aerobics etc. etc. They encouraged people to get involved and didn't cancel events because they were lazy. They really made the effort all the time! They also had several evening events that were fun as well.As for the resort itself, it is quite beautiful and well maintained. The food is fair -- nothing to write home about. The fact that they advertise several different restaurants is not a big deal. Most of the places have very similar menus. I am the sole vegetarian in my family but I found the salad bars extremely boring. Usually all inclusives have expansive choices for non-meat eaters but this resort did not. Each restaurant had a salad bar but they basically consisted of lettuce, cucumber, carrots and chopped cabbage with a couple of Chef's special salads which had fish in them. A little disappointing for me. I am not a big drinker but I was told that the liquor was not up to par, especially the tequilla. If you like to have poolside drinks delivered it doesn't happen here. Be prepared to go up to the bars yourself. The major gripe with this resort was the lack of beach towels. When you arrive each person is given ONE towel card. This entitles you to one smallish towel at the pool. Not a bath sheet, this towel does not cover the fairly uncomfortable plastic pool chair. If you come out of the pool dripping and dry yourself off with it you have to put it back on your chair wet. You cannot talk the towel dispenser person into giving you two towels. He is a towel security person and cannot be swayed. If you take your towel poolside so you have it when you get out of the water,and it is stolen, you are told you will have to pay $25.00 for another towel!!!! So bring your own beach towels with you!!!!! We also only had 2 bath sheets in the room, plus two hand towels and one wash cloth. They are certainly cheap when it comes to towels.Also remember to bring books with you - their little library cart has very few books in English.They also skimped when it came to having chalk around the pool tables (finally a tiny chalk appeared on our 5th day there) and the ping pong paddles were an embarrassment until late in our trip when they were finally replaced.All in all, we had a fun week - the weather was glorious, the grounds were beautiful, and the staff was very friendly.

<Author>rcamp9
<Content>Great Family Vacation My mother chose this hotel after much research and time and decided this would be the best hotel for us. We traveled as a family (6 people total) with kids ranging in age from 18-25. The airport was a very easy and quick process. Everyone has to pay for a $10 tourist pass, but everything else was very quick and easy, we found our bus quickly, but if you needed a taxi there were plenty available.  The ride from the airport to the resort was about 30 minutes and allowed people to see how the real Dominicans live, which I actually enjoyed. My mother however gets bus sick very easy, and was not feeling great by the time we got to the resort. Check-in was as expected, not as easy or quick as in the United States but still pretty easy. They had the name wrong for one of our rooms, so that took some time to get fixed but not too bad. The only problem was that we asked for 2 rooms with 2 beds but did not get any, all 3 rooms only had a king size bed, and one of our rooms was not ready when we checked-in and was not ready for some time. The Rooms:The Rooms are very nice, but I understand how some people complained about the lack of privacy in the bathroom. It really is not a big deal, but it is an open bathroom set-up, so beware. Our room was on the first floor with a view of the pool, and a hot tub on the back porch, which was very nice for relaxing at the end of the day, but if you do not like the music and noise from the pool, you may not want a room on that side of the building.Just another point, since we had 3 rooms I saw what people said about how some rooms were cleaned much better than others, including how many and what types of towels varying from room to room. I do not have much of an explanation for this, but did see this as well. However a few dollars go a long way with the staff, so keep that in mind!The Bars:All the bars had good, middle to top shelf liquor. I was very pleasantly surprised when I saw they had Stoli vodka, as well as Jack Daniel's, Johnny Walker, and other premium brands. All bartenders are pretty helpful, and very helpful and fun if you are willing to tip a little. The Food:I found the food to be pretty good. Now let me point out that none of my family are the type of people that live to eat, or are extremely critical of food. If you are that type of person, this section can probably be skipped over, because you might have completely different opinions than myself. With that being said, none of us had much of a problem with feeling sick. If you want to be adventurous with what you eat, you can, or if you want to stick to the basics, it is very easy to do that as well. The breakfast buffet I found to be very good. It does get crowded and have a slight summer camp feel with all the people wandering around, but food is good and there is a wide selection. The lunch is much better at the buffet than at the Restaurant La Hispaniola (which is closer to the beach and pool), which kind of stinks, but it is not bad to get out of the sun for a little extra time. Shirts are required which I actually preferred but I did see some people get upset with being asked to leave or cover up during lunch. We did not eat at all the restaurants, however the ones we did for dinner were good. The Steak House and Restaurant Tres Carabelas are located in the same place out by the pool and beach. These are nice places and the dress code is pretty casual, as long as you have on a polo shirt and shorts for the guys it is fine. We also ate at Restaurant Le Gourmet, which required a reservation and was much fancier than the other restaurants. The food was pretty good, and the dress was more formal with all men in pants but most still in flip flops. Come to think of it, I wore nothing by flip flops all weeks! The only other place we ate was Restaurant Taino which was the Dominican/Mexican restaurant. As expected this food was good, but upset all of our stomachs slightly, but the same would have happened if we had at a Mexican restaurant in the US!The Beach/Pool:The beach is gorgeous! The water is crystal clear, the sand is very clean, and there are plenty of chairs and cabanas for everyone. One thing about the beach is a lot of women go topless, which might be an issue for some American families, however is not allowed by the pool, so if it bothers you, stay by the pool. The Pool also has plent of chairs and very clean, although it is louder and filled with younger children than the beach. There is some great snorkeling right off the shore, and the waves were pretty calm the whole time we were there. The entertainment from the Animation Team was great. The dances and contest were very fun to watch and participate in. My family's personal favorite from the team was Jimmy, he was always looking out for us, and knew all of our names after only a short time there, but watch out he is a VERY good volleyball player. Overall I would say the vacation was GREAT! The main reason we went was for the Sun, Beach, and relaxation, and we got all that and more. Sure some things could have been a little nicer when it came to the room, but you know what, I go on vacation to get out of the house, so that was the last of my concerns. One more plus I forgot was the TV in the rooms are actually pretty good, with most channels in English including ESPN, and every room we saw had a DVD player, which is nice if we had remembered any DVDs. This was my second trip to the Dominican in two years during the month of December and it has only rained for about 2 hours total over the two weeks, which also helps makes for great vacations.

<Author>Esef
<Content>Simply fantastic and relaxing! My family of three stayed at the Majestic from Dec 14 - 21. We have a 51/2 years old. The experience was just fantastic. We arrived late on the first day - after midnight - and the check in went perfect. We had emailed them a few days prior to ask to be in building 2 based on reviews we had read here and sure enough, we were in a great room - 2118 - facing the pool with a great patio, about half way along from the main building to the beach. Thanks Rafael!The food was great - of course, this is an all inclusive in a developing country so to expect the same kind of food as we would in a North American or European resort would be naive (although it is clear that many still do). If this is your expectation, then you best stay in NA. That being said, we found there was a huge variety at the main buffet, with some changes day to day, but there was always something to eat for even the picky 5 year old. We ate mostly at the main buffet but also went to the Japanese Teppanyaki (you need to make reservations there - be sure to do this as soon as you arrive), and the a la carte Steak place. Be sure to try the chateau b. it is pretty great given that beef is not the specialty in the DR. Drinks were plentiful and delicious - try the mojito at the main bar but do it early in the eve as they run out of fresh mint by late night. The resort was very clean - sometimes there were some cups and stuff left by poolside, but a friendly request gets them cleaned up. The beach is amazing! We are early risers so we always got a great spot whether we were at the beach or pool. The beach is spotless, with lots of umbrellas and the softest sand ever! If you want huge waves, take a walk around the bend to the next resort as this part of the beach is pretty calm. The staff is amazing - like any all inclusive in this part of the world the rule is to be nice and friendly, slide a dollar or two when you get great service and they will appreciate it. We got a stack of US ones and it was very helpful for tipping. I went to the casino almost every night and if you hunt around, you can get a great game of hold 'em going - they also have other poker games, blackjack and roulette. The dealers were great - professional and fun. We have been to DR once before at another resort and in the Mayan Riv and liked this best of all. We will certainly return!!

<Author>MrFantastic74
<Content>A great honeymoon My wife and I stayed at the Majestic between December 6th and 20th, 2007, and this was our honeymoon vacation. We had a wonderfully relaxing stay, despite the stormy weather for more than the first week of our stay. We managed to obtain a room upgrade due to being on honeymoon, which was nice, especially since the hotel was booked solid. We started off in a room overlooking the construction, but were moved to one that sort of had a view of the beach.I will break down this review into three sections: Negatives, Positives and Notes.Negatives:1. BEWARE OF THE PRO PHOTOGRAPHY SESSIONS! Since it was our honeymoon, a special event in our lives, my wife and I decided to get some professional shots done via the photography studio's photo session. When we were first approached by one of the photogs about the session package, we were concerned about the price. The photog explained that it was $8 USD per digital pic and $10 USD per printed pic, and that we could choose as many or little as we liked, but with a minimum of 10-15 shots. This was acceptible to us, as we were willing to spend between $150 and $300 for pictures in total. She also said the photo session was about an hour long, and that it was of no extra charge for service. On the day of our shoot, our photographer ended up being Alejndro (Alex), who was a nice guy who gave us a great time during the shoot. He worked with us for almost 2 hours and took almost 200 shots. When it came time to choosing our pictures in the studio later that night, however, we ran into some difficulties. Alex tried to sell us the whole packge with all pictures and a variety of prints for almost $1300 USD. I tried to explain that we only wanted digital images, and only some of the shots, but he insisted we listen to him while he ran down a list of different packages and prices. When it became clear to him that we were only going to purchase a select bunch of the digital images, he became less and less service oriented, and basically rolled his eyes at us when we were eliminating pictures from the selections. He almost made us feel guilty for not buying all of his precious works of art. We finally settled on 43 digital images for $344. He told us it was cash only... How could he expect anyone to have been carrying $1300 cash?! We didn't have enough cash to pay for this package, so we had no choice but to use the ATM. The ATM only gave Dominican pesos. Having been told by multiple vendors that the exchange rate is 32 pesos to the dollar, we took out the appropriate amount from the ATM. When we returned to the photography studio with our payment, they told us the exchange was 35 pesos to the dollar (if we wanted to pay in pesos)!... So we ended up having to take out even more money, even though I was obviously upset over this fact. By this point in time, we were no longer receiving service with a smile, and no thank yous were exchanged. Poor poor customer service skills. If you decide to have one of these sessions done, be sure to explain to your photog in advance that you only wish to purchase x amount of pictures; it may save you some trouble.2. Our on site travel agent, Felix, who works for Sunquest, was not at the least bit customer service oriented. We had cancelled an excursion due to the bad weather we had had every day of our trip up to that point. We had already rescheduled the trip prior to this, and were told by Felix that the weather would get better within the next couple of days. Five days later, the weather had not improved, and that's when we approached Felix again to cancel the excursion scheduled for the next day. We didn't want to be stuck on a boat in choppy waters in the rain with poor visibility for snorkelling. He was visibly disappointed by that, but we thought nothing more of it. As it turns out, the day of our would-be excursion had fair weather, but there was no way for us to have known. You have to cancel more than 24 hrs in advance, so we made the best decision based on the weather we had been experiencing. A few days later Felix approached us as we were minding our own business and stated that he wanted to make a complaint about us. He scolded us for not believing him that the weather would get better, and said that he's been doing his job for 5 years and knows the country very well. Then he left before we could say anything. Needless to say, we were shocked by the conversation, especially as it became apparent that he was merely disappointed over losing his commission for the sale. My wife's been in customer service for years and was shocked over his behavior. It was the first time she's seen a professional make a complaint about a customer.3. The games area, where they have foosball, ping pong, darts and billiards, is a little dillapedated and not well maintained. The equipment is either broken, dirty or missing vital parts. For those times of boredom between dinner and the evening shows, on nights when you want to do something other than drink at the bar, it would be nice to play games in that area. Oh well.4. Smoking is permitted EVERYWHERE, which is a problem for people like us who feel sick around cigarette smoke. Some of the inside or covered areas, including the theatre where the shows are put on, can get pretty smoky. Many people, usually of the non-English or non-Spanish speaking variety, just light up in the seat right next to you without asking... the same people who cut in front of you in the buffet lines, but that's another story... I saw a couple people smoking while strutting around in the pool. That was gross.Positives:1. The staff was excellent and helpful. They catered to all of our requests within reason, and only fell short when the language barrier got in the way. For instance, we ordered hot chocolate during the stormest and coldest of days, and received cold chocolate milk, even when attempting to order in Spanish... Doesn't caliente mean hot? :) No worries. We tipped the waiter for the hassle, as he was very friendly. 2. The pool, as everyone says, was amazing. It is so big that you are never lacking for a good spot. There are even areas where you can place your chair in shallow water areas while sunbathing. I only wish it had a deep section for diving. It was hip-deep water all the way around.3. The beach was beautiful, and we never had trouble finding a good seat there either. The water is aquagreen and crystal clear in parts. The waves were rough during the stormy period, but died down when the winds receded.4. The drinks are good. We reccommend the Majestic. We don't know what's in it, but it's delicious.5. The steak restaurant by the beach has great Chateaubriand. The pasta stations at the buffets are also very good.6. The entertainment (animacion) staff was great, and the activities they organized were fun. I recommend you get off your tush and participate. You just may win a nice bottle of rum, as I did! Say hi to Jimmy Sexy Black Banana Anaconda for me. I also recommend you learn the taki taki resort dance, and do it on stage after the nightly shows, or by the pool or at the beach in the morning/afternoon!7. The shows were good for the most part. Very similar to the ones we saw at the RIU Playacar in Playa Del Carmen Mexico. The Micheal Jackson show was probably the best one, but even the in-house animacion shows were entertaining. I do have one complaint against many of my fellow spectators, though. Clap! Give the performers applause for their efforts; it's only common courtesy. I find it very rude when people just sit there and do not give the slightest bit of polite applause, and there were quite a large number of spectators that fit that bill. Are you expecting the Cirque du Soleil? The real Micheal Jackson? Give me a break, people. Show some respect.Notes:Malaria.THERE IS MALARIA IN THE PUNTA CANA AREA. My wife and I did not take anti-malarial pills, but we took other precautions that we recommend you take as well. Since malaria mosquitos attack from dusk to dawn, we applied a 28% DEET insect repellent lotion (that didn't smell too bad at all) on all of our exposed skin at night. We would adjurn to our room at about 5PM, take a shower, etc., then apply the insect repellent before going back out. We also brought a $40 mosquito net with us that we slept under at night time, as we did see a few mosquitos in our room at night time. There is also dengue fever in the Dominican Republic, which is acquired via day-flying mosquitos, but the risk of acquiring this illness is much smaller. Just make sure to apply insect repellent when venturing out into rural areas.Tipping. We decided to tip at the bar or restaurants when we received friendly service with a smile, or service with that little extra something. It seemed to work out well for us. At no time were we displeased with the service or the drinks being served. We left $2 USD per night for the housekeeping. We never received any towels sculptures or fancy frills, but we did recieve lots of extra towels and coffee when we asked for it. Candies/ toys for the kids.We brought a bunch of toys and candies from a dollar store to the DR with us, with the anticipation of giving them out to children outside the resort. It worked out well for us; Dominican children are very receptive to this, as are their parents. We also thought we could use the items as bargaining chips with street vendors (we had heard of other people being successful with this), but we didn't really get the opportunity to try it out. We left what was left over for the housekeeper on our last day.Turista.Although my wife and I both took great precautions about not consuming tap water (we brushed our teeth with bottled water and never let any water enter our mouths when showering), and although we took the oral vaccine to prevent it, we still got a bout of Majestic revenge. This may be a result of churn-up due to the hurricane.Rooms.Yes, the lack of privacy when using the toilet is slightly annoying. My wife and I took turns waiting on the balcony while the other was using it. It's not too bad, though. The rest of the room is very nice.Food.Although we liked the steak and pasta, most of the food was simply ok. A 6 out of 10. Don't expect anything fabulous.

<Author>ShanaRaven
<Content>Very Relaxing! We booked our trip from CheapCaribbean.com. Overall, we felt received an excellent deal and were very pleased with the service they gave. However, they were unable to give us the rebates promised because I changed my credit card number after booking.When you collect your baggage at the very large hut they consider an airport, you will then be thrown into a pit of valets that want to take your bags and escort you to your transfer agency. Don't try to avoid them, its impossible, and you need them to get to your van, as you would never be able to find it. The drive was wild. There don't seem to be any driving rules in the Dominican at all, so I felt like I was putting my life into this maniac drivers hands. Apparently, you have to drive like that though or you will never get anywhere. There were motorcyles and scooters everywhere, some with three people on them, and it doesn't seem anyone wears helmuts. Despite all that, I never saw an accident while I was there.The country itself isn't much to see. Very, very poor. Most of the houses we saw were shacks with aluminum roofs. This is why many people feel it best to stay at their resorts.When we arrived at the hotel, we were given a cold towel (but no drink!) before check in. They were able to upgrade us to a poolside room. I was very disappointed when we got to the room. First of all, it had double beds and we requested a king/queen. It was also over run by flies and smelled terribly musty. The room was near the stairs and very loud with people coming and going. I called the front desk but was unable to get another room and they told me to call back the next day.We were able to get another room the next afternoon, less smelly, but this one had a mosquito problem. I was bitten at least twice a day, but my boyfriend escaped harm.The bathroom is a very weird set up if you are a new couple or traveling with friends. The tiny toilet stall leaves nothing to the imagination for other guests. The shower was very nice, but they only give you two towels, and if room service doesn't clean your room at the right time, you have to use the same set again. The tub only fits one person comfortably.Room service did a good job cleaning, but was very inconsistent with the timing. Also, I was expecting towel animals or fancy designs with the curtains or bedding. We didn't get that at all.The pool was beautiful, as was the beach. We never had a problem getting a chair at either place. the pool water was very cold. The ocean was gorgeous but a little rough. Also, the towel hut was extremely well stocked and we never had a problem getting new towels throughout the day. The man that worked there all day, every day was extremely pleasant.I thought the food was good in most cases if you stuck with the safe choices. Breakfast had lots of options. The omelet station was always popular but worth the wait. Lunch at either lunch buffet always had enough choices, and there was a good amount of variety from day to day.For the two restaurants that require reservations for dinner, make them the first day you arrive. Le Gourmet is well worth it and we ended up eating there twice. We never waited for a table at any of the other restuarants. I was very disappointed in the chateaubriand after reading all the reviews. It didn't impress me at all, and I love steak. Drinks were good, but its hard to find other options when you get sick of the sweet stuff. Sometimes it amused me when you ordered something because it seemed like each bartender made up something new for each drink. For instance, a mudslide at one point consisted of milk, chocolate sauce and vodka. The mamajuana shots were great fun. And don't let them tell you that it is just for men! The main bar on the bottom floor of the lobby area seemed to have the most options.We worked with Andreas from Turinter Tours and he was very helpful. We booked two excursions - the Kontiki Fun Cruise and the Buggies. Both buses to each excursion was an excursion of its own. In addition to the crazy driving, the all felt like they were going to fall apart. The excursions are not as well put together on other more established island. When we arrived at the beach for Kontiki, we had to get on a small motor boat to be transported to the larger boat. It turned out to be a great time. They made sure you had a drink in your hand at all times. Snorkeling was great! So beautiful! After that, they had sandwiches ready for you. Then they entertained you with dancing and some skits.The Dune buggies were also a lot of fun, but we had to drive through such a poor area, with children waving at you in front of their shacks and some trying to sell you things. They made a stop at a natural cave, but I think it was just an excuse to have you stop at people's tables where they try to sell you jewelry and paintings. Every store and place you go has the exact same stuff. Don't let them sell it to you for an expensive price, as most of it is cheap and will fall apart. We stopped again at a beach for more salesmanship. I was also uncomfortable that we didn't get helmuts for this. If you do it - prepare to get very dirty!The animation team was fun, but after a few days, it was just the same stuff over and over again. Plus, they only stayed at one area of the pool and never moved around. We learned not to sit near there when we weren't going to participate because it was distracting and annoying.We never saw any water activities available like snorkeling, kayaks, sailboats, etc, that were promised when we were booking. We thought it might have been because it was too rough.The photo store did offer private photo sessions. We saw what they did with several people. Really beautiful work. I'm upset that we didn't do this.Turinter got us back to the airport with plenty of time to spare. One note - if you are going to buy the Mamajuana, you need to get it pre-made or fill the bottle with rum after washing it out. They won't let you travel with just the bark, twigs, etc, as it is considered vegetation.Overall, we had a great time. This was only my second time at an all-inclusive. Overall, my experience at an Iberostar in the Mexico was much better, but this trip was extremely relaxing and we had a great time.

<Author>World_Travellers04
<Content>One of the best hotels in Punta Cana We have just come back from a week at the Majestic Colonial from 10-17 Dec. We had read every single review on TripAdvisor which we found useful. I hope others find ours just as useful.Despite having landed in Punta Cana when Tropical Storm Olga made it's landfall, the Majestic Colonial made it all worthwhile. This was our 6th trip to the Dom Rep and our 4th to Punta Cana. Our first and hopefully not our last to this hotel.It did help that we had exchanged several e-mails with the Reservations Dept. (Rafael Ferreira: holiday-saviour) and hence upon our arrival, we basically got what we had asked for (room in preferred block, king-size bed). NOTE: the Majestic Elegance (a new hotel) is currently under construction next to the Colonial and if you are planning a trip to this hotel, request a room in either Block 2 or 3. Block 1 overlooks the entrance of the Grand Paradise Hotel (next door-lots of cars, buses, etc), while Block 4 overlooks the construction site of the Elegance. For some, the construction site could be a problem.Having said that, everything else is certainly worth it. The rooms are great and very big (and we had the standard Junior Suite-did use the whirlpool regularly for a relaxing time). We did not see one person using the outside Jacuzzi provided in the superior suites so it might not be worth the extra expense. These rooms are also swim-up but we go to the Dom Rep for the sea and sand, definitely not the pool (even though it really is an impressive one!).The grounds are extremely well cured and special attention is paid to small details. As mentioned to the staff, it would be great if people did not use the balcony railings in their rooms as clothes lines as it ruins the view of the entire place....especially for all the lovely weddings we saw during our stay (and there really were many!). A possible solution could be for an extendable line to be drawn up in the shower stall, which is triple the usual size.The food was excellent: we tried Buffet for breakfast and lunch, Matsuri-Oriental (as well as the special presentation that you need to book for), the lunch buffet at the beach (Hispaniola), the Rodeo Grill and the Fish place (Las Tres Carabelas) and the French restaurant (Le Gourmet) that requires reservation. They were all really good. 6 Nights did unfortunately not allow us to try the Taino (Caribbean).I think it is important for people to realise that when travelling abroad, it is important to look for the best the place has to offer and not look for exactly what you would have (or even expect) back home. Hence, the pasta is not Italian, the lobster is not the same as in Boston, the sushi is made in Punta Cana and not some sushi bar in New York. Having said this, we tried everything and it really was all very fresh, well-presented (yes, do try the Chateaubriand at the grill, the lobster at the seafood restaurant) they are fantastic!!Did get a wrap at the Spa and the treatment, as well as their prices, were OK (Europeans being favoured with the exchange rate).Small suggestions for improvements, besides the clothes on the balconies: some of the staff could improve their attitude towards guests (I don't appreciate the feeling of being completely pampered to but the opposite also has an effect-no-one likes to be completely ignored-I sincerely hope that this does not have to do with the different coloured wrist bands which I was told by management staff, is linked to geographic origin of guests), but rather to some members of staff who do not make the effort to catch your eye or even smile).Having said that, the vast majority is however very friendly, efficient, professional and eager to please; guests should, for hygenic reason, be required to cover-up at the restaurants: we did see many guests literally dripping sea/pool water when serving themselves at the buffet (by the beach) or using their fingers to serve themselves. This is revolting and controls should be improved or put into place; it would be nice to have a drinks/cocktail menu for those guests like myself who have no idea of what certain cocktails contain but would like to know/try out. Some of the waiters did not know themselves (!) and I even had a couple of drinks that contained various different ingredients!These are all small (some of them) things that could help improve the (already very good) service of this hotel.I hope that my review will help many TripAdvisor fans like myself to decide, but remember what's good for someone might not be the best for the next. There's nothing like trying it out for yourself.

<Author>JJax987
<Content>Wonderful Experience Booked this for a 10 day honeymoon and couldn't have been more pleased with the experience. Some highlights:- The staff was absolutely amazing. They work ridiculously long days there and manage to smile and be cheerful til their 12th hour on the job. Make sure to tip staff - they make next to no money at all. They are always willing to talk and make it a point to ask them how they are doing - in the DR, small talk is polite, even if you are just asking them for a towel or drink. - Food was good. It was varied enough that I didn't get sick of it, even after ten days. Big thumbs up to Le Gourmet and the Japanese Restaurant. Book AS SOON AS YOU CHECK IN. Reservations go quickly and they are both totally worth it. Went back to both for a 2nd time.- Wear a Red Sox Shirt or hat - the locals love Big Papi and will treat you like a king/queen and offer to buy the clothes off your back!- The Circus and Michael Jackson shows were awesome. I highly recommend spending an hour there.-The rooms were great - had a Colonial Jr Suite with a hottub outside and view of the ocean. Couldn't have been better. -Denny was great as a beach concierge, very helpful. Freddy in the Buffet and Mexican Restaurant was a sweety. And there were several spectacular bartenders - mostly at the Piano bar, Lobby bar, and the bar in the entertainment area during shows. -As a gay traveller, it was difficult, mainly because what's accepted here in the States isn't really something the locals run into on a day-to-day basis. Kept getting asked where my husband/boyfriend was and getting hit on. We switched to being in the closet after having discussions and explaining to several staffers what the deal was - we just got sick of the long conversations and questions and wanted to enjoy vacation. Not their fault, but something to consider. Lots of gay couples there though!-Beach was nice, warm and wavy - if you are looking for a lagoon, this isn't the place. It was fun! Spouse found 40 bucks in the ocean one day! Sometimes schools of fish would surround swimmers - really cool.-Can't say much about activities - I was happy doing nothing!-Some tips: bring sunscreen and BUGSPRAY. The bugs aren't really pesty down there and they aren't very big. I found myself not even being able to spot some of them, but ending up with lots of little bites (the mosquitos are much smaller in the DR!). Bugspray stopped that!-Make sure to get yourself a shot of Mamajauna mixed fresh at the bar and a Mr. Majestic with Rum! Enjoy El Presidente!I highly recommend this hotel - I cannot wait to go back and am figuring out who to bring!

<Author>Pazuzu999
<Content>Great vacation overall!! Overall, the Majestic was the best A.I. resort i've stayed in. I've been to 4 and 5 star resorts in Cuba and Puerto Plata, and was my first time to PC. This is pretty lengthy so read on, and feel free to email me at irishguy876@hotmail.com if you'd like to ask me more questions. Rooms - My gf and I stayed with 2 other couples from Toronto (we're mid 30's) and ahead of time i requested building 2, second floor. George in PR (who replaced Emily) kindly accommodated me and we had excellent rooms, ours in 2205 and the others just down the hall. I recommend this part of the resort, and don't think the swim up poolside rooms would be worth the extra cash. They have jacuzzi tubs outside the room but there's obviously no privacy. We used our jacuzzi tub in our room nearly every night (after a tough day at the beach/pool!) and it was nice to have a little quiet private time in a jacuzzi bath that we could both comfortably fit in.The rooms overall were very nice, and we loved the shower! Didn't care the bathroom door was a frosted glass window.The pillows were pretty flat and the bed a bit hard but no biggie; the kingsize bed was great. Staff seemed to makeup rooms later in the day, but i guess that depends on where your room is. No problem, except for one day where i wanted to get some sleep during the day (more on that below). The resort policy seems to be that they'll only provide 2 beers per day but again, no biggie since you're at an A.I resort and there's no shortage of booze at the bars. And, if you don't use your beers up one day, hide them in your suitcase and the maid will give you two more..then put the other 2 back in the fridge and you have 4 for when you want 'em.The in room safe was great..good to see the resort not charging for this as some I've stayed at charge 20bucks for the week.We had the grey wristbands, and i wasn't sure what the difference was between these and others (pls comment or email me if you do?) but on arrival, we had fruit and champagne in the room, and on nights 2 and 3 we got bottle of wine and sushi/ fruit delivered around 5pm. After that, no more deliveries though! :(The robes and slippers were a nice touch, but one day we left the robes to be replaced and we never got new ones, but no big deal overall.Grounds - Incredibly beautiful. Immaculate. Constant attention all around the resort. In the case of any unthoughtful guests who left cups or garbage (which i simply don't understand), trash was picked up almost immediately by any/all staff constantly making rounds. Service /bars - Above average. We tipped fairly well, and each person in our group probably tipped 50 bucks each throughout the week. I just don't get people who don't tip at all - don't care if it's not custom to do so in Europe..the Majestic isn't in Europe and the staff make little wages. I found them very friendly, helpful and courteous. I also don't understand why some guests (seems to be older European folks to be honest) treat some of these people like servants. I heard many ordering drinks without saying please and thank you,etc. Can't hurt to say hola, por favor, gracias. I didn't have any problems with non English speaking staff for the most part..one night i wanted to order a Sherry but they weren't aware of the term, but the lobby bartender found me a suitable alternate (premium drink, but we didn't have to pay for it). Would be nice to have a menu of drinks to try some variations in drinks, but in some cases the various brands were displayed, including premium brands such as Stoli Vodka which I drank most of the week. In some cases the mix for drinks was flat however. Presidente beer on tap was always cold, crisp and fresh. It seems to be primarily a Canadian phenomenom but our group brought thermos containers or smaller bubba kegs - this is a must. Otherwise you'll get small glass cups where drinks get warm very quickly in the tropical sun. Bevvies stay cold and it's good for the environment. Just don't overdo it with the giant bubba kegs the size of your head. A little crass! The market shop sell the thermos thingy's at a ridiculous price so pick one up at home for 8bucks. Pool - Excellent - by far the best i've ever experienced. The layout means that it forces people to spread out, so there's not a billion people around a circular pool. I walked to the nearby bahia principe and it seemed quite congested around the pool. And, as long as you got to the pool by about 9am you could get a chair somewhere. We're not fans of excessive noise on our vay-k so we stayed clear of the main bar where the animation team was constantly getting things going. Just not our thing, and we found their yelling into the mic in between soundbytes of techno pretty annoying. There were a few staff serving drinks at your chairs around the pool tool, which was nice. You didn't have to tip, but you can guarantee that if you didn't the number of repeat visits by the staff member would decline, which I agree with. Throw the guy a buck every 2nd round - it won't kill your budget. Beach - beautiful sand, great warm water and yes, it's blue. Maybe not photoshop blue..but blue. BRING WATER SHOES. It makes your life easier. There are a few rocks under the water to step on so just save yourself a few ouchies. And don't expect a completely serene, calm bed of water folks. For us, the wavier the better - makes it fun to play around in the water. Otherwise it's just like being in a bath. Best waves seemed to be in the morning and at sunset. Was pretty windy at the beach on a couple of days, but the breeze was nice.Weather - i think the week before us it rained or was overcast most of the week, so i guess we were lucky. It was beautiful every day - on our last day it rained for about 10 minutes and that was it. But were were determined that even if the weather didn't cooperate we'd still make an effort to have fun. In fact, we swam in the rain in the pool..awesome.Excursions - we only took one, the Speedboat/snorkelling trip and it was excellent. $70 per person for 2people in a boat, or $100 per person for your own boat. Very well organized and efficient. Only ate up a half day too. Would have been nice to see a few more exotic fish in the snorkelling portion but no biggie whatsoever.Shows - umm..cheesy. As mentioned before, the animation team/nightly shows aren't our cups of tea. Our group tended to create our own party. I think this is a generational thing perhaps. Older folks may enjoy that sort of thing but we all just sort of laughed at the shows. However, if you like that kind of entertainment..then you will like the shows. Disco/Casino - Again, we created our own fun at these places. I don't gamble and it's basically a one room casino but it gave us something to do when we were revving up our evenings. Shops - don't bother as everything's overpriced, but then again, if you need something..you need something. Public bathrooms - other than an odd earthy smell (perhaps it's the resort's cleaning agent?) the bathrooms were immaculate and always beaning cleaned it seemed. And guys, at some point you'll likely go into a bathroom and need the urinal - if there's a woman in there cleaning/mopping, just proceed with your business. She's not gonna leave and she'll just ignore you so no big deal. Restaurants - Buffet was pretty good overall, and i especially liked the freshly made to order pasta. The pizza was delish too. Service to your tables in the buffet was outstanding. Constant attention to your drinks was the norm. The chinese a la carte was very good, but we decided to forego the Japanese cuz we ended up getting an early 630pm reservation (the only one available when we checked in 5 days earlier..so book a la cartes asap). The Gourmet was quite good too. Steakhouse was mediocre. I loved the Mexican/Caribbean but it could've used some tasty hot sauces! Good that they had some authentic Domincan dishes too. A nice touch. Another nice touch was a mini appetizer/drink stand just outside the main lobby bar every night. If you have food allergies be cautious because the person serving is doing just that and not an expert on all ingredients in the items being served. It was nice to have though because you could have a little appetizer and blue lagoon/punch before dinner. And oh, the late night snack bar is really quite awful so just avoid it if you can. Health issues - On day 5 i got under the weather...by my own doing. It seems i had a bit of sunstroke so i woke up nauseaus and threw up a couple of times, and the next day and a half i had absolutely no appetite. A couple of folks in our group had some minor stomache issues - but hey - it's a different country, different foods and your world has changed instantly with a lot more drinking than you're used to, along with a dramatic change in climate and activities, so it's bound to happen. Since i was up most of one night not feeling well, i was exhausted the next day and it seemed that my room wasn't going to get made up for a while so i had to try and find a quiet corner in the lobby to crash for a while on a couch. Departure day - this may not be a factor depending on when you leave, but we had our check out extended to 1:30 (instead of 12) since the bus wasn't picking us up until 630pm. For $40 you may be able to get a 6pm checkout but it was unavailable when we were leaving cuz the resort was getting filled up. No biggie though. You just stick your luggage in a waiting room (no charge) and take a shower and change in a shower/change room off the lobby. Very helpful. Airport /Transfers - they didn't have our names on the list when we were about to board our bus at the airport to take us to the resort..but we got on anyway. This delayed things by about 20 minutes as they had to arrange a private taxi for 6 others. When i got to the resort i told my Sunwing rep so it wouldn't happen on the way back..He assured me it would be no problem, but sure enough it happened again and there was another delay. It might've been an anomaly and local mixup, but they should get this straightened out really because although it's minor and they made arrangments, people just want to get to their resorts on the way in, and get out of Dodge on the way out.We found that the PC airport when we were leaving was absolute chaos. tough to get a place to sit down really, but whatever..it's still a 3rd world country and developing this type of infrastructure. So sad to see a Wendy's at the airport too. Duty free had decent prices on stuff too. And best of all, while waiting for our plane, the airport had free WIFI (or just unsecure wireless internet!) and we listened to the Leaf /Bruins game online.. a nice segue back to Canada!Oh one other thing. I know there are people visiting from all over the world, and people are proud of where they're from, but in my opinion, people should avoid blatantly wearing clothing that shouts out their country's name. The number one offender, IMHO, was Canadians (and I too am a very proud Canadian). You're on vacation AWAY from your country, so why jam where you're from down the throat of the locals and every other guest? If Americans were wearing USA shirts, it would get more heat wouldn't it? But us Canucks seem to get away with it, which i don't think is right! :) If it comes up in conversation with locals or other guests, that's fine, but lose the Canada/ Raptors/Leafs/Oilers/Roots Canada shirts..all of which i saw last week. Just my opinion..if you don't agree, that's fine too.So that's it..i think. Feel free to drop a line or question!Ryan
