<Author>nyhenry
<Content>Great Family Reunion We traveled to the Majestic from July 29th-August 3rd with 18 family members. We booked through Diane (Group Sales) at cheapcaribbean. (All went well!) The ages of our family ranged from 12-81. We had a nonstop flight from JFK which worked out great for our 4 families. The Punta Cana Airport was interesting. Even though we were aware of the $10 tourist fee, it still was confusing and a little unorganized. Also, on our Delta flight we were given a white Immigration form to fill out, however, the Dominicans wanted us to fill out a similar one in blue. The transportation to and from the hotel with Tourinter Tours, pre-arranged by cheapcaribbean.com, went well. It was a large air-conditioned coach. The ride was nice and took about 30 minutes. The guide tried to get us to meet with a rep the next day to schedule day tours. It seemed like he was trying to get us to think we had to meet with the rep to schedule our return ride. We didn't go. Instead, we went to the rep in the lobby of the hotel the night before we left and confirmed our ride back to the airport. Part of the departure terminal is air conditioned.The Majestic is beautiful!! It is uniquely designed and architecturally very interesting. The pool, the beach, and all our rooms (8) exceeded our expectations. Yes, there was a slight odor in the rooms, but as other reviewers have mentioned, it's probably the humidity and the proximity to the ocean. We didn't mind at all The weather was sunny and in the 90s everyday. We spent most of our 5 days on the beach (the best in the country!) and in the pool (the largest in the Caribbean). Every area of the incredible pool has its own personality. Numerous bars make getting a drink very easy. We saw the animation team in one area of the pool and one area of the beach. You can choose to be in a quiet area (left side of the beach)or a rowdy area. Our family used the kayaks, sailboats and went para-sailing. Two played golf and eleven went on the snorkeling excursion. FYI-the boat ride to the open ocean snorkeling is pretty wild. One of our favorite day and night locations was the open air beach bar and restaurant. For lunch, this large facility has two buffet areas serving salads, freshly made pastas, lunch items and desserts. We called the hamburgers mystery meat because one of our group members was a meat-cutter, and he wasn't sure what cut/kind of meat made up the hamburgers. They were really good though and many of us ate them. The open air buffet and airy atmosphere was perfect for our diverse family. At night it becomes two restaurants; Seafood on one side (we found the seafood to be overcooked, and the lobster fell short of our expectations) and Steak (other reviewers were right on the money about the chateaubriand; it was excellent!! The chicken was great too.) And with its ocean breezes, great bar, and romantic views, it made for great memories. We also dined at the French Restaurant (soups and appetizers were good, desserts were awesome, dinners were ok [surf and turf consisted of a piece of lobster the size of a quarter, the lobster hamburger was great] service was the best.) Japanese Restaurant (some family members liked it, others did not) and the Grand Buffet (always excellent). Everyone seemed to find something they liked wherever we went. We didn't eat at the dominican/mexican restaurant. We walked in, saw the goat soup, boar's head and other unfamiliar foods and walked out. Breakfast for us was always at the Grand Buffet and one of our favorite meals. Fresh fruits and fruit milkshakes, waffles, crullers, pancakes, French toast and omelets all made in front of you. Outside of the lobby there is a bar and large patio. In the morning, they have coffee, juice and fresh croissants. Great for early risers. The entire staff was very hard working and always wanted to please. We tipped at every opportunity. (On the bus ride in, you'll understand where these wonderful people really come from.) Yes, there definitely was a language barrier, but we all worked through it. At times it was funny. My sister wanted a little whipped cream on top of my mom's strawberry daiquiri, but instead, he put milk in it. Then, because they always try to remember your drinks, every time my sister ordered a drink from this one bartender, he put milk in it. We all smiled with him, as he thought this is what my sister wanted. We brought insulated cups and had the bartenders fill them with our favorite drinks (pina colada with extra rum and ice).The evening entertainment was mostly in Spanish, but still entertaining. They have some very entertaining, talented people performing. The lobby bar and piano bar areas are not air-conditioned, but they are so open and beautiful, we didn't mind. Several used the gym and enjoyed their time there. Many went to the casino. Be watchful of the casino employees raking your bets when it should have been a push. They will take the chips and cards quickly, sometimes before you have had a chance to check them. Also, check your chips before cashing in. But having said that, those that went had a blast and several of our party walked away a few hundred dollars richer. Two members of our family had some stomach problems for a few days, but overall we remained healthy. In closing, we all had wonderful time with the very friendly Dominican people at this incredible resort!

I usually have a phobia of going in the sea without some form of foot wear but it was lovely and I was happy to walk into the sea without shoes.What was great about both the pool and the beach was the fact that there were plenty of sunloungers available whenever you went to either - no need to take your towel down at 3am to 'bag' your sunlounger as happens in Europe!The staff:They could not have been more helpful. Our glasses were always filled up. As I have already mentioned the staff in the mexican restaurant were particularly good.The weather:I guess I should mention the weather although it has little to do with the hotel. I was concerned that being the rainy season it may be a disaster. It wasn't. The weather was fantastic. A few showers in the evenings which lasted about the duration of my actual shower so they did not matter.Arrival and Departure:Arriving at the hotel was so simple - no queues to negotiate. We were provided with cool face towels and welcome drinks which were very welcome after an 8 hour flight! It was stress free.Leaving the hotel was as stress free. The staff were very helpful.In all I am pleased I picked the Majestic... it was even better for the fact that the were so few English... I really felt like a foreigner and that can only be a good thing!Finally.... would I recommend the hotel.... yes I would!

<Content>A pleasant experience Vacationing with two kids that was our first time in Dominican and Majestic did not disappoint. Great beach, extraordinary pool, friendly staff and good looking/spacious rooms made this vacation memorable and enjoyable. Another important asset of the hotel are roof covered walkways - you won't likely to get wet if you happen to be outside during the rain storm. There're a few areas of improvement needed though to make it a family friendly five star resort as they claim it to be.1 Food is not up to the expectation. <Author>SlyGuy
<Content>Honeymoon at Majestic Hi everyone.We just returned from the Majestic where we spent our Honeymoon from 28 Jul to 4 Aug 07.I'll address everything by sections to keep this short and sweet.Airport: Wow: short and sweet, 30 mins to the hotel. 10$ tourist card was included in our package (flew with Sunwing). You do need the 20$ departure fee when checking in on departure.Check-in: Amazing service on arrival. We had a VIP/Honeymoon package so they assigned someone from the Guest Service desk to assist us for the check-in. Took us aside and made all our a la carte reservations right away including a special honeymoon romantic dinner at the seafood restaurant.Room: we ended up in 2217 (block 2, 2nd floor, room 17) which faces the pool in front of the towel hut and pool bar. Great location as it's not too close from the swim up bar where the activities take place but close to everything including lobby and restaurants but only a short walk to the beach. Room itself was beautiful with Jaccuzi. As per our VIP/Honeymoon package, we received a bottle of white wine and some finger food at the room the first 2 nights (around 5pm), a fuit basket and champagne on arrival and a breakfast in bed on Tues morning. Amazing.Restaurants: This is where the resort lacks a little bit in quality. The buffet is pretty varied and offers some very good items. The a la carte are somewhat comparable to all other resorts we've visited. The Japanese is pretty good but is also pretty typical with 8 folks sitting around the cooking table where the chef prepares the food and then serves everything at once on a plate. The steakhouse is pretty good also other than they cook everything early and re-heat the food as necessary (this is why your steak arrives in about 10 mins...). Don't go there at 10pm as you will get the leftovers (we did that one night and the brochetes were overcooked and hard). Our romantic dinner was at the seafood and we were assigned our own server with a nice table at the edge of the pool. We didnt' get to pick the food but ended up with some gamba and small beef filets which were OK. Carribean/Mexican wasn't great but offered variety. Again, overall, lots of choice but I wouldn't compare the food to a Sandals as far as quality. But the important thing here is we didn't get sick and didn't loose any weight... LOL!Beach/pool: amazing. Always room under Palapas and plenty of chairs regardless of time of day. We did the beach in the morning and pool in the afternoon and never a problem. Pretty windy on the beach the last couple of days so sand everywhere so we stuck to the pool more. Never a problem exchanging towels either (we did 2 or 3 times a day).Activities: typical stuff going on at the beach but mostly near the swim up bar. This is where everyone would go for a drink and watch around 4pm everyday. Shows: again typical. We watched 3 nights. The best was the Michael Jackson. Other nights were the typical guys against girls, Mister Majestic etc... Sad thing is that the shows don't start until 10pm, very late....Disco: we managed to stay up one night and made it to the club where everyone ends up right after the show is over (around 11pm). Only carribean music but a good crowd on hand when we went.Gym: not bad for a resort gym. There is AC but the door is always being opened by some curious folks so it does get warm.There is an attendant there who looks after the eqpt/towels etc... He's constantly near you as you're working out so it can be a bit annoying. Lot's of bikes/treadmill and some free weights and nautilus eqpt so you can have a decent workout.Service: well, I'm going to choose my words carefully (as my wife said... so not to offend anyone here). I'm only indicating this as to offer advice for those who are seeking a resort with a specific clientele and staff. First off there is an issue with english speaking staff. Most don't understand english at all although the Guest Service staff are incredible and fluent in english. However, most servers or shop attendant don't speak much english. Lucky for us we also speak french and some of those did too so we managed. The ladies at the mini-mart were extremely serious, never smiled and got offended when my wife was looking at T-shirts (unfolding them to see the logos...). Additionally, most of the customers are spanish speaking. Again, not trying to offend anyone here. I believe that this resort caters to those folks a bit more as the majority are spanish speaking. This is perfectly acceptable and might not be something the resort was looking for originally. It wasn't a big issue for us but if you are a french speaking person from Quebec city who doesn't speak english or spanish, you might wanna reconsider. For us, we managed well and still had a good time relaxing. Just didn't meet that many foks.Check out: very quick. Check out at 1200 hrs. On the bus within the hour. Airport check-in done in about 30 mins.Overall: We had a very good, relaxing honeymoon which was exactly what we wanted. However, I don't think we would go back to this resort. Again, the issue of staff and clientele was very surprising to us and different from other resorts we've visited where we've met many different people. Surprisingly, there were many, many kids at this resort which wasn't really indicated in the reviews. Although kids are allowed, we thought that this was mostly an adult type resort. Obviously, families are choosing this resort more and more which is very OK as it is very a nice place.The resort itself is beautiful, service in most cases is above average but some areas as indicated above could be improved.Hope this can help some of you in selecting your dream vacation.

<Author>kelli96
<Content>Great Trip...would bo back!! My group traveled July 28th-August 2nd and we had a great time! Please email me with any questions you have and I will be glad to help answer anything I can.Check In:Arriving was easy, we were greeted with Majestic drinks and warm towels. Check in was a breeze. We were given a room very close to the beach and the check in person, Manuel even made reservations for us at the 2 gourmet resturants at check in. Someone walked us to our room, gave us a brief tour of the facility and welcomed us to our room. Great service so far.Rooms:Very nice. Plenty of towels, pillows, stocked fridge. We never had a problem getting new towels, more drinks, a clean room, etc. Everything was perfect with the room. Yes the beds were a little hard but we had no problems sleeping. After a long day in the sun and drinks, you will sleep like a baby. The only small thing I can say that I didnt like about the room was that I couldnt ever get it cool enough. The temp wouldnt go below a certain degree and we slept with only a sheet at night otherwise we were always hot (sunburns could have had something to do with that). No musty smells, it was always always clean, etc. Toilet area was a little different but my husband and I didnt seem to mind with it just being the 2 of us.The beach:OK, this is what makes Punta Cana such a wonderful place. This was the best beach I have ever been to. The water is beautiful, the sand is awesome, the views are breathtaking. Enjoy the beach...you will love it. Always had loungers available and things to enjoy: snorkeling, kayaking, wind sailing, massages, tattooes, etc. There is a place where you can pay for water sports not included: parasailing, banana boats, scuba etc. The guy working this booth (which is not affiliated with the hotel) is soooo rude and service is sooo slow).The pool:Nothing is better than a HUGE pool where you can always find a place to hang out. Lots of room, lots of loungers, always got drinks quickly. I even had someone serve me drinks when I was on the loungers and not in the pool. The water is cool, refreshing and kept clean. The pool winding throughout the whole resort makes the entire resort all that much more special. The food:As good as other all inclusives I have stayed at if not better. The beachside resturant didnt have a very impressive lunch. The lobby restaurant is much better for lunch. Breakfast was OK....the waffles hard and scrambles eggs runny but that can be nitpicking. The dinners were always wonderful. No complaints about any of the dinners. The only thing I really hated was that breakfast is only served until 10 and lunch starts at 12. So if you miss breakfast and youre starving, you will only have a fruit and bread tray to eat from. This is the 1st time I have stayed at an AI and there wasnt more offered at the down times. Room servce would have come in handy here but that cost $$$. Overall the food was good...sometimes wonderful, sometimes OK. I have been to several nice AI resorts and I would say they food was as good, sometimes a little better yet others whom I talked to said that Majestic's food was the best they had ever had. So its all in comparison to what you have had.The drinks:We learned on the 4th day there that the downstairs lobby bar has premium liquor. If you ask for it they will serve it. The smaller bars around the pool do not have these liquors. The drinks were good for the most part. Keep in mind that this is not Mexico and they tequila drinks will not be the same as Mexicans would make it. They have their own specialty Dominican drinks that are great though. JUAN who works at this bar is GREAT. We are from Texas and every night he would yell Texas! and give us the Hook 'em Horns sign that we taught him as we walked into the lobby. Get to know him. He is at the bar every night.The casino/entertainment/disco:Casino was fun at night. This is the only place where I found the staff to be very stand off-ish and somewhat rude. The slots and video/machine games do not despense money. You actually have to call a teller over to collect the $5 you won. Everytime I felt like I was bothering them. They will try to jip you on your winnings so watch the amount of money given to you when you win.The shows at night were great. Very entertaining and you can tell that the animation team and staff work very hard and a lot of work goes into what they do. This is the first resort I stayed at where we actually went to the shows every night and looked forward to them. Danny the MC is great. It was kind of annoying that everything is performed in English and Spanish....sometimes we had a very hard time understanding what was going on. It was almost as if 80% of the audience was Spanish speaking so they were mainly being catered to. And sometimes it was hard understanding the english version...accents are thick. But were were in a Spanish speaking country so I couldnt expect everyone there to speak clear english. Most wait staff understood enough english to get us what we needed. They try very hard so that counts for something in my book.The disco had its fun night and its dead nights. Once again most of the music was spanish/latino music that we didnt understand or never heard of. Tyson who works at the bar in the disco is worth going to disco for. He is fun and entertaining. Great guy and great bartender. He works every night so get to know him.  As most readers have said, this is definetly a resort for couples and families. The night life is somewhat dull after the show but they have several things going on throughout the evening until the show starts. It would be really hard to get bored here.Excursions:Few and far between. This is not like mexico where there are 76 different excursions to choose from. They offered about 8-10 and only 3-4 looked appealing. We did the snorkeling trip withe the sharks/stingrays that I highly recomment that. Lots of fun. My husband and I are more beach/pool/relaxing vacationers so the lack of excursions wasnt a big deal to us.One last thing I would like to add is that the Dominican people are very very nice. It is a very happy, entertaining, friendly culture. Enjoy all it has to offer. The staff was soo nice to us. They work hard and we always tried to tip something to let them know that we appreciated the service they gave. They do a good job. In all this resort is a wonderful place to stay. We would go back to it in a heartbeat. The few things I have complained about are all small in the grand scheme of things.

<Author>LindsMich81
<Content>Memories That Will Last a Lifetime!! First with the negatives....After reading over 25 reviews before going on our honeymoon, I was a little surprised at the lack of English spoken in the Dominican. This was not something that I had ever read, but I believe this is really important to note. YES, I know, we are in their country, and need to experience their lifestyle, which is why I suggest going ONLY if you are fluent in Spanish, will learn some before you go, or you do not care if you can communicate or not. Yes, some people who work there speak English, but the majority of the activities are done in Spanish (at least in the pool area). My husband and I were both surprised by this, and we spoke to other couples who felt the same way. Even those who could speak English made us feel bad when we talked to them in English (we often got dirty looks, rolled eyes, etc) and YES, we did attempt to speak Spanish (we always greeted with Hola, and asked for drinks or food in the best Spanish we could). Now, on to the positive aspects of the Majestic Colonial.....our honeymoon was amazing! As far as the appearance is concerned, the Majestic is beautiful. When we walked in, it took my breath away! The pool goes on forever, and the beach was great! We never had a problem finding a seat at the beach or pool area, and there was always a bar open close by. We found that the drinks were a little watered down, but we aren't big drinkers, so this was not a problem for us. Make sure to get a drink called the Majestic---it is delicious! We found the bar in the lobby to serve them the best--but they are good anywhere! Also, many people mention the bathroom being open as a bad thing---what they are not mentioning is that that is only the case for the bathtub. There is a shower with a door, and the toilet has a door, so those are very private. The shower is huge---you could easily fit 2-3 people inside! We used the bathtub, but we were on our honeymoon, so it was wonderful for us, but there is not a need to use it if you are uncomfortable. The staff at the water activity hut is amazing! They were, by far, the nicest at the resort! They have staff available that can speak fluent English, German, French, and Spanish, so this was wonderful! Snorkeling was hard b/c you are only allowed to stay in a certain area, but we did see different kinds of fish. My husband loves kayaking, so he took out the kayaks a lot, and never had to wait to get one. We tried boogie boarding, but there was a lack of waves, so this did not work too well.We booked our trip through CheapCarribean.com and this worked out great! They had an agent named Noel at the Majestic and he was extremely helpful. He spoke English well, and set us up on 2 excursions that were great! My husband and I both recommend doing the ATV ride! It was amazing! We recommend getting your own ATV, and make sure to get a helmet with a visor--you will thank us for this later! haha! Bring your camera on the trip and wear your bathing suit, b/c you will be stopping at the beach for a few minutes! We also took the tour to Sanoa Island. We had a good time on this excursion, but we felt that a lot of the time was spent driving. We had to leave at 6:30 am and did not get back until 7:30 pm. It was a long day. The food at the Japanese restaurant was delicious. The food at Le Gourmet (the French restaurant) was great except for the appetizers (they made my husband EXTREMELY sick for 2 days). The Caribbean restaurant was okay. We ate at the main buffet the majority of the time, and found the food to be pretty good. There is a great variety--something for everyone! We never tried the shows (we were outside all day, so we were relaxing in our rooms usually by 10:00) The movies were cute though, and we heard good things about the shows. Overall, we had a great time. We found 7 days to be too long, but by the 6th day, my husband and I both had stomach problems, which was probably why 7 days seemed so long! Like I said earlier, the only thing that caught us off guard was the lack of English spoken, however, since we were on our honeymoon, we didn't need to talk to other people much....we just would have liked to participate in some of the pool activities, but they were in Spanish 80% of the time we were there. We LOVED having our room right by the pool, and found this to be an extremely relaxing trip, with lots of great pictures! I doubt we will go back anytime soon, but we will have our wonderful memories for years to come!

<Content>July 15-22 2007 We stayed at The Majestic from July 15-22. Overall we had a great time. The resort itself is beautiful and the pool is spectacular. The rooms are great with one exception...the toilet room. We had an ocean view room and the view was great. The food was okay, but you have to remember they are cooking for so many people/cultures. I found the steak house and buffet were the best. All the wait staff and house keeping staff were really sweet...no complaints in that area. However, the cashiers in the casino were very rude. The entertainment team were fabulous. We always sat at the section of the pool where they would come and play games. We did the water aerobics a few times and had alot of laughs. Our only real complaint would be the other tourist. I am not sure from what country they were from but they were very rude. They would jump in line at the buffet, push you out of they way or just run into you and act like it was your fault. I am a Southern American and we were always taught to mind our manners so this was very different for me. After a few days of it you just got used to it and expected it. We went on the 4 wheeler excursion and had a blast. If you are planning on taking that excursion (or the doon buggies) please make sure you bring clothes you have no problem throwing away and closed toe shoes. You will get filthy but it is so much fun! Also be warned the Punta Cana airport is not air conditioned so on your return flight home wear warm weather clothing. We were soaked when we boarded the plane. Another thing, if you plan on going on the excursions, bring candy. The children will hear the bus/ATV and will come running in hopes of candy. This area is very poverty stricken so that is the only real treat they get. Also, we left a few dollars each day for housekeeping with some candy. Bring alot of 1's and 5's. It was hard to find anyone in the resort that wanted to break a 10 or 20. We also left a few bucks each time we ate for the wait staff and they were very grateful.

<Author>pamelaG99
<Content>Beautiful resort.... We visited the Majestic from July 11 to July 18. The hotel itself is gorgeous. The beach is nice and the pool is FABULOUS!! Nicest pool my boyfriend and I have ever seen. We were very disappointed with the food. The food at the buffet was always cold.... at breakfast the waffles and pancakes were hard, the eggs were always undercooked and gooey... so after the second day we just skipped breakfast every morning. We never really found anything we liked at the buffet for lunch or dinner except the pasta. The pasta was great, the bolognese sauce was decent... so for the last 4 days we ate the pasta for lunch and dinner. We tried 3 of the restaurants, and the only one we kind of liked was the Dominican restaurant... the fajitas were very good. We asked for cheese and got beef. This is how serious the language barrier is.Our biggest problem I would have to say was this language barrier. Most of the staff does not speak English very well. LEARN SPANISH BEFORE YOU GO!! We learned a little and thought it would be enough... but we were really lost. Learn how to ask where the bathrooms are, where to get food at night, and learn how to ask for your beverage of choice IN SPANISH!! They didn't understand us when we ordered our drinks (just asking for a Jonny Walker on the rocks we got a full glass of JW with a bottle of water on the side....??). If you ask for mustard you will get mayonnaise. (BTW mustard= moustaza) It was a lot more difficult than we ever thought it would be.The beach was very nice, you could walk for miles in either direction. However at the Majestic be careful when you're in the area closest to the resort... we found about a dozen pieces of glass... where they came from I have no idea... but make sure you wear your flip flops when you're on that part of the beach. There is NO information about the resort in your rooms. The staff at the front desk don't speak a lot of English so it is difficult to get any questions answered. Make sure you do some research on the hotel before you go, and like I said before, learn Spanish or better yet: buy an English to Spanish dictionary!! Our vacation would have been a lot better with one of these handy.The workers at the casino are SO SO RUDE... the bartenders are GREAT, the waiter was soooo nice,.. but the dealers are incredibly miserable. Watch out when you play blackjack. They scam you big time. Twice the dealer took my money when it should have been a push, but they take the cards away so fast you don't have time to say anything... the first time I let it go, and the second time I demanded to see the cards... the dealer got very upset and the pit boss came over, the dealer argued with her in spanish and then stormed off. The pit boss then just gave me my chips back but really it didn't make me happy. Other people at the resort had the same problem. Also be careful when playing the machines... the power went out 3 nights in a row for almost an hour over the entire resort. There is a computerized roulette game (which is sooooo fun!) BUT if the power goes out, you lose all the money you had in it. When we spoke to a couple that lost over $100 because of the power outage we were sure to cash out every time we hit $20, just in case the power went out again.I'm rating this hotel a 4/5 mostly for effort and for beauty. The resort really is stunning. Lots of trees, and it is very well taken care of. It's not really our type of resort however, or maybe just that the Dominican isn't really our ideal vacation spot. If you prefer to have the type of vacation where you just lie on the beach or by the pool all day, than this resort would be great for you. We are the type of people that like to wander into town, see the sights, go on excursions and stuff like that... and unfortunately Punta Cana doesn't really offer anything worthwhile.Oh and DO NOT BOOK WITH HOTELBEDS. They are awful. The shuttle on the way back was leaking and it completely ruined one of our pieces of luggage, and some items inside the suitcase. We wrote to their customer service department and haven;'t heard anything back. If you did book with Hotelbeds, then don't go see your rep, there are tons of other reps at the hotel that will be happy to help you book any day trips and stuff... and splurge for a taxi to get you there and back. Its worth the money to avoid this company, trust me. To be quite honest, we were not impressed with our vacation. But I try to be objective (hence the 4/5), and I can understand why people return to the Dominican and to the Majestic again and again. We were celebrating something special and the hotel sent us a couple bottles of wine as well as chocolate covered cherries and a platter of sushi. We were impressed and thankful by this gesture. The rooms are beautiful as were the hotel grounds... we will not return but I do understand why other people love it and do come back. It's just a personal preference I think, and if you do prefer to be more active on your vacation than I do not suggest this resort, or Punta Cana in general. It is by far the prettiest resort in Punta Cana though. So if you have been to the Dominican before and love it, I would definately suggest this resort (just don't forget your dictionary!)Cheers!

<Author>LauraEH
<Content>Had higher expectaions, but OK trip My boyfriend and I visited the Majestic Colonial from July 6-July 13, 2007. Overall, it was a good trip, but I think all the reviews are a little exaggerated and slightly misleading about how great this place its. Neither one of us had ever been to an all-inclusive resort before, nor had we ever been to the Dominican Republic. I must say, first of all, that the resort/beach is BEAUTIFUL--we loved the location, the resort grounds, etc--we had perfect, blue sky weather everyday (got really lucky on this) and for the most part, thought the room was very nice (we upgraded to the direct pool access room which I would highly recommend--it was very convenient to be able to walk out your door to the pool). There was a slight bug issue in the room (lots of small, ant-like bugs on the furniture (especially desk and nightstands), but I guess what can you expect--it is a tropical climate, etc. I would strongly advise reading as much as you can about the resort/what it has to offer/etc, because the rooms have NO guides/information about the resort (ie-no info about the restaurants/hours of operation/menus, etc/no instructions on how to use the phones even...this was fairly frustrating, but thankfully I had done a lot of research prior to coming and knew, somewhat, what to expect. We did have some issues with the phone that were frustrating...I had purchased an international calling card (which i do not recommend) prior to leaving home and intended on using this rather than our cell phones (which did work, but cost 2.00/min to use while there). There is a 2.00 connection fee anytime you use the hotel phone and you have to dial 0 to get the operator to dial the number for you. I tried 3 times to get the calling card to work, it never did, and was told that we wouldn't be charged as no call was actually made--we ended up just using our cell phones--upon check out, we were charged and told that it didn't matter what we had been told and had to pay for these calls--this was frustrating--we also spoke with others at the resort that said their calling cards would not work either--not sure what the problem was. My biggest complaint was the FOOD--in my opinion it was TERRIBLE--I am a slightly picky eater, but my boyfriend is not at all and we both had a lot of trouble finding things that tasted OK. There is certainly no lack of selection, everythinig just tasted strange and was very greasy--especially the breakfast. My best recommendation would be the French Restaurant, Le Gourmet--we ate there twice and I got the Pumpkin Cream soup and surf and turf both times and this was my favorite meal by far!! I was very disappointed w/ the Japanese Steakhouse Matsuri and the buffett--the beach steakhouse was OK, but definitely not good. I would STRONGLY recommend bringing snacks--towards the end of the trip, I couldn't take the food anymore and bought a small/med bag of Doritos from the gift shop that cost 7.00!! I ate that for 2 meals!! I would also STRONGLY recommend bring pepto bismol--we used all 24 tablets of ours--we didn't drink the tap water and never got sick, but had upset stomachs several days and assume the food had a lot to do with it. As far as activities go, I did the pool-water aerobics almost everyday--would recommend, and we took the Isla Saona trip, a little long, but would also recommend (we were gone from 6:30am till 7:30 pm and it cost approx 85.00/ea)--it's really interesting to drive through the cities and the Island is beautiful. Overall, we had a good time, probably wouldn't return, but if we did would definitely plan no more than a 5 day stay--8 was a little too much.

We did find that we loved the buffet for breakfast and lunch, but not so much for dinner - definitely take advantage of the other restaurants they have there. Also, if you are planning to eat a late lunch (3-4pm) avoid the Steak/Seafood buffet area as they kicked us one afternoon to start setting up for dinner. You will be amazed at the excellent service you get at the bars and restaurants and it will definitely be remembered. One of the couples in our group did an excursion around the island (Jurassic Safari, I think it was called) where they went to see a sugarcane field, coffee factory, a cave and had a typical Dominican meal. They raved about it! You can make reservations to do things like this in the lobby. Half of our group got deep muscle massages at the spa and they were amazing! Very affordable and the women were all very professional. A great way to end our trip! Everyone on staff is very attentive and polite. We had nothing but excellent experiences with all of the employees and other travelers! I would definitely recommend this facility to all ages - there were lots of families, couples, and travelers of all ages. It was also very affordable going off season - We had a great time!

The BAD - It was not only my room that had a weird smell but all the people we asked had the same problem. We bought sented candles at the Spa and it made it much better. Within a few days it went away or we got used to it. Buy your scented candles at home and bring them with you. In GENERAL - Don't go to the DR expecting great food(Only Casa de Campo) because it's just not. It's ok- Breakfast at the buffet and lunch at the beach was fine. (You can find something) Dinner we had a good experience at the Steak restaurant we ate there twice and the French we found good. We paid $1500 a person including air. We all decided that for what we paid the Majestic Colonial is a wonderful resort.

<Author>CollinsRome
<Content>Just Another Day in Paradise! Five nights at the Majestic were just not enough! After relying so heavily on Trip Advisor to help choose a resort, I wanted to give our opinion. Many others have gone into great and helpful detail, so I'll try to limit my comments.Folks have noted the beds are firm. That's an understatement. Hard is more like it. It took 2 nights to adjust. But adjust we did. As we also adjusted to flat pillows and sheets with little pills. It's a reality of travel that everything is not going to be like it is at home. Sometimes that's good. Because what we don't have at home is a gorgeous beach with lounge chairs, tiki hut umbrellas, palm trees with soft breezes and clear clean water. Enjoy! Enjoy the huge, beautiful clean pool for all its different possibilites. The active side, the peaceful side, the hot tub and it's partner with almost ice water. Enjoy the antimation team. They work hard to include everyone in the good time. The entire staff is very agreeable. Even the ones who don't understand a word you are saying. I never heard a negative comment about any staff member except in the Casino..(What's up with that?)The scenery is magnificant. Take lots of pictures, but also seekout the excellent professional protographer who will make your friends and family look great. And why nit-pic the food? There is a great variety and many options to choose from. We enjoyed the Sushi in the Japanese area, the French, the Steaks, the Seafood, and the regular buffet. You can always find something good! At many all-inclusive resorts you are limited to one or two special restaurants and must eat most meals at the buffet. That's not true here and my family appreciated that. Alcoholic drinks were not watered down as you will find in many all-inclusive resorts. If anything - you must ask for a bit more mixer if you want to stay upright!.For folks needing more privacy in the bathroom - I suggest bringing some duct tape to tape a sheet over the opening between the bedroom and bath. Bring plenty of reading material. That is expensive at the Majestic. A newspaper was over $10. US cable channels are plentiful. That was great to watch movies or the news in English.Another tip. Go to Guest Services on your first day. Ask for a map and any helpful information they wish to give. It will save some aimless wandering. If you want to take a helicoper ride or go on another excursion, book early in your stay. We waited too late to be able to get into some of these.This may not be the nicest resort we''ve ever visited. The Melia Paradisus hotels are more luxurious, but also more expensive.. Tthis resort is beautiful, a great value for the money and lots of fun. I would highly recommend it to anyone. You can't go wrong. You'll get a lot for the money.

<Author>beachlover32
<Content>Great Place Didn't want to leave Just got back from the Majestic Colonial. We stayed from July 6th thru July 13th. Our party consisted of 5 people. My husband, two grown children, ages 20 and 24, my brother in law and myself. We had a great time. The weather was great, with a little rain a couple days, but it only lasted 10 minutes and was done. A little back ground...this is the second time my husband and I have been to the DR, so we kinda knew what to expect. We booked thru CheapCaribbean and air flight with Delta, leaving Detroit to Atlanta, then to Punta Cana and had no trouble. Once we landed at Punta Cana airport, bought our $10.00 entrance card made it thru customs, got our luggage and found transportation to the resort, which was Turinter Tours, we were at Majestic Colonial within 35-40 minutes. The ride from the Punta Cana airport to Majestic Colonial is an adventure in itself. The way the people drive is something in itself. Quite amusing. Just sit back, hold on and enjoy the ride.We checked in without any problems, got to our rooms and changed into our suits and headed to the beach. It's a beautiful beach and the water is clear blue and clean. Each morning we would be at the beach by 9:00 -9:30 and had no problem getting front row palapa's. As you walk to the beach to the left (I think west) you can see mountains which are simply spectacular. And to the east all the way down the beach you can see the merchants tents. More on the merchants later.... The beach bar was the place to get a great drink from Flelix. What a great smile. I told him is was famous on trip advisor and he said he knew that. All the bartenders at the beach bar were very friendly. Everyday we would snorkle. Make sure you take some bread with you and an underwater disposable camera and the fish will find you. Our rooms were 2238 and 2237. Facing the pool. Right where the animation teams perform. Something that may help you out is room number...the first 2 is building #, second 2 is floor number, third and fourth # is room number. We could see the beach and watch the entertainment if we wanted to.The rooms were very clean and did not smell musty. The bathroom situation was a little odd, but we adapted well. We were on vacation and were only in the room to sleep basically. The shower is huge and great pressure. The toilet is a little cramped but not an issue. The housekeeping was excellent. Clean room and towels everyday. We tipped them a couple dollars everyday, and I think they appreciate it. Anytime we would see them walking by, they would smile and say holaThe pool was magnificient. We called it the never ending pool. IT starts by the main lobby and ends by the beach. Like other trip advisors write, you could find a quiet spot to float or participate in the activities by the swim up bar. Very nice.Our food was good. Something for everyone. Some people have written in and said the food just so so, but were were impressed with the Japaneese, Gourmet, and breakfast buffet. The Japaneese was very entertaining and a good time and great food.. The Gourmet food was great. Please try the pumpkin soup, and the beef wellington. WOW!!! Our breakfast each morning consisted of fresh squeezed orange juice or mamosa, omlets, potatos, bacon, sausages, waffles, french toast, fresh fruit...I could go on. We would eat lunch at the beach buffet. Salads, fruits, fresh pasta, hotdogs, hamburgers, chicken, fish, palea. You could eat at the beach buffet in your swim suits. Men, remember you must wear a shirt, but us ladies can go in our swim suits with wraps or covers. One day we went off the beach and changed into dry clothes and went up to lunch at the main buffet. To be quite honest it's the same thing at the beach buffet only you have to be in dry clothes. So we decided it wasn't worth it to go up to the main buffet for lunch. All and all the same food. We also ate dinner at the steakhouse and at the seafood restaurant. Same building only one side you order seafood and the other side you order steak, sausage, etc... Almost all the restaurants are air conditioned except the steakhouse, seafood restaurant, and lunch buffet. (Same building) It is open air concept. But with the breeze coming off the beach it was really no problem.My daughter and my brother in law had made a pack that each day they would try something new and different to eat. Needless to say, I did not participate in this adventure. It was quite fun watching them try new food and then watch the facial expressions. On two different days, went to the water taxi east of the resort (to the right of the resort when you face the ocean) There were two men with a boat and they would take you anywhere you wanted to go. Bargain with them. We paid $20 dollars for 4 of us for them to take us to and from the merchants tent which is about 2 miles down the beach.We just told them where we wanted to go and what time to pick us up. When we were done shopping they were there waiting for us. No problem. Quite an experience at the merchants tent. They are so friendly and try to sell you something. As we got off the water taxi they were right there to greet us. My husband and I have been through this before and as long as you don't let the touchy - feely, close talking get to you then you are fine. Everything was cheappy, cheappy, 99% off. Better sales than at Wal-Mart. (heard these phrases alot.) I bet we spent $250.00 buying paintings, jewerly, statures, and t-shirts. I wanted my grown children to experience this and they both had a blast. By the end of our shopping experience they had come out of the merchants tent loaded with bags of goodies. And great memoriesAbout Wedensday, my daughter and I craved some American munchies...we went to the Mini market at the resort and bought a $2.00 Milky Way and a $5.00 stack of pringles. UNBELIEVABLE. The checkout lady must have seen the look on our face and asked how much this would have cost us in USA and we told her and then she had the same look we did. But the $7.00 we spent was worth it. Believe me that Milky Way never tasted so good.Check out was a breeze. You have to be out of you room by 12:00noon. A CheapCaribbean rep was there and we got on the right bus, and headed back to the Punta Cana Airport. No problem thru customs, and immigrations. The flight back to Atlanta went very smooth. We even got bact to Atlanta 30 minutes early. Last year when I wrote about our adventures, coming home thru Atlanta was a disaster. So landing in Atlanta again was something I wasn't looking forward to. However, it went very smooth. The customs and immigrations people were wonderful. I guess last year must have been a bad day. We were welcomed back home with warm greetings and smiles. (Unlike last year) Really only one bad situation...It has been 20 hours since we flew into Detroit Metro and we still do not have our luggage. But we got a phone call a little bit ago and everything is being delivered yet today. And we are 90 minutes from Detroit. When we realized that some of our luggage was not in Detrout we had to go and file a claim with Delta Airlines and describe our lost luggage. (5 bags) I asked what had happened. The Delta rep said that Atlanta customs are so overwelmed and they want to thourghly check every bag. Sometimes the luggage doesn't make the flight. I was fine with that. However my husband wasn't. But I feel they are doing the best they can considering the world we live in today. Delta airlines have always been good to us and I know they will do everything possible to help us out.In closing (sorry this is so long) just some suggestions: * Remember you are in someone elses country. Try to respect  enjoy their heritage and their lifestyle. * Try some new food each, you never know you may like it * Tip the Dominican workers. they are warm, wonderful, happy people and they work for very little. *SUNSCREEN, SUNSCREEN,SUNSCREEN *Go to the merchants tent. A great experience. Buy something from them. It's cheapy, cheapy.Thank you Majestic Colonial. We had a wonderful time and made new family memories that will last a lifetime. We can't wait to come back.

<Author>dlr17
<Content>Avoid The Japanese Restaurant Overall, I was very pleased with the resort. We stayed in the Junior Standard room, which is the most basic available, but it suited our needs. The first room we were given had two double beds, but we were able to switch to a room with a single king, which I found to be very stiff and pretty uncomfortable. The A/C in our room didn't keep it very cold, but the ceiling fan did help a little bit. I liked the roomy shower; however, it came at the expense of the toilet area. There is very little room in the toilet (and I'm average sized) and I kept knocking the phone off the hook. Why there is a phone in there to begin with is a question I have yet to answer. There was a small college boy fridge in the room, although it did not keep things cold at all. I was surprised to find the TV got several US stations (including ESPN), although the satellite did go out on occasion, especially when it rained.Overall the food was pretty good, although I did get tired of it after about the 4th day. At the buffets, I found that most of the food that should have been hot was on the cold side, and most of the cold food was lukewarm. I would recommend eating at the different restaurants to experience some variety. However, I would recommend avoiding the Japanese hibachi restaurant entirely. I cannot stress this enough. Someone needs to put a tent over that circus. If you're idea of a good time is being trapped in a room with people screaming in a language you can't understand and whistling at ear splitting volumes for two hours, then by all means go for it. This, however, is not my idea of a good time, and thus I was about one more whistle away from turning into Jack Nicholson during the last half hour of The Shining. My girlfriend and I both enjoyed the French restaurant tremendously, and also liked the Steakhouse and the Mexican restaurant. The Seafood place was OK, but the lobster was awful. There is a Chinese restaurant that is not part of the Japanese section and doesn't require reservations, unfortunately, we didn't know about that until our last night.The pool is by far the highlight of the resort. It has something for everyone. We mostly stayed in the quiet end, which was near the front of the resort. However, there were louder and fun areas as you traveled down to the beach. There were also some Jacuzzi areas and a swim up wet bar. The pool had several ledge areas, which held about 6 inches of water, in which you could lay down in or pull a deck chair into. It made for a nice relaxing time. The water temperature was perfect.One caveat...if you plan on playing a lot of tennis during your vacation, this is not the place for you. There are 3 courts, none of which are playable. They have something they call a clay court, but where I'm from we call it a gravel pit. It was just a lined plot of gravel with huge rocks. One of the 2 hard courts looked decent, but unfortunately the net was lying in a ball off to the side. The other hard court had big sections of gravel and dirt. We raised the issue to the front desk, and the next day they sent us a note saying the courts were repaired. We went to check it out and found that they had run a few lines of green paint on the court with no net. So much for tennis.The resort had a gym, and I was pleasantly surprised with the amount of equipment, because I expected nothing. They had a small selection of free weights (dumbbells and bars) and some weight machines, as well as some cardio equipment. It's by no means a health club like we have in the states, but it gets the job done for a week. Although I think the guy who worked there was trying to make a play on my girlfriend all week.The beach area was very well kept, spacious, and never crowded. We walked past several other resorts and it looked like a tornado had blown through, with people and stuff everywhere. All in all, I was very pleased with the resort. Nothing was ever crowded, the staff was very pleasant, and there was plenty to do. Just please, please stay out of the Japanese restaurant.

<Author>newmchugh
<Content>An amazing vacation from reality! First, let me say that I feel absolutely compelled to write this review. I stalked Tripadvisor for months trying to decide where to stay on this vacation, reading reviews and reading the forums. Therefore, I would like to share my experience with others and try to share some things that haven't already been shared....although I think that may be hard to do!My hubby and I had gone alone to the Riviera Maya in November 2006. We stayed at the Iberostar Maya (free upgrade from the Lindo) and we were extremely impressed. We were afraid we would be disappointed with the Majestic, as we had high expectations after this trip. But we were not!As a background, I went on this vacation with my husband, my 10-year old daughter and my in-laws. We booked through Cheap Caribbean and received a fantastic deal. We were there from June 1 - 6, although I wish we could have stayed longer! We were looking for a relaxing vacation as the past few months were quite tough for our family. I believe we found exactly what we needed.Unfortunately, the flight from Chicago was a bit of a pain. There was not a direct flight from Chicago, so we flew in through Puerto Rico and flew home through Miami. Long days of travel, but well worth it. Hopefully airlines will realize what a great destination Punta Cana is and will offer more direct flights through major carriers.Upon arrival at the hotel at about 4 PM, after traveling since 5 AM, we were greeted with cool, scented towels and a Majestic. At that point we were hooked on the Majestics!!! I had tried to confirm my reservation a few days before but I believe the Majestic's internet was down, and I never received confirmation. We were a bit nervous, especially since we had been through hell and back with our passports, as we traveled the week before they changed the passport rules. Anyways, Victor, Oscar and Emily had certainly taken care of us, giving us a special check-in and beautiful rooms for both my family and my in-laws. I would strongly advise to make your reservations for the Japanese and Gourmet restaurants immediately. We had no problem getting reservations, but had we waited, I don't know if that would have been the case. Our rooms were absolutely gorgeous! I am not sure as to the room category, but we were on the 4th floor and had two room suites with the jacuzzi inside as well as one on our own private deck. We never had problems with the air conditioning, nor did we have and musty smell issues, as some guests had mentioned. The air in general had a Caribbean smell to it....which was not a bad thing! The beds were harder than the ones we have at home, but I had no problems sleeping at all and no back aches. We had a king size bed in one room and they put a twin sized bed in the other room for my daughter, thus giving us some privacy, which was really nice. Yes, the bathrooms are an odd set-up, but as we had two rooms, it wasn't an issue at all. We aren't too bothered by these things anyways. The shower was big enough to fit a bowling team.....very nice. Never had issues withwater temp as well. No problems with maid service....we left a few dollars every day, and they were clean apon our return. We didn't spend much time in the rooms during the day, as we were enjoying the sun. Our mini-bar was always restocked as well. Always had clean towels. At one point we had some ants, since my daughter sloppily ate some crackers. Housekeeping came very quickly ans sprayed, and even left the can with us. The ants were gone in a few minutes and never returned. OK, as for the pool, I believe everyone has said everything that needs to be said. It is magnificent!!! The water temp was perfect....not too warm, but definitely not cold. I am a baby when it comes to water temps, and I had no problems walking right in. the pools were always clean....which is surprising, due to all the empty cups that people leave lying around. We mostly stayed at the noisy end of the pool by the swim-up bar. We did water aerobicsevery day at noon....quite fun. We participated in many of the games and had a blast. We met a great group of people from KY, CT and Puerto Rico. It was very easy to socialize in this area. The animation team was great as well, although they were geared toward adult entertainment rather that with the babies or kids, as they called them. Regardless, my daughter did aerobics with me, and learned the Tacqui dance as well, and still does what she can remember when it plays on our ipods! You can definitely find quiet areas in the pool as it is so expansive. As for drinks, we mostly drank at the swim up bar. I believe Bianca was our main bartender, and she was very attentive. Of course, this became more difficult at times when it was more crowded, but what can you expect! My daughter must have had at least 30 non-alcoholic Majestics...yummy! My hubby loved the Pressidente, and the guys would often order them by the tray!! We tried shots of Mamajuana.....very tasty, and if you can't catch a buzz, try some of these!! I mostly had alcoholic Majestics, Miami Vices, and I would request Stoli and cranberry. No problems with alcohol content. I would suggest to bring an insulated cup....I had read this, but didn't get a chance to buy them, and I wish I had! The ice does melt fast...duh!The beach was gorgeous, of course. The water was clear, and the waves were too bad. There were a lot of topless women, as a lot of guests are European. We just tried not to look! We brought sand toysfrom home and built a castle. We didn't have any problems getting a palapa, but we usually went to the beach in the morning.As for food, I found it to be quite good overall. Remember to bring pants for the men if you want to go to the Gourmet. I accidently took my hubby's pants out of the luggage and we were not allowed into the Gourmet. We didn't have an issue with pants anywhere else. We ate at Taino, both the steak and seafood restaurants and the Japanese. All were very good. The buffets were great as well. Of course, I wasn't expecting downtown Chicago quality food, but we were not unhappy. I think the food at the Majestic was better than the Iberostar.A few other thoughts to end this monster of a review.....The layout and size of the hotel were great. It was much smaller than the Iberostar, yet had everything we needed. You could find your way easily, and everything was scenic. There is a Catholic chapel on the property, which has mass on Sunday at 11. We attended, and although most was in Spanish, you could follow along. We did not use the kids club for my daughter. She made a friend from Miami, and they would play in the pool while we were doing our own thing (always in our sight, though). There were not many kids there, especially since we went June 1 and most are still in school. While my daughter had a blast, kids that require a lot of activities may not be as satisfied. Again, we did not check out the kids club....although from afar it seemed to cater more to younger children.We unfortunately lost our digital camera the first day we were there. I must have but it down somewhere...no clue. So sadly we don'thave many memories, and this put a damper on my vacation! The last day I did buy a disposable for $25....yikes. The pics were just ok. They have photographers at the resort who take beautiful pictures, but they are also a bit pricey. I would suggest bringing a cheap disposable, just in case. My hubby did have some stomach problems while we were there, but when you eat a lot, drink a lot, and spend the entire day in the sun, what do you expect! We brought any medicine that you can think of from home....tums, heartburn meds, pepto bismal, advil, etc. I would suggest to do the same. Bring a lot of sunscreen! We brought the spray, and it seems to go a lot quicker than the lotion. The sun really is hot down there, so be careful! Bring some aloe as well, for nighttime in case you burn.I heard people had problems with the ATM, so be sure to bring enough cash. We brought at least $100 in singles, and my in-laws brought a lot as well. We always tipped, as the people are so hard-working. Service was almost always top-notch. As for excursions, we went swimming with sea lions. It was a lot of fun. We also went snorkeling throught the hut that is located on the beach, to the left. Otherwise, we stayed and played at the resort. There were definitely not as many excursions as Mexico, and no town like Playa del Carmen. This was fine with us. We never felt bored!!I have much more I can say, but I don't want to take up an entire page on Tripadvisor!!! Overall, this was a great trip for the price, and I would, and hopefully will, return. If you have any questions, please feel free to email me at nplestina@yahoo.com. If you are looking for fun, relaxation, great service and beauty, the Majestic is a great option!

<Author>pmla1117
<Content>Absolutely loved the Majestic! I stayed at the Majestic for a family vacation May 28th-June 6th and it was outstanding! I don't have any complaints. If you wanted to relax by the pool the end by the lobby was good for that or if you wanted to be by the action, the beach end of the pool as perfect. As for the food-delicious! I loved the seafood restaurant. The lobster was delicious. We also went to the Japanese steak house and that was great! The portions were huge. My parents and brother LOVED the fish they served at the steakhouse. For lunch we went to either buffet. There is something for everyone. The paella was my favorite. The pasta station was also super. I would recommend making reservations your dinners as soon as you arrive. You only need reservations for Japanese and French restaurants. They fill up very fast and many people didn't know this. The Japanese also has a Chinese restaurant in it where reservations are not required. The lemon chicken was delicious. The only place we didn't try was the Dominican/Mexican restaurant/ At night we watched the shows and either headed to the sports bar to watch a game or hung out at one of the many bars. They had a drink called a Dirty Mokey which was refreshing. We did take the Jeep excursion which showed us a lot about the country. I would recommend bringing a camera and wearing lots of sunscreen. Also, when laying out all day make you are you reapplying your sunscreen because the sun is a lot more powerful there then in the US. The market was right outside the resort and you can get great deals. DO NOT pay the asking price. You can expect to pay about half the asking price, if not less. If they don't offer you a price you like, move on to the next vendor. Most of the staff understood basic English so it wasn't too hard to communicate. I found the staff to be very helpful and polite. We met quite a few people. A few people we met were on their honeymoons and having a great time. The Majestic deserves the wonderful reputation they have earned. I will definately be returning to this resort-hopefully in the fall already!!

<Author>LCutie112881
<Content>Awesome!!!!! I just got back from a week-long stay at the Majestic Colonial and my boyfriend and I LOVED it!! Upon arrival, we were immediately greeted with a cold towel and a frozen drink called the Majestic Sunset (a frozen creamsicle). The rooms are absolutely beautiful, complete with oversized beds, ceiling fans, a jacuzzi, and a deck! The only downfall is that the bathrooms are not entirely private (aka they are constructed like bathroom stalls). Let's just say my boyfriend and I made a deal to go on the deck or blare the TV when the other one had to use the bathroom. haha The pool is 1/4 mile long and has something for everyone. Both ends are rather quiet, while there is a wet bar in the middle and games and activities near there. The beach is about 20 feet from the pool and they have different activities there too. I played volleyball a lot and my boyfriend and I both participated in a coconut-throwing contest on the beach. The hotel has energizer staff to get the crowd pumped and involved in all of the activities and it worked. Even though you are there to relax, the activities are a lot of fun. The one thing I would highly recommend doing is taking an excursion. We booked ours through Prieto Tours (in the hotel lobby) and went on a day-long excursion to Catalina Island. We were picked up at 7 am and our tour guide, Carmenia, was the nicest woman in the world. We drove for an hour to Caso de Campo, and she educated us about the Dominican Republic and its people. While it was very interesting, much of it was also very sad since the Dominican Republic is a very poor country. Once we arrived at Caso de Campo, we saw the villas where Michael Jackson, Sammy Sosa, and Shakira all have homes and saw an ampitheatre where Frank Sinatra used to perform. After leaving here, we took a catamaran out to Catalina Island and went snorkeling on this deserted island. We enjoyed a lobster lunch, vitamina (Dominican rum and coke), and dancing on the catamaran on the way back. Most of us were a little drunk at this point from the vitamina and the waves tossed us about like we were fish...let's just say it made for some funny dancing. Anyway, the Majestic Colonial was amazing and I would go back in a heartbeat. I had heard mixed reviews about Punta Cana in general before I went and I can't figure out why. Perhaps we enjoyed it more because of where we stayed....the staff were warm and welcoming and made us feel at home. Overall, here are some tips:1. avoid the water - drink only bottled water!! They will tell you that they use bottled water in their pitchers to fill your glasses, but it's not true. ASK FOR A BOTTLE THAT YOU CAN OPEN YOURSELF. 2. Food: The stewardess on the way down told us to avoid pork products. We also stayed away from most fish. You aren't sure how they keep it and cook it, so it's better to be safe than sorry.3. We were awakened early by the maids about 4 of the 7 days we were there. I think they had a censor/motion detector outside the door to indicate to them whether or not we were in the room (iRobot?), but if you are asleep, clearly you aren't making any motion. You might want to ask how to avoid this at the front desk. Or, just make your own Do Not Disturb sign and hang it on the front door.4. Drink lots of Presidente beer!! - the mixed drinks are not good. Plus, the yeast in the beer helps eat up any bad bacteria that you may have eaten.5. Apply your sunscreen religiously throughout the day...otherwise, you will wind up positively scorched. My boyfriend and I sat in the shade (he had 50 SPF on) and he still got burned!! 6. Bring single dollar bills with you. Often, they don't have change or you have to get money from the ATM in pesos. 7. Bring snacks! I was craving American food by the end of the week and paid $5 for a thing of Pringles!!! If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me at lradano@gmail.com. Have a wonderful trip and enjoy the Majestic Colonial!!!

<Content>Good Deal My wife and went with two other couple friends and stayed for 5 days. Overall, our experience was good. The rooms were relatively clean and spacious. Glad to go with friends because we spent lots of time together and helped pass the evenings. Bring DVDs if you want to pass time at night. Overall - this place is a great deal for the price we paid. <Author>Boston_ABbaby
<Content>Heaven, Heaven, Heaven I'm going to start this with a few basic facts about us because I believe it's important to contextualize my experience a bit. First: I have never been to an AI before, my boyfriend has been to one, in Aruba. Second: I am 27 y.o. and my boyfriend is 30. Third: I'm going to try and keep this brief, and just share what I think are the most important details. Third: We were there from May 22nd-May 30th, 2007Airport: Arrived at 2:30pm. Paid a $10 Tourist fee. We were through the airport and out to our bus (we booked through AAA and our transfers were included) in about 20 minutes, including time to collect bags/go through customs/use the bathroom.Arrival: The same as all the rest. Quick, easy, low key. Lovely non-alcoholic cocktail. Cold, Lavender scented towel. We were loaded into a small van with our bags and driven to our room. Only one of our keys worked when we got to our room and the man helping us zipped right back to the front desk and brought us a new one within ten minutes. That one didn't work either, but we learned from other guests throughout the week that this is common, but eventually we got two keys that worked; it just took a few tries!!Room: Lovely, big, clean, and cool. We had an ocean view with a balcony. We paid for the basic room and I emailed ahead and asked for an ocean view/king size bed/not on the first floor. We got it. The bed was hard, the sheets not so soft, and the pillows thin. We were so tired by the end of the day that it didn't matter and we both fell asleep without problem. The jacuzzi was great, the shower huge. There is a large closet, two sinks, hairdryer, robes, just a few hangers, a safe that you program yourself, and a large TV with remote. We got lots of channels, but reception was spotty, so we mostly relied on Discovery Channel and CNN. There was a complimentary bottle of Champagne when we arrived and the mini-fridge was refilled daily with beer, diet pepsi, pepsi, orange soda, 7UP, water, and chocolate bars. We never had a problem with noise in the room. Our room was cleaned daily without problem; and we hung a Do Not Disturb sign on the doorknob each night before bed. We bought $2 worth of washcloths from Target before we left after reading everyone's complaints of not being able to get them and then just left them there when we came home. Scented candle was quite helpful.Food: Fine. Some things were very good, some not so good. But we could always find something we liked, and many things we really liked. We always ate breakfast at the main buffet and bounced back and forth between the main buffet and the beach buffet for lunch. Just a note about breakfast: there is a seemingly little known about continental breakfast served out by the pool bar where the band plays at night for those who don't want to go all out. We ate dinner most nights at the main buffet, although we did branch out for the Japanese and Gourmet, both of which required reservations. Both were very good. Illness: I always get sick when I travel. That said, I also tend to be someone who believes When in Rome... and will eat just about anything because I feel that often the best food in a foreign country is what the locals are eating at small food stalls. This trip, however, I was adamant about staying healthy and was quite careful about what I ate, as was my boyfriend, and neither of us got sick. The people I met who did get sick ate without thinking; subsequently my advice is this: Take acidophilus/pro-biotics before you go and while you're there. You can take Pepto as a preventive thing (the CDC says two tabs, 3x a day) but we quickly learned that this caused the exact opposite problem we were trying to avoid. If you don't recognize it, don't eat it. If it's supposed to be cold and it isn't, don't eat it. If it's supposed to be hot, and it isn't, don't eat it. If it's been sitting there for two hours, don't eat it. If it's raw, don't eat it. Also, people keep saying the spent so much money on supplies when they did get sick. We brought our Pepto, Tylenol, thermometer, Gatorade Powder (to prevent dehydration in the event of illness), etc. Although we didn't need them, we met people who did, and who had spent $90 on the same things in the DR.Alcohol: Plentiful. Wonderful mixed and frozen drinks, beer, and wine. I recommend the Dirty Monkey, the Majestic, and the Mojito. My Cosmopolitans were also quite good. Bring an insulated mug (whether it's a Bubba Keg or not, doesn't matter. We brought our travel coffee mugs and were SO glad we did. The plastic cups are tiny and the drink melts.)Beach: Perfect. Nothing more to say than that. Never a problem getting a palapa. Clean, soft sand. Miles to walk. Places to snorkel right off the becah. Bring a floatie ($3 at Target), it's great for the beach and the pool....Pool: Enormous. Lobby to beach without stopping. Plenty of space for quiet and plenty of space for fun. Again. Bring the floatie. It gets hot in the sun, and reading while floating is lovely.Entertainment: The band, the piano bar, and the sax player were great each evening, and sitting listening to music in the open air with a cocktail before dinner was perfect. Appetizers: Every night in front of the main bar at the bottom of the Lobby stairs. And they always had a Cocktail of the Night to go with the food.We went on this vacation looking to eat, read, sleep, tan, drink, float, swim, snorkel, and relax. And that's exactly what we got. We are planning to return at Christmas with our families; which means we loved our trip so much that we have recruited 12 people to return with us in less than a year.

Mamajuana isn't the smoothest going down, but will hit you hard if you drink a few shots of it. Presidente beer was also cool and refreshing. 5. Rooms were nice, no musty smell, nice view, and the AC was decent. 6. Beach was nice, just had some rocks and seaweed, au natural. Pool was great, even for a late night swim.Tips-1. Wasn't gonna venture off the property, or risk spending lots of money on hotel phone. 4. Always haggle at the shops/tables, could get items originally quoted at $30 for 8 bucks! (about 32 pesos per $1)5. Bring a thermal cup for drinks and even an inflatable raft to take to the pool. Bring an OFF candle, gives a nice scent and keeps bugs away. 6. Don't need converters for electrical devices, safe was easy to use, most of staff speaks English well. Didn't bother with spa, excursions and so forth, just relaxed!7. Not the greatest for singles or young groups.If you just wanna chill out in a decent place, then go for it.

To summarize; The Majestic is first class and we would not hesitate in returning.

We were at the Majestic from 4-18 June.Arrival at check-in. Greeted with the wet towel and refreshing cocktail.
