<Author>Nokes
<Content>Wonderful Service...Beautiful Location! My husband and I stayed at the Majestic from Dec 21 to 28, 2006. We were there to attend my cousin's wedding, which made this a unique experience. Below, a brief overview of our fantastic trip:FOOD: If your idea of a dream vacation is gourmet food and spectacular dining experiences, I would recommend against all-inclusives in general. All-inclusives tend to have a formula: breakfast, lunch and dinner buffets, a few specialty restaurants, and more casual eats near the beach. You will not go hungry, but you will rarely have a magical experience. Le Gourmet had a couple of very nice dishes (squash soup, veal), and the Rodeo Steak House surprised us with an amazing steak and fries. At Matsuri, we asked them to make a custom sushi roll (rolled in tempura batter and fried) which was fantastic!! Overall, the buffets were varied enough for a week's stay and fairly tasty. I was trying to be careful not to get sick, so I stuck to simple stuff and I was fine.ROOMS: I thought the room was beautiful! I agree with the reviews regarding the bathrooms being not private enough. I was there with my husband so it wasn't a problem, but if you are sharing a room with kids it could be tricky. Take advantage of the jacuzzi tub!! Beds were comfortable, air conditioning was perfect.POOL: I LOVED the pool. It was crystal clear and we didn't have a problem getting pool chairs up to about 1pm. The swim-up bar was great! Tip the bartender your first few times, ask him his name and get to know him, and pretty soon he'll be pouring you very generous drinks. Bring an insulated mug; you'll have to go back for refills less often and you'll keep the bugs out!BEACH: Beautiful beach! I love the fine white sand. The beach chairs get full pretty early. Personally I prefer the pool since I don't like a bikini full of sand at the end of the day, but the ocean water was warm. Waves can be a bit rough - keep an eye on non-swimmers.SNORKELING: We would not recommend going snorkeling with the company that operates at the Majestic beach. They would not give us a group rate for 12 people, their boat was 40 minutes late, and the boat captain was impatient and barely spoke English. They said they would take us to a site that was calm and good for beginners and that they would have a ladder for people to get back in the boat. Instead, we went to a choppy site, four people on our boat threw up, there was no ladder and people injured themselves being hauled back into the boat, and to top it off, the coral was all dead at the site they took us to. NOT WORTH THE MONEY.SERVICE: I was impressed with the service. Anytime we asked for anything (more towels, water, specially made meals, various wedding-related requests) they were more than happy to accomodate. Don't be afraid to ask for what you need, just PLEASE remember to be polite!! They really do work hard to make a living.DRINKS: This was my other area of disappointment. I am a wine drinker and was excited to order some wines with dinner, but they were sold out of almost all the specialty wines on their list. Their house red and white are TERRIBLE - undrinkable. I switched to liquor - many premium brands are available. The bartenders make some nice cocktails.OVERALL: Beautiful resort, gorgeous beach and pool, enough food, drink and entertainment to keep you happy. We would definitely go back!

<Author>beachbumIrricana
<Content>Great vacation, Great resort! We just returned from the Majestic Colonial on Friday morning after a week's stay, and I am wishing that we were still there. This was our third trip to Punta Cana, and as always, we had a great time; the Dominican is one of our favourite places to travel to. My husband and I traveled with a group of 8 others, all of who had never traveled to the Dominican before. Since my husband and I have traveled to Punta Cana in the past (Barcelo Beach and Melia Caribe), we were looking for a resort that would service the needs of all the individuals traveling with us. Overall, this was a great resort. We have traveled not only in the Dominican, but in Mexico as well, and I would rate this resort as one of the top resorts we have stayed at. When traveling, I always try to keep in mind that there's no perfect resort out there; there's always going to be things that you like an don't like, but it's the overall experience you have that matters.We arrived at the Majestic around 10:00 in the evening, and we were the only one's at the check-in desk when we arrived. Prior to traveling I had made room requests through our travel agent, as well, I had emailed the resort a week before arriving to confirm our room requests. Of the 5 rooms we booked, 3 of the rooms met (or partially) met the room requests we made. I noticed that my husband and I had been put in a room on the 1st floor of block 1000, which I immediately asked to be changed - we had requested a room in the 3000 or 4000 block on the 2nd or 3rd floor with a king-sized bed. I was told that nothing else was available, and to come back the next morning to request a change. After being persistent, they finally took the time to check if another room was available, however, again I was told to come back the next morning. The result; room 1142 - a room with 2 double beds that overlooked the restaurant of the resort next door. Not very romantic, but how much time do you really spend in your room? That being said, my sister and her best friend were put in a room with a king-sized bed in Block 3000 that overlooked the pool - I question why they put a husband and wife in a room with two double beds, and then put two girls who requested two double beds in a room with a king-sized bed? It doesn't make a lot of sense, and when we questioned it, we were completely ignored. I think that this resort has a lot of work to do when it comes to their services at the front desk, and this is my biggest complaint of the service we received during our stay.We also had problems with the front-desk on the day we checked out. As we didn't fly out until late in the evening, my husband had asked for an extended check-out time (we were told by our Air Transat rep to do this, and that it shouldn't be a problem to do so). He was immediately told no by the individual he had talked to, however, after going back to the front-desk a second time and talking to a different individual, he was told that it would be no problem at all. In general, we got the impression that the front-desk doesn't really care about what kind of service it offers to it customers, and that they just fall back on the excuse that they're at 100% capacity all of the time. This is definitely not the service I would expect from a 5-star resort.The rooms, in general are very nice. We booked a standard garden-view room and it has everything you would expect from a 5-star resort room - large room, bar fridge stocked daily, etc. The open bathroom concept didn't bother us, however, I can see where it would be a problem for families or non-couples. As mentioned in previous reviews, the construction of the rooms (and in that matter, the resort itself) was done in a very shoddy manner (it appears as though they tried to put the resort together too quickly and that the specifics were overlooked). Although this didn't bother us, I heard others complain about it while were were there, and if you are one of those people who likes perfection, this may not be a resort for you.The beach was also nice, however, the other resorts we stayed at on Bavaro Beach kept better care of their beaches - we found that although they cleaned up the seaweed, etc. on the beach daily, there still seemed to be a lot of straws and cigarette butts lying around. At both the Melia and Barcelo they cleared the chairs on the beach every morning and raked it thoroughly. Bavaro Beach is one of the nicest beaches in the world, and I would suggest that everyone at some point in time in their life take the time to visit Punta Cana to see it.The pool was also very nice, however, as mentioned by a previous reviewer, there is some work they need to do to the sidewalks and decks of the pool area - some of the concrete areas around the pool is breaking up and needs to be worked on (sooner than later). The pool was colder than the ocean, so we tended to spend more time swimming in the ocean that we did in the pool.The food and service at the restaurants throughout the resort was outstanding - some of the best food and service we have received. If you can't find someting to eat at this resort, then an all-inclusive is not for you. We tried all the restaurants on the resort at least once, and all were fabulous in their own way - no complaints at all.Overall, this is a wonderful and beautiful resort. As it is a new resort, the foliage still has a lot of maturing to do, however, it is still a very beautiful resort, and in a couple of years I can only imagine how magnificant it will be. If you enjoy smaller resorts, then this would be a perfect resort for you - it's very easy to walk from the beach to the lobby, and vice versa. We have typically stayed in larger resorts, however, enjoyed being able to get around quite quickly without having to rely on a tram to get us from one point to another.Overall, I would rate this resort a strong 4 / 4 1/2 out of 5. There are some small things that need to be done by a resort to give it a 5-star rating, and this resort falls short of that. With a little attention to detail, however, I'm sure they could achieve this.

<Author>brucer2
<Content>A veneer of Excellence We stayed at the Majestic because it had been chosen by friends for their wedding. We stayed for 14 nights. If you a planning a wedding then I would recommend the Majestic, as they did a superb job. Just be aware that it rains repeatedly each day !This was our first all inclusive holiday and I am pretty sure that this is the best hotel in the Dominican Republic. But, if you are expecting 5 Star standards then think again.The hotel is very new but the standard of finish is dreadful. At first glance the hotel looks stunning , but it has been built very shoddily and within a couple of years unless they spend a lot on maintenance it will be come very tatty. There is a very long driveway up to the Resort, but if you walk down it you will see that they haven't quite finished the building work ( piles of rubble which haven't been removed or landscaped over). In many places they mixed concrete on the tarmac and never washed down afterwards so you see white patches. All over the hotel the concrete walkways are breaking up, and this is uncomfortable in the pool side areas when you aren't wearing shoes. The paths and pools areas have what could be be nice attractive inlaid bricks, but these are partly concreted over or have fallen out and this really spoils the appearance.In the bedrooms and public toilet areas the standard of tiling is a joke. They could never have used professional tilers as the standard of workmanship is awful. In many of the public toilets the flush mechanisms were broken.There was a lift outside our room and it never worked all the time we were there. I reported 2 faulty lights in my room but they were never repaired. I reported the coffee maker faulty but it was not replaced.Fortunately there is a a very good Doctor on site 24 hours. My wife caught Gastroenteritis and spent 2 nights in hospital, many people in our party experienced upset tummies.They do try to make the grounds look attractive, everywhere you see gardeners hard at work. The restaurants have a wide variety of menus, but there is little variation and it is possible that you would tire of the same food each day. The same food appears time and time again in different restaurants. The service is excellent.The bar and entertainment staff are first class and work very long hours ( always a smile ).The beach is stunning and is kept very clean. There is very good security minding the beach.I would recommend the hotel for breaks up to 7 nights, but you could become bored in the second week as the entertainment repeats weekly.

I'd get them to put it in the blender with ice and rum. A great afternoon treat! We went to all the a- la carte resturants which were a nice change from the buffet. LeGormet was nice, service there was top notch. If our wine was half empty it would be filled imediately. The wine at this resort is quite good being at other resorts with the wine coming out of a barrel, the wine here is in bottles and is nice. Rooms: First we were amazed that there was a bottle of champage there for us.The room was very spacious. My parents had a king size and my sister and I had two doubles. There was a bit of musky smell when we first arrived but we turned on the fan and kept the air at 20 and its seemed to to the trick. The shower are was huge probably 5 people could stand in there eaisly. We would leave our maid small gifts each day. Bars: We spent alot of time at night at the lobby bar with Juan. I do suggest taking a few dollar there as the first night we were there the service was a bit slow as the bartenders seem to tend to people who did have dollars to give. The entertainment staff will be there and love to get people up and dancing, its great. <Author>bnr74
<Content>not my favorite hotel Recently got back from a 7 night stay at the Majestic and felt compelled to write a review, something I've never done before. The quick summary is that this was not a hotel I would ever go back to. First, however, let me start with the positives. The grounds were very nice. The pool was very large and quite pleasant, and the beach was nice as well. The rooms were very spacious and were nice as well (except for the bathroom).  That being said, when we got to the hotel, they didn't have the type of room we had reserved. Rather than a room with a king bed, they had a room with 2 full size beds. The room issue did get fixed for the second night. But, I happened to be up at the front desk several times during the stay, and each time saw at least 3-4 people complaining about their room and being told to check back the following day to see if there was a different room available. At least some of these people that we subsequently spoke to were not able to get their room changed. The hotel was also very stingy with towels, both in the rooms and for the pool/beach. The toilet in the room was literally set up as a tiny stall; if you're claustrophobic or if you're a large person, you'll have a problem with this. The pillows were terrible as well. Luckily, I saw a review on Tripadvisor before my trip, and had my own pillows with me, so this wasn't a real issue for me. Now for the biggest shortcoming of the hotel: the food. Let me preface this by saying that I am not someone who demands gourmet food, and I am usually not difficult to satisfy. Breakfast was average. Nice selection of fruit, different types of eggs, cereal, pancakes, french toast (actually was closer to regular toast), etc... Nothing to complain about, but also nothing to brag about. Lunch, unfortunately was the exact same options every day. Much of it was from the previous night's dinner. It wasn't so good the night before, so repeating it for lunch was not very appetizing. The dinner at the buffet was the same every night as well, and the specialty restaurants were not very good either. My wife and I got so sick of the food that we decided to go home a night early, even knowing we probably couldn't get a refund for the last night.

<Author>zulusimba
<Content>This hotel is second to none! Firstly, DO NOT be swayed by the few people who complained about this hotel...if you take the time to read their complaints, they are petty, and most complain about their VACATION( ie, excursions, bartering, the airport,what the bus ride was like, etc). All of these items have nothing to do with Majestic Colonial ~ so its unfair to rate a hotel based on these issues!I can't say enough about the Majestic, its staff and the facilities it offers! We stayed for one week Jan. 4, and wished we were still there! The road-side entrance of the Hotel is not too inviting but don't dismay, once you arrive at the main hotel lobby, you forget all that you saw. The hotel staff make you feel instantly welcome, as bell-boys grab you luggage for you and you are directed to the check in area. The Front desk staff all speak English very well, and will check you in while a waitress bring you a nice cocktail to welcome you! All of your questions are answered and your uggage follows you to your room. The walk from the main lobby to your room can be long, depending where you are situated on the property, but when the hot sun hits you, who cares?The rooms are HUGE! As they are all suites, I think it was almost 600sqft in size (average hotel room is 375sqft), and is very nicely decorated with all up to date amenities including hairdryer, iron/board, jacuzzi tub, separate shower(could fit 4 people!), stocked mini-bar (water, pop and beer), oversized balcony with chairs and table, satellite TV. The electicity is the same as Canada, so no plugs are necessary. The pillows are not good,and the matress is firm, but at the end of the day, it still felt good to get a decent nights sleep. A/C is strong, and we didn't notice a musty smell at all. We left the houskeeping staff $2/day, and the bar re-stocker $1/day (got extra water  beer!).The pool is huge, and you can always find a lounger, although we did get annoyed by some people who would put their towel on the best loungers, fold down the back of it and leave it for whenever they felt like coming back to the pool, some HOURS later. Many a time I felt like removing their towel and act confused when they return! HA HA! Bar service is excellent, prompt and although I don't think the staff expect it, even a dollar to them every couple of drinks means the world to them. The Beach area is where we spent most of our time-fine white sand, aqua-coloured water, and lots of sun. It did rain almost every day, but it lasts for about 5 minutes, then blue skies again! There are salespeople on the beach trying to sell you excursion packages or bead your hair...they respect you if you don't make eye contact and won't approach you. When you say no thanks!, they thank you and move on. Believe me, they approached us twice in one week, and that's it-they are polite and are not pushy.The waves did get quite big on 2 occasions, but when you're dealing with the ocean, you have to expect it -water was clean, refreshing and A1!Our meals were excellent! Buffets provide everything for anyone, but they are still buffets-you do get a wide variety of options, breakfasts were very well done. Lunch gave you a couple of options, either buffet or you could eat at the Beach restaurant which served food all day-salads, pasta, burgers, hot dogs, calamari, paella, desserts all up to 3pm, but would extend it if there were losts of people eating late! Your options for Dinners are wide - every night we ate somewhere different! Buffet, Seafood, Rodeo Grill, Caribbean featuring authentic Dominican food, Le Gourmet(reservatoins needed), Maiko-Japanese cooked before your eyes(reservations needed), and the regular Japanese restaurant. All of the meals were done very well, and are worth trying! I didn't have high expections for the food, but walked away pleasently surprised and full! The staff at all of the restaurants are truly OUTSTANDING! They all move as quickly as possible to serve you- my drink was never empty, a dirty plate was wisked away within minutes, inquiries about how our service/meal has been, but not in any way did I feel rushed to throw back my meal to make room for the next guest. My hat goes off to the staff, and leaving a couple of dollars is purly at your discretion for outstanding service!Speaking of staff, we encountered no staff who left us with a negative feeling-all were friendly, approachable and eager to serve you and make you feel like a million dollars! They will speak to you in Spanish first, but most have some English skills, and between my poor Spanish and their poor English, we made it work! My advice is to try to learn a few things in Spanish~after all, we are in their country, and by making an effort shows them some respect. Everywhere we went on the property, we were greeted with a smile, be it the gardeners, the maid, the washroom attendant or the guys who cleaned the beach daily. These people work damn hard, and always have a smile-a tough thing to do! The Animation team - a group of individuals who try to get you involved in daytime activities, for some fun by poolside. If you don't want to participate, they will leave you alone, but they have the energy of 10 men! They keep you entertained during the day and usually have something to do with the evening shows, which were pretty good considering they probably operate on a small budget. Don't expect a Las Vegas show, and you will have fun!Overall, the Majestic exceeded our expectations and I would recommend this property to anyone, maybe not singles, but couples families defintely! You are in a third world country, so don't expect the country to have all the things we take for granted. On the bus ride to the hotel, you will find that the roads are awful, people live in shacks, some have no shoes, and seeing shopkeepers and guards on business properties with guns is not uncommon. All of the Hotels have fences surrounding their properties to keep locals out, and do have security staff. Other than those things, we didn't venture off the hotel property, but did walk along the beach daily (as does everyone else), with no problems or concerns for safety.I will be visit the Dominican again and will stay no-where else other than the Majestic Colonial!

<Content>Don't expect too much The Majestic Colonial is an average all-inclusive. Having stayed at a number of other all inclusives on other islands, it appears that, at least at this resort, the DR needs to do some catching up. We paid for an ocean front room which was lovely (after we went back to the front desk and demanded what we had paid for), spacious, clean and with a personal jaguzzi. There were plenty of lounges because everyone seemed to be at the more sheltered pools, where lounges were at a premium. The water was incredibly rough with whitecaps and rollers inside the breakwater.Food was acceptable to poor, depending what and where you ate. The bars had no snacks, what few hor d'ouvres they put out in one spot in the evening were inedible.Glad we were only there for 5 days, a week would have been way too much.

<Author>Suncanuck
<Content>Liked It But Not As Good As Sunscape The Beach We stayed at the Majestic Colonial from December 16-23, 2006. It was our second time to Punta Cana. We stayed a year ago at Sunscape The Beach. We booked this trip last minute and based somewhat on the reviews on Trip Advisor. The hotel property was nice. The hotel requires wristbands that must be worn. The towels require a card. You are only allowed one towel per person. There are reservations required at the French and Japanese restaurants. We found the buffet food to be only fair. It was the same food daily. The Japanese and Chinese restaurant was good. We tried to ask for lobster with our steak in the Steakhouse but were advised it was not allowed. The bars around the pool do not use blenders. They have crushed ice that are shovelled into glasses. The kids club was okay. The children played video games most of the day. The girls working at the kids club were very friendly. They assisted as much as possible. The shows were fine. We watched part of the Michael Jackson show and the trampoline show. There were several nights of interactive participation shows. The bars at night in the lobby had good drinks. The would make expresso and blended drinks. The main buffet restaurant closes at 10:30 am. We advised it was a bit early when we showed up and it was closed. The maid service was fair. We noticed that the bathtub was not cleaned daily. The mini bar was fully stocked. The room has a safe. There is internet access in the lobby. The stores on the complex were expensive. The entertainment staff were fun. There were many activities and games. The pool was huge. During our stay the spa was closed for repairs. The ponds on the premises were drained several times after a thunderstorm. We met several people from around the world. We had stayed previously at Sunscape The Beach and found it much better. STB had free towels, did not require reservations, had not wristbands, had nicer rooms and had friendlier staff. We would go back to Punta Cana but likely try another hotel or go back to STB.

<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	5	5	5	

<Author>rugby007
<Content>A Very Nice Place, Especially for Families Overall, this is a very, very nice all-inclusive resort on a wonderful property and beach.First, expect a bus ride of approximately 40 minutes over seriously bad roads, maybe 30 if you have a taxi or other direct hire. The DR needs to invest immediately in improved roadways to the Punta Cana resorts, or they're going to lose visitors.The resort is impressive, and it begins with the entrance. Check-in was easy and fast, with the bellmen in perfect sync with the front desk, the bags arriving at the room as soon as we did. Everyone arriving gets a virgin Majestic welcome drink (or more, if you'd like).The rooms are a very good size, each with a balcony. There is ample closet space, iron and board, a programmable safe, one robe, and lots of space for suitcases. The TV has a good mix of English, Spanish, German, and French cable, with channels for the kids, too. There is a massive shower (enough for 3 or 4--yow!) and a separate whirlpool tub in the room itself. There is a small fridge which is stocked with soda, water, and beer, and you get a bottle of champagne on arrival (actually, it's German weinhaltiges Getraenk).Our looked out onto the resort's single pool, a massive thing stretching almost the entire length of the resort to the beach. The water was consistently clean, with no debris. The pool deck, bottom tiles, and entry railings do need maintenance, though. The pool has plenty of deck space, with ample shade cabanas and very nice chaise lounges. There are numerous pool bars, and waiter/waitress service.The clientele was all over the place. As Americans, we were in the minority here, usually mistaken for Canadians. Lots of Europeans, especially French, Germans, and Italians. Also Iranians, Russians, and South Americans. Consequently, you get a number of topless ladies at the pool and the beach, and a laissez-faire attitude toward a bit of discreet full nudity as many Europeans would change into and out of their swimsuits poolside/on the beach. No big deal.The staff was uniformly friendly and helpful. I recommend a fistful of 5s, 10s, and 20s as tips to the staff, which his always well received. The only staff I encountered with attitude were the two ladies in the mini-market store, who consistently over 3 days had seriously unfriendly and peeved attitudes.The staff is passable in English, but a little bit of Spanish always helps things along. I recommend the Majestic invest in some basic English classes for all of its staff.The food was outstanding, especially for an all-inclusive resort. I stayed at the St. Lucia Sandals two years ago, and their institutional food was awful compared to the excellently prepared and presented food on offer here. There are usually three buffets to choose from, and sit-down, menu-order restaurants as well. Each place offers a variety of local fare as well, which I found most often to be the best food offered. To their credit, the Majestic has established and actually strictly enforces dress codes for the restaurants, such as men having to wear shirts in the beach dining room, and having to wear shoes in all other restaurants. A small touch, but it goes a long way to keeping things classy.There is a massive theater, and there are kids' movies every night. There is also a kiddie stage show, in which they get to participate. This is for the 3-7 crowd. The kiddie play area is small, but adequate. It is not that well developed.The casino also is small, mostly slot machines. There is a sports bar with a single pool table. There is no game room/arcade for the teenagers.The beach is close, and also has dozens of shade cabanas and the same chaise lounges. The sand is white and fine, just short of sugar sand. It's great for digging and sand castles. The surf is just right for kids, with an average beach break of about 2 feet. The surf is not good for boogie-boarding/body surfing. If you want that, you can go north/west about 1/2 mile up the beach for a much better place with a consistent 4-6 foot break about 60 yards out.Snorkeling and scuba from the beach is definitely not recommended, as there's a great deal of boat traffic, often traveling at high speed. The hotel has buoys marking the swimming area, and venturing outside this area is quite dangerous.The beach is marvelously free of hawkers and pitchmen. If you go up or down the beach, expect to be accosted by women wanting to braid hair and men offering parasailing, scuba, snorkeling, jewelry, etc. But on the hotel beach, there is none of that.This is a great family place. I was there with the wife, 2 kids, my sister, and my two parents. Everyone loved the place, and may well return in the near future. The place was packed with many families, and many little children. This is definitely a kid-friendly location. It also is most definitely not a singles destination.All in all, this is an outstanding resort, a welcoming place that is definitely worth every penny you're paying.

<Author>bdl003
<Content>Excellent Value - Worth the Visit! This is really a great hotel for the money. It is only one year old. I really recommend this resort - you will have a great time. Before going I read all the reviews, and paid close attention to the negative ones - which made me real nervous. The bottom line is that the negative reviews are not really accurate. Here is the lowdown:(1) The food is actually pretty good if you know where to eat. The breakfast is excellent. The lunch is so-so, but we mostly skipped it because we ate such a large breakfast. The Chateaubriand at the Rodeo Steakhouse is as good as anything you will get here in Boston. The Japanese Habachi style was also excellent. Also know that you don't need reservations for the steakhouse, nor to eat the sushi at the Japanese restaurant (which was pretty good). Sure, there are some spotty things at the buffet, but overall the food was alright. Also, I didn't meet anyone who got sick.(2) We found the service to be excellent. The people are very friendly. Sure, they don't all speak perfect english, but they try and always have a smile. Also, there are a lot of Europeans and Canadians at this hotel which makes it a whole lot more fun than your regular hotel at Aruba or some place like that.(3) The beds are not very comfortable - they are your typical Holiday Inn style bed (actually same brand I think). The pillows are very slim, so bring your own. I think they use these foam pillows to keep out the mold from growing.(4) We had an excellent room. We asked for quiet, and guess what, we got very quiet. Never heard a single thing in our room. We asked for second floor, away from noise, with no adjoining door inside the room. We were really pleased with the quietness. If you are a light sleeper, this hotel has something for you. I was really impressed.All in all, you will love this resort - don't listen to the negative posts. For the money, this is an extraordinary deal. Sure, it isn't the Westin Resort on Maui, but also you aren't paying $400 a night, and to be fair, it isn't all that far from the Westin in terms of quality.

We all enjoyed this tour very much.All in all we loved the Majestic and would not hesitate in going back at all.

We flew on a direct flight from Philly, and had no trouble moving through the Punta Cana airport. It wasn鈥檛 always clear what was coming next, but we had no trouble following the crowd, and the Dominican officials just sort of guided us along. We were the only two there, where we enjoyed some delicious frozen Majestic drinks, while everything was explained to us. As soon as we had our room key, a porter whisked us and our luggage toward our room. He pointed out the important sights along the way. Our room was 3330, a Junior Suite, Pool View. We explored the grounds, which were beautiful and took a nap before dinner. The first night is the gala buffet, which we did not know until we tried to go to an a la carte and found it closed. We inquired at Guest Services where they directed us to the buffet. It was so lovely! They had a station outside on the walkway making the evening鈥檚 鈥渃ocktail鈥?(I later learned this happened every evening, and it was wonderful) and they gave each woman a rose as she entered the buffet. I like that the hostesses take you to a seat in the buffet and pull out your chair. It eliminates the aimless walking around and hoping you aren鈥檛 sitting at someone鈥檚 table who just got up to get another plate of food.Most days we spent around the pool in the morning, with some ocean time later in the day. The sand was white, and there were huts a-plenty at the ocean and the pool. The ocean was clean and clear, and much nicer than many other stretches of beach that we passed on a walk down the strip. I got in the ocean in front of another resort and it was rocky vs. the soft sand of the Majestic. We didn鈥檛 participate in many activities, we prefer to take it easy, but we loved having the gym and game area at our disposal. We tried speaking English to the servers, bartenders, etc. but by Day 3, we pretty much gave up and went to Spanish. It wasn鈥檛 a problem, and since the knowledge was there (it came flooding back) it felt more appropriate anyway. But please keep in mind that these people who are serving you know MANY languages. They have a very hard job of walking up to you in a restaurant, looking at you, and guessing what language you might speak. If you courteously insert your appropriate language, they can reasonably accommodate you. Please don鈥檛 take it personally if they don鈥檛 choose the right language on the first try.There were plenty of included drinks on the AI plan, and we were able to eat lobster, shrimp, and filet mignon, which is more than I can say for many of the other resorts that I researched. All of the food did have a Dominican flair, but that does not mean that it wasn鈥檛 good! I probably gained 5lbs. in crepes and Coco Locos in only a week. I wish that the pool was open at night, as the lighting is very romantic, and a night swim would be a lot of fun!One night we had a leak from our ceiling at 1am, and though it wasn鈥檛 my favorite way to be woken up, I have to commend the staff on how efficiently it was handled. From the moment I heard the water and woke up, to the phone call, the service man arriving, fixing it, mopping, and leaving was no more than 30 minutes. At 1am, that鈥檚 amazing service! So is the mini-fridge man who brought us 5 candy bars every time we asked because we said we liked them! The drinks during the day were never strong. But you鈥檙e going to have to drink a lot to get a buzz. The night bars were more what we鈥檙e used to in terms of a serving. My husband and I are not beer drinkers, but we enjoyed the Presidente very much.Bring a pool float, it鈥檚 very relaxing to drift in the beautiful pool! <Author>pebblelake
<Content>Great, but not perfect I stayed at the Majestic Colonial based on the reviews I read prior to booking. It was rated the 2nd highest in this area of Punta Cana, and quite frankly, I was surprised after only a couple of days. A few comments: Food - the fresh food was great, but any cooked starch or veggie was way too salty (I don't eat meat or fish, so will not comment on either), and I could not eat my meal at the Japanese a la Carte. I looked like a blowfish all week, and could not get enough water in me to wash out that salt - even my morning oatmeal was salty, I had to cut it with fresh dates. Staff - lobby staff was not helpful the three times I had dealings with them. In fact, upon arrival, I waited 4 hours for a room that I did not book. When I told them so, after 30 minutes, they begrudgingly switched my room, still not as booked, but I wasn't going to change it again. The daytime activities are the same day after day, so if you choose the same spot daily, you'll hear and see the same thing. The fitness staff was non-existent even though the board indicated different activities daily - didn't happen. The rooms - pretty good, but strange open layout if guests are around. Just bring a pillow for a good night's sleep. The chambermaids just chatted amongst themselves, and though I was in the room twice upon their arrival, they did not thank me for the gifts they found on the bed. The mini-bar staff on the other hand were fabulous - I told them only once that I drink the water but not the soda, and my mini-bar was refreshed fully with only water. The grounds and inside stairwells were incredibly slippery after rainfall, very dangerous, and the pool area was very pebbly and rough to walk on barefoot. Lots of bugs, but that's probably because of the 'lakes' and waterfalls, which were dirty, smelly, loud when being cleaned and had pumps and vacuums the whole week, so really, what was the point if they have to keep servicing them on a daily basis? It took away from what should have been a very serene and clean environment. The groundskeepers work incredibly hard in my opinion, and still could not keep up with the mess that my fellow tourists from around the globe created. I was shocked to find piles of cigarettes butts on the grounds, inside and out, where ashtrays abound. Water bottles and empty cig packs were strewn around the perimeter of the grounds. Why would tourists do this? I could not walk around the pool barefoot since I would have stepped on a couple of lit cigs. This is very inconsiderate and disrespectful, but not the fault of the resort. By DR standards, this resort is certainly a 4, but definitely not the perfect 5 star that some have given it. I won't return to this particular resort when I go back to Punta Cana.

<Content>Great Honeymoon We stayed at this resort from September 25-30. Here is a breakdown of everything, some of which you have read before and some is new.WEATHER: Awesome! When we got there it was raining, but we did not care, it was 6pm. we ate and then stayed in the room. Tuesday night was an awfully loud storm, but no rain, strange. Everyday was beautiful, hot, but with a cool breeze all the time. There was rain all night I think Thursday night, but it did not start till about 10pm. No rain during the day though. It was great!1. POOL: Fabulous! It is long and great not too cold not too warm, doesnot smell like strong clorine, seems very fresh and very clean (except at the end). The entertainment at the pool is loud, but it is only for a little while at different intervals in the day. If you go past the barrier and go on down, you can get away from everyone and pretty much be by yourself. Only one complaint I had about the pool: IT CLOSES AT 6PM!!!!!!!!!!! What the heck!?!?!? We had a georgeous pool view room, it is all lit up and pretty, but you cannot get in it after 6pm!2. ROOM: Loved it! They are nice and big, lots of storage areas for stuff, and a safe to put valuables in. Large tub in the middle next to the bed was very nice. It had a large shower also. I do not recommend it for friends traveling or families. Like everyone said, the toilet area is very small and has a frosted glass door. You can hear and smell stuff when someone is in there. It didnt bother us much though. Same with the shower, it is frosted glass door. Cant really see through them, but you can make out that someone is in there. Bed was kinda hard, pillows suck. We meant to bring our own but forgot. They filled our fridge everyday with anything that we drank. 3. BEACH: Beautiful! Waves were good, nice and big. Some rocky areas in water, just move over a little. Saw some small fish swimming around, nothing big. We got a kayak for a little, that will tire you out quick. Not a problem getting chairs. There seemed to be more people around the water sports area, which not sure why because it was rocky there on the beach. Be prepared to see some breasts, people are not shy at all. And men in thongs. If you bring kids and they are not used to this, keep them at the pool.4. FOOD: Food was great. Never had a problem with the food at all. The first night we did the steak house. It was ok. Mine was not quite done enough, but flavor was good. The best thing were the hot wings at the beginning. They were awesome. Seafood was good also, got the lobster and it was delicous. Japanese steak house was ok, I did not like it much but my husband did. Gourmet was good, small portions though. Went to the buttet after for more desert. One night they had a party, so the restaruants were closed and it was a large buffet set up in the open air restaruant, that was good. We didnot get sick at all but brough gas-x and pepto with us, also imodium. Took a couple of gas-x one night but that was it. Oh, yeah and sometimes the water smelled fishy, I would get something else if it smelled bad.5.EXCURSIONS: Ours was through gogo tours, and the guy there was very nice, spoke english well. We went on the Catamaran sail to Saona Isle. I have always wanted to do it. Word of advise: Our resort is the last one, which means that it is the first to be picked up and the last to be dropped off. The picked us up before breakfast started, and we went to the next resort, and the next one and the next one and picked up people at bus stops and at the tour places from other resorts. Took about 3 hours on a bus. Then the hour and a half sail to a beach. Not an island, a beach. there were broken coral and shells all along the bottom of the water and lots of seaweed. We ate lunch, which was ok, and sat. and sat. and sat. Nothing to do. It was not the prettiest place and there was nothing to do. Then the speedboat back and they take you to a natural beach It was a shallow area in the middle of the ocean! Hello Shark Feeding Grounds!!!!!!!!! Ok we did not see anything but still. Oh, yeah, I do not recommend the sail unless you are young, and can speak and understand Spanish. Lots of music in spanish and a guy with a video camera that will tell you things in spanish, if you dont' understand him, he will ignore you. 6. LANGUAGE: We did not have a problem at the resort. The animation crew knew both so if they approach you and you say you don't speak Spanish they know lots of languages, that is not your excuse! It is kinda funny to watch people use it though. We dont know any spanish, but it did not matter. We didnt come to make friends, so if you are wanting to socialisze with people, Americans are few and far between. Money was not a problem either, we did not exchange and had no problems with dollars. We didnot tip anyone and everything was fine. We may have gotten a towel made up into an animal if we did though, oh well. A couple of more tips, bring lots of sunscreen. We bought a bottle before we left, but had others at home. They did not make it into the bags and we had to buy some. $18-25 for a bottle there. We did not go outside with out sunscreen, and thus we did not burn. Don't lay out your first couple of days, you will get lots of sun there so wait to lay out for color your last days. We saw a lot of people get VERY burnt and I am sure miserable. Bring a waterproof disposable camera, or a couple. If you go to the beach or go on a snorkle trip or any excursion, you are not gonna want to take your expensive digital camera. Get cheap sunglasses. My husband lost his RayBans in the ocean. Make sure your connecting flight back is at least 2 hours from when you get there. we landed in miami, and had to get our luggage (which took forever), go through customs with it, had to have it all checked out, recheck it back in, go though lines, and then find our gate. Our layover was not very long and we were scared to miss our flight. Luckily it was pushed back an extra 30 minutes so that we could eat something. Also, don't wrap anything up too tight. We brought back a couple of glass and stone items, and had to unwrap them and try to get them wrapped back up.I hope this helps. If you are going on your honeymoon, it will be perfect. We definetely will go back here again.

Freddy at the lobby bar makes the best drinks 鈥?try his frozen amaretto sour; Lidio at the lobby bar was very patient with us as we practiced our Spanish on him and we were never without a drink; Ernesto at the pool bar kept me supplied with coffee and water all day and occasionally entertained as he danced with the animation team. <Content>Overall, an enjoyable stay My wife and I and one other couple just got back from the Majestic recently and had a very enjoyable time. The resort does have more Europeans than Noth Americans, so if you have to have the majority of people around you speaking English, or topless sun bathing is offensive, this resort might not be for you. Neither of these were a problem for us! For English speaking guests, Mike at Guest Services will assist you in any way. He was great!We paid extra for a Jr. Suite Majestic Pool room. This is a 1st floor room with a patio that walks-out to the pool and has an outdoor jacuzzi. Not unless direct pool access is important to you, I don't think its worth the extra $, as all rooms are nice and the indoor jacuzzi found in all the rooms is better than the outdoor one. We've been to Secrets Capri in Playa del Carmen and to Couples in Ochos Rios and, although each has something special about it, the Majestic got 5 stars for their beach and pool!The Dominican all-inclusive experience, particularily at the Majestic, offers you a nice overall vacation and for the price we considered it an excellent value.

<Author>ankh1234
<Content>Great resort except for the restaurants My wife and I stayed sept. 2 thru 9. We are in our mid 20's and 30's. I don't speak Spanish and my wife knows just a little. We've been to the caribbean on a cruise and visited several islands, and stayed at an all inclusive in the riviera maya. I read most of the reviews good and bad and thank you for those. I always keep an open mind but also like to be prepared.Arrived at punta cana airport and purchased the $10 dollar cards, fast thru customs, avoided the bag grabbers that want a couple bucks for carrying your luggage 15 feet and went right to one of the tourist companies set up there. I had only bought airfare and hotel, so i needed a taxi or a transfer to hotel. There seems to be a set fee of $30 dollars per couple for a one way transfer in air conditioned mini bus. So if you need a tranfer to a hotel, after customs, just go right to one of the tour companies there, I happened to go to funjet vacations. Bus ride was wild and fun, similar to driving in Italy but with pot holes and speed bumps. Arrived at hotel after 40 minute ride, no wait at desk, guy spoke decent english, got a couple drinks and right to room. Here's where I noticed a problem right away but still kept an open mind. I had asked for a top floor room but got a second story room. From other reviewers as well from past experience, noise from above can be a problem, plus tile floors echo sound. Now for all those that seem to complain about every little detail to the front desk and try to get a better room, well i thought about it. The reviewers who did, seem to do better later. I decided not to complain, i saw positives - the room was on the end of building, so only 3, not 4 neighbors and it was in the middle of the resort convenient to everything. Fortunetly neighbors above were fairly quiet. But when furniture is moved, sounds like someone is vacuuming in your room, very loud.ok, for the room, exactly as expected, very large, jetted tub in middle of room with two sink bathroom, small toilet area and very large shower. no problem with water pressure. bed was comfortable for me and my wife. pillows are long and thin. i rolled my second one up for double support. tv has variety of channels for when you get food poisoning and can't concentrate to read. mini bar always stocked every day. maid came 4 days at 3 pm and 3 days at 10 am. no problem with service and always pleased. she even sprayed air freshener three days because in afternoon, we did get a musty smell from a/c. It smelled like heavy smoke and i tended to turn the a/c off in the afternoon or make sure i wasn't in the room then. smell sometimes came thru mid morning and late at night. Don't know if they have a problem with ventilation system as it may be smokers in some rooms sharing smoke with non smokers in other rooms. I never noticed the smoke when it was time to eat. why would i be in the room when its time to eat - food poisoning.restaurants: breakfast selection is excellent, lunch selection is good. Buffet dinner was best dinner meal we had besides gourmet. Steak restaurant had same food as buffet. caribbean restaurant was bad except their buffet selection was ok. The beef and chicken we got in our burritos and fajita's was tough and inedible. We took a couple bites and left. The following day, I was stuck in my room for 2 days with no appetite and very weak. Luckily i didn't throw up but did get diarreha (however its spelled) after i got my strength back and was able to eat again. Both my wife and i still have it but its finally getting better now that we are back in states. So she ate at buffet when i did not eat. We missed the fish and oriental restaurant. We did manage to eat at the gourmet the last night there and that was very nice. We both had chicken soup, filet mignon and chocolate cake. All very good. Gourmet was only one we would recommend though you are only allowed one visit a week. You can be carefull all you want when eating but you never know when the food will get you sick. My wife and I watched carefully what we chose, ate a yogurt a day, and yet we both got sick. We did see other people actually throw up at the restaurants but that was rare. Not much you can do but get better and enjoy the time you still have. We never got sick in the Riviera Maya. the resort: fantastic!!! pool is long and has activities most of the time or has its quiet places. bars all over the place. try the cooc loco or the majestic drinks. beach is very nice though swimming area is not that far into water. you do have to be carefull of rocks. plenty of chairs. kayaks and windsurfing. no pedal boats though which was disapointing. More up to date people there, so fewer tops. If you don't want to see breasts and ---, don't go to the beach anywhere. In other words, some of the men i saw out did the women in size. So get over the sexism thing people have in america and either allow all to go topless and none at all. spa was very good. Its good to know spanish but you can get by without it. Its polite to llearn a few common phrases and use them. Take the spanish lessons while you are there, it helps. Service was always very good. checking out was easy, taxis are waiting at hotel and are $30 per couple. At airport, you get passport stamped to leave, then switch lines to go thru security. not much direction so be careful you do it in that order. no a/c at airport and normal wait to get through security, so be aware. drink water before security.Overall a very nice resort. If it wasn't for the food poisoning and the restaurant food choices, I would go back to this resort. Activities, beach, pool, resort are great. food and bathroom stall not so great.

<Author>abcgphi
<Content>Place is truly majestic!!! My boyfriend and I (both in our mid 20's) went to the MC Aug 31 - Sep. We arrived a few days after Ernesto, but once we arrived you couldn't even tell a hurricane was anywhere near the place! I booked through beachdestinations.com and had no problems with them. I booked a garden room, however, 2 weeks prior to my trip I emailed the hotel requesting a high level room possibly facing the ocean...and I got exactly what I asked for : ) Entering the country was pretty simple and FAST. the rushed us through the $10 tax line and our baggage came out fast. I was worried about everything I read about the baggage handlers grabbing your bags. I said no once, and they let my bf and I carry o ur own bags. All the tour guides are set up outside the airport with signs. It was very easy to fine our tour guide who showed us to our bus. The bus ride was about 25minutes and they drive CRAZY there...make sure to wear your seatbelt! Like others have noted, it is a pretty poor place while driving through the country. When we arrived there was no line to check in and the front desk workers spoke perfect English. foodAs my bf checked in I headed straight to the reservations table. There was no need for me to hurry to the restaurant reservation desk b/c they had several openings. I read reviews of people who stayed for a week and couldn鈥檛 get into the Japanese restaurant....not true! I walked into the Caribbean restaurant, it didn't look good at all and we walked right out...just as many others did. On 2 occasions we stopped into the chinese restaurant just to get some sushi. It wasn鈥檛 as good as some sushi restaurants I鈥檝e been to...more like the sushi you get that supermarket...but still not too bad. I read horror stories about food poisoning, but I had no problems and tried everything at the restaurants. Breakfast was by far my favorite. Delicious crepes, made to order omelets, milk shake bars, mimosas, they would even cut the fruit in fancy shapes right in front of you if you requested. Breakfast is from 7-10..so you cant really sleep in. Lunch is at 1230 and you can eat at either the main buffet or by the beach. My first 2 days I ate at the beach. It was so-so....burgers, hot dogs, and fries. On the 3rd day I discovered the main buffet lunch...much better! I never did the buffets at night, but heard from others it was the same food from lunch served for dinner. Great pasta bar..pick out of pastas, 5 sauces, and about 8 ingredients. We went to the gourmet restaurant once. The place is all about atmosphere. Place was as pretty as any 5star restaurant here in DC. The waiters were very professional and started the meal with a cocktail, then mango cold soup, shrimp salad, lobster entree, and tiramisu dessert. The presentation was beautiful, but like any nice restaurant the portions were tiny. The chinese restaurant was also great. sushi was available buffet style. The had traditional chinese soups, appetizers, and entrees. Huge portions! I tried the steak restaurant, but wasn鈥檛 too impressed. The meats were dry and no sauces were provided. The Japanese restaurant is a MUST! The chef is such a great entertainer. I felt bad for barely making a dent in my food :( but it was soooo much! Everyone had the same thing - shrimp, fried rice, egg rolls, steak, chicken, sea bass! They also brought out sushi and fried ice cream dessert. We tipped about $2 at the a la cart restaurants.BarsThey have drink menus at every bar, so you can see what is included and what cost extra. I was impressed with the included alcohols..something for everyone...beer, vodka, rum, tequilla, etc...all the basics! you will see the same bartenders at every bar day to day..which I liked! I made friends with the guys at the beach bar and they would have my drink ready when I would walk up (pineapple juice w/ vodka ) :) There is literally a bar every 10 feet! Bars are open 24hrs a day! There is no drink service on the beach..but it's only a 30 sec walk to the bar..so I didn't mind at all. Beachwhat can I say....it's perfect! they had people raking the beach every morning and constantly picking up trash. I reserved a chair under the hut before I went to breakfast each morning, but I didn鈥檛 need to. I would come back after breakfast and still it was so empty. They have some solicitors walking around the beach, which did get annoying at times. I was asked at least 3 times a day at the beach if I wanted my hair braided or go to restaurants outside the hotel. There are a bunch of fish that are in the shallow end, so I was glad I brought my snorkel gear. The water is crystal clear and very warm! the waves were gentle and plenty of people outside the roped areas using kayaks and other boats. They are free to use, but you must leave a credit card as a deposit.ServiceI was worried about the language barrier..but not once did I encounter someone who didn't speak basic english. Everyone was nice and always saying hi. I also read on this site about a shortage of do not disturb signs..but again, this was not a problem. I saw plenty everywhere!RoomsPerfect!!! bathrooms are completely open. I would definitely recommend the rooms for couples, since it's open. The bathrooms don't have door that are completely closed- open on the top and bottom. So basically you hear EVERYTHING! I was in the 3rd building (3344)..it was perfect. Ocean view and across from the restaurants. Our room did have the moldy smell, but we brought candles so it was tolerable. The beds are very firm and pillows are so-so. I brought my own pillow, so I was ok 飦?Our power shorted everytime I tried to blowdry my hair on high setting鈥o I gave up on nice hair after day one. I think the walls are pretty thin..I could hear people walk up and down the stairs (our room was right in front of the stairs). We received the bottle of champagne, which was yummy! Our mini was stocked daily with 2 beers, 4 water bottles, pepsi, diet pepsi, sprite, and orange soda.Weatherweather was perfect, despite weather.com's promise of daily rain showers. It wasn;t humid at all, and temps never were too hot to sit in the sun.GroundsBeautiful!! You can tell the place is new, b/c the flowers/plants/trees are small..but give it some time and I can tell this place will be lush! Tons of groundskeepers keeping the place looking beautiful. I never saw trash anywhere!we were so tired from sitting in the sun all day, so we didnt try out the disco or casino. The disco is open to 7am, but I never heard people coming home that late. This is definately a relaxing place and not a party people resort. Most people were young couples, like my bf and I. I saw very few families and older couples. But I did see terrific looking kids pools and playgrounds. The people I spoke with said a lot of people were winning $40-50 (paid out in pesos of course) here and there on the slots at the casino!CheckoutWas a breeze. Checkout is at 12. The airport was much MORE hectoc getting out. they went through EVERY carry on bag very carefully...which took forever! It was about 2 hrs to go through the lines and finally reach the hotel gates. Everyone was sweating to death dying for water...finally we got through the lines and water costs $8 at the minimart!!! I guess they want all your money before you leave.Bottom line is the place is great, and you won鈥檛 regret it!

<Content>Everything you will read is true Everything you will read here is true. The good, the bad and the indifferent. I am glad I did my research because it definately helped our trip. We stayed at the Majestic for 7 nights for our honeymoon and it was everything we were looking for. I can say it wont be for everyone.Listen to what they say about booking the Japanese resturant right when you first get there. It books up fast. We visited all the resturants with no real favorites, but we did get a little bored with breakfast and lunch because there are only the same two places open. The shows are lack luster. We watched a few, but never stayed for the whole thing.The casino was small. Big enough for my husband to win $200! So no real complaints there.The pool is addictive and so beautiful. (Leave it in the fridge or the maid will take it).We brought IM and Pepto and did use it. I would reccomend at least bringing it just in case.It is an open concept which we enjoyed, but can see how it could be problematic for people with preteens-teens. It is also a topless resort and beach. We didn't care, but we also didn't know about it.Don't buy anything on the resort, it is very expensive. You can walk about and hour up the beach and find vendors you can barter with or if you leave the resort enterance there is a flea market to the right where you can also barter. They love giving you gifts to make you feel like you have to buy (necklaces, shots, cigars) they all do it, so dont feel bad about walking away. We had a lot of nice necklaces that we got for free by the end that we heard some americans paid $10 for!!!Finally DO THE BAVARRO RUNNERS. We were so glad we did! They take you to the sugar cane field, cigar factory, to a typical dominican home where you get to see a cock fight (only for a minute and not a real one, you can also purchase coffee, cinnamon, chocolate and vanilla for $5), and finally a ranch where you eat lunch and ride horses on the beach. We loved it. Definately our favorite part. We also did the Saona Island. This is a LONG day. Very beautiful and fun, but wouldnt suggest it as the only excusion you do all week.All is all it was everything we wanted and expected. Everything you will read in here is pretty much true, but if you are prepared there is nothing to complain about. Keep in mind we have nothing to compare it to and aren't the kind of people to complain about them working on the elevator or painting a wall. We make our own good time. We would go again, but not for a long time, there are to many other places we want to see first.PS We were also told by another guy there that when him and his wife took the long walk up the beach they stopped at other resorts and ate and drank along the way. We weren't so daring, but it sounded like fun.

We traveled my husband and I and three children, ages 15, 14 and 10. From the moment we arrived at the hotel we were greeted with their Majestic drink, which is a fruity type of drink. The people working at the front desk were very helpful and gave us our rooms right away. We stayed in rooms 4322, 4323 and 4324. (The girl that made our rooms was nice and very accomodating.) Very nice rooms with partial view of the beach and very quite at night time. The food at the hotel was very good. I loved the breakfast buffet, with a wide variety of choices, omelletes, crepes, cereals, fruits, churros, breads, natural juices and the best outmeal and hot chocolate. There are two lunch buffet one in the main dining roon and the other by the beach area, also very good. At night there is a little of everything. You have the Japanese Restaurant which needs reservations, the Chinese which is right next to the Japanese, no reservations for this one. The Gourmet which has an excellent filet mignon. Here we sang happy birthday to my daughter, they turned off the lights and came out with drums and singing happy birthday to a dominican beat. The Caribbean restaurant has a wide variety of dominican dishes and especially liked the red beans. The two beach restaurants are also very good.The beach is beautiful, crystal clear water and clean sand without rocks or shells that bother your feet. The pool is amazing very clean and large. The pool area has enough chairs to go around and is divided into several areas. If you are looking for some quite time to read or just relax, then the pool area near the dining room is ideal for you. If you are looking to have fun, hear music, do aerobics and play games, then the pool area by the wet bar is for you. As well as the beach has the quite side and the fun side which has the same things as games, dancing lessons, etc. The nightly shows are fun and the most see, is The Michael Jackson Show. There is also an excellent nightly saxophone player by the pool area.The best part of the trip was the entertainment group. They work very hard to make your trip enjoyable. They took that extra time to make sure my children had fun especially my daughter. We love you guys and hope to see you soon, again at the Majestic.......Betty, Ernie, Sr., Ernie Jr., Cristina, Bertha, Miguel and Beatriz from Miami

<Author>Dibaco
<Content>Excellent value for money We returned from the Majestic last week, and I would like to give my review to Tripadvisor, as the reviews her were very useful in deciding which hotel to go to.First of all, both me and my girlfriend have an education in hotel management and many years of experience in the hotel industry. Secondly, we have travelled extensively around the world, including the Carribean and Dominican Republic, and believe me, we've seen the good, the bad and the ugly! So I hope this review will give an objective picture of what to expect.= the good = ResortThe resort is beautiful! It looks brand new and is well kept. Throughout our stay, we saw gardners, mechanics, painters and cleaners to keep the resort green, pink and clean all day. The rooms are huge, about twice the size you would expect. I believe they all have at least a jacuzzi in the room and a shower that fits 2 persons. The minibar is restocked daily with beer, water and sodadrinks. The large TV has 32 channels, including movie and sports channels, mostly USA channels. One thing I particularly like (although not very environmental friendly) is that you can keep the Airco on all day  night, so it is always 20 degr.C | 68 degr. F in the room. Another thing thing I liked is the large gym, good equipment. If you work out at home, it's worth bringing your gymshoes etc. to the resort to stay in shape a bit.The poolThe pool is excellent. It is very long as it runs over the lenght of the resort. It is clean, lots of grass, flowers, palmtrees etc. around it, and not overcrowded. Plenty of pool beds available, although some French and German guests have the nasty habbit of 'claiming' a bed early in the morning with a towel or single flip-flop and then go back to bed or breakfast.The beachWhat an amazing beach! It ranks high in my top5 of alltime. Again, plenty of beds available under the palmtrees or umbrellas. It is cleaned througout the day. And the best thing: as it is a private beach, you don't have the annoying beach boys trying to sell you trips and fake watches. You can get kayaks, snorkling gear and boogie board free of charge. You can also rent catamarans, go scuba diving and (I can recommend) rent your personal speedboat for an 1-hour trip.The restaurantsPlenty of choice here. I've counted 7 or 8 restaurants, most of them are not bad at all. Our favorites were the Japanese/chinese restaurant (you need to make reservations only for the tepanyaki tables, but the other tables offer excellent food inclusing sushi and sashimi) and the Caribean restaurant, which serves mainly mexican and local Dominican food. And you have to try the lobster in the seafood restaurant at the beach!Shows  entertainmentAs stated by others, the Michael Jackson show is the best one. The other shows vary from good (Latin dance) to horrible (funny gameshows with audience participation is not my thing at all)The daytime games at the beach and pool are not to bad, some of the annimation crew actually have a good sense of humor.= The bad and the ugly = Of course there are also things which could be improved. Service in the restaurants sometimes leaves a bit to be desired, and unfortunately it's mainly the ladies who seem to lack enthousiasm and hospitality attitude. The gourmet restaurant for which you need to make reservations, was the worst of the 8 restaurants. Food quality and quantity was disappointing, and the waiters were nervous, clumsy and unattentive. Kudos however for Reception and housekeeping staff. Tips1. Do not leave the resort unless you have to. Both in the mini-mall just off the resort and in Playa Bavaro you have to run the gauntlet to avoid vendors of cheap souvenirs and fake sigars. They all sell the same stuff and are quite agressive in their approach.2. Do not book the trip to Sanoa Island unless you are prepared to spend 6-7 hours in a bus to a location which is less attractive that the beach at your hotel.. We were warned on Tripadivor, and met people at the resort who did take the trip. They were very dissapointed. 3. If you like cigars: don't buy them in the hotel, it's a rip off (US$30 per cigar!!) Instead, ask the concierge for the tour to the Davidoff factory. It's close by, and I've heard they let you tast the goods before you buy. Be prepared to pay about 4-6 USD per cigar. So, hope this helpes you to make your choice. This is the best all-inclusive resort I've been in, ever. I can recommend it to anyone!.

Let me say I was very aprehensive about booking this trip after reading some of the reviews. However, after visiting the place my self I can attest that some of the bad reviews are by those few that can never be satisfied. Trust me I have been in the hotel business 22 years in the states and there are some folks that you cannot please no matter what you do.The guest rooms are tastefully decorated and are very spacious. We were concerned about the open plan but the shower and tiolet are separate and have frosted glass doors. Also the shower stalls are huge so the kids could actually change in privacy. The a/c was cold some times too cold. We had to turn it up. The view from balconey was exquiste. At night you could sit out and enjoy the jazz (saxophone) playing from the live solo artist. The resort is only 7 months old. While there are minor issues with the finish it will NOT effect the guest experience. The service was great. Like others have said you are in a spanish speaking country get a clue! With that said the staff was eager to please (always smiling) and would speak to you in english or find some that did. The predominately European guest were great. We had no problems befriending them. I even joined some for volley ball in the pool. The buffet is overwhelming and you are sure to find something to satisfy you. Get bottled water whenever you can. Your room fridge is usually stocked and a tip to the housekeeper will get you extra bottles (or towels etc) if you need.Last but not least the bars. Smile, tip (a dollar) and your drink will be fine trust me. $1 will go along way and I always left a $5 before I retired for the night. Talk to them, smile and the bartenders will be your best freind in no time. Make sure you say hello to Lidio at the lower level lobby bar. Ask him about Ramona... it will bring smile to his face and extra liquor in your cocktail of choice.To end. This is a extremely well designed, laid out and appointed resort. With this they still smile and provide a proffessional level of service that is hard to find here in the U.S.  This place is truly MajesticThe service was excellent. The place is exquisite.

<Author>SeanandKatarina
<Content>Majestic Delivers the goods We spent a week in Majestic Colonial in Punta Cana in mid-July (got back on July 27th) and had a nice, fun, relaxing time. The staff were universally helpful and friendly, the food was decent, our room was clean and spacious, and the beach was beautiful.In sum, if you are looking for a nice resort with a beautiful beach, you could certainly do worse than Majestic. Just remember that this is a highly developed tourist area and will not provide you with a nature experience (be prepared to deal with seeing plenty of tour helicopters buzzing overhead, parasails, banana boats, motor boats, etc). We hope that you find this review helpful! Punta Cana: Majestic is one of at least a dozen all inclusive resorts lining the beach, and all follow a similar arrangement. If you walk on the beach west for about twenty minutes, you will pass all the neighboring resorts and it will be more peaceful, quiet and natural there, but no resort staff clean the beach at that point so some trash will wash up there. Walking on the beach in the opposite direction will take you past resort after resort for miles, some of them appearing very crowded. Some times salesmen from other resorts will try to lure you into theirs. We took a sneak peek in some of the other resorts, and they each have different features. We thought Majestic looked the nicest, basically because of its huge, meandering pool. Grounds/Facilities: Apparently the place is only about a year old. The shrubbery is newly planted, and very small, and the artificial fountains on the resort grounds are not all up and running, and the entrance to the resort is still a construction zone. All rooms have nice balconies, or if on the ground floor, outdoor jacusis. If you can, request a room with a pool or ocean view, as the garden views are kind of crappy. The pool: Sort of the centerpiece of the resort grounds, it stretches for about 400 meters, but is only 4 feet deep, so no deep end or diving. The pool is warm, not brisk. It has nice jacuzzi areas and is very pretty at night.The beach itself: much less crowded than neighboring resorts, and we never had a problem getting beach chairs under nice umbrellas. The water itself is divided into small, roped off areas -- one for swimming , one for the boat launch. water is warm and full of fish even in shallow areas. Lovely beach for lounging, dozing, taking in the beautiful view, people watching (see #9).Water Sports: The resort offers use of snorkel gear, kayaks, katamarans and windsurfing at no extra cost, but requires a 50 dollar lesson to use the katarmanans if you have never done so. They also offer fishing, scuba etc at cost.Snorkeling: A 2 hour snorkeling trip (actially about only 50 minutes in the water) is about 30 bucks. They take you out by motor boat out to sea where the water is deeper and the coral formations more elaborate. It is nice but not breathtaking. We heard Catalina island was better, but didn't go (read below). Some people brought bread with them and fed the fish, which led to huge numbers swarming around you. In our opinion the motor boat snorkeling trips should have been inclusive, not extra money.Excursions: There are several different kinds of all day or half day trips offered at extra cost. We wanted to go to Catalina island, but they only offered trips there with forced stops for shopping, corny entertainment, and so on, so we decided to just stay at the resort.Weather: it was hot and sunny pretty much the whole time, except for our last day, which was cloudy. It only rained twice the whole time, both very brief periods. A constant breeze came in off the ocean. There was a pretty strong current moving sideways in the water, and sometimes larger waves which kicked up sand and effected underwater visibility. Wildlife: some pelican type birds at the beach, hunting for fish. We also saw lizards and a large spider. And of course, the fishes.Some notes and recommendations if you go:1) A couple of the restaurants require reservations. Book your restaurant reservations on your first or second day as they fill up.2) Do not rely on the front desk for a wake up call -- we asked for one for 6.45 AM and got a call at 5.50, and oddly another one at 6.00.3) Most staff don't speak English.4) They had several places to eat, our favorite was La Hispaniola near the beach, which had seafood and steak menus.5) They only let you have one beach towel per person the entire time -- a little stingy. Perhaps you can tip the towel guy and get an extra.6) Bring all the sunscreen you will need with you, as they charge rip-off prices for that stuff at the resort.7) The enterainment is fun but cheesy, and a loud, roudy element congregates around the pool bar.8) Most of the resort patrons are Europeans or other Spanish speaking people, which is nice if you want to get away from other Americans. Consequently, the beach sports lots of topless ladies and men in speedos, so be ready !9) Be prepared to wear a plastic band around your wrist all week. This is to distinguish you as a patron of Majestic rather than one of the other neigboring resorts, and make sure you are not a freeloader.9) Go to the beach at night and look at the stars. Have fun!

<Author>DawgFamily
<Content>Great Vacation My wife and I with our two sons aged 15 and 19 just returned form a week at the Majestic. Just for a frame of reference we have traveled extensively throughtout the Caribbean and stayed at many all inclusives.Check in was a breeze. Our room had a less than desirable view but a quick phone call and two Presidente's later and we were moved no problem. ROOM Very large and well appointed. A few small bugs but nothing to be concerned about as we have seen some of these in most places. The refrigerator is stocked with beer, water and soft drinks. Naturally we needed extra so I left a note with 2USD on the refigerator that said Yo Quiero cinco cerevzas y cinco botellas de aqua. Rough translation I need five beers and five waters. Like magic no problem. Unlike when you travel in Europe if you try your best Spanglish they will try theirs and communication takes place.FOOD Hey its an all inclusive! That said the food was good. It is not five star but you can have everthing from steak to lobster. Go with the proper mindset and you will not be disappointed. We never went hungry and many of the meals were very good. The gourmet and Japanese require long pants but the food was so good even my boys did not mind. We wore linen drawstrings and flip flops. If you want to change walk to the room and pop on the shorts.ENTERTAINMENT Lots to do! The crowd by the pool was always into to something it starts around 9am then they take a break at 1 and then start again at 4pm. I went to get a beer and my son was involved in an arm wrestling match TOO FUNNY!Early and late evening there is a saxophone player by the main lobby named Domingo! He is an EXCELLENT musician and a nice person to boot.. Please tell him Juancito (John) and Barbara (Beverly) say hello. Late night the club is hopping until the wee hours of the morning just ask my boys!PEOPLE This to us was one of the best features. We as Americans were the minority. English is not the predominant language. There were people form Germany, Italy, Spain, Sweden etc... My boys LOVED meeting those people from other countries and learinng about how they live. Just as a note because of this international crowd there are a lot of topless women. This is normal for them and really is no big deal. After a day or so you really did not think much of it. My older son met a friend from Germany and we in turn met his parents. We spent a couple of enjoyable evenings with both couples struggling to communicate over drinks.. My guess is that our sons will go to visit one another in the near future.LESSONS LEARNEDTips (a few dollars here and there go a long way)Noise it can be noisy and people stay up a lot later than I did. If you are a light sleeper bring ear plugsDO not fret over the language barrier. Bring a phrase book, use your hands, draw, act like you are playing charades and it is a lot of fun.Stomach stuff can happen and a little happened to me... Drinks, sun, lobster, desert can harm even a cast iron stomach like mine. Bring some Immodoium and or Pepto Bismol and you will be fine.Drink LOTS of water the sun is hot and you need to stay hydrated.We brough our own insulated mugs (Bubba Kegs) so during the walk from the beach to the bar your drinks stay cold.This is a great hotel with a great staff and our whole family gave it very high reviews.PS find Louis in the Taino restaurant and share s shot of their local drink Mamajuana!
